Backpacks filled with essentials—plus love!

BACK@YOU was created to help open people’s eyes to those that so many of us walk blindly by each day. The homeless are not invisible, and we should not act as if they don’t exist. We all deserve to be treated with dignity and kindness. None of us is less of a person for not having a home. With those principles as our guide, we simply fill backpacks with some essential supplies and basic comforts to share with our homeless neighbors, and our volunteers distribute these backpacks when the cold weather approaches. We make each of our backpacks to show its recipient that someone cares.

We will take it one step further by filling each of these backpacks with the above necessities and a scarf made with love. Each recipient will know that someone cares about and respects them. We want to give them our respect and the knowledge that we've got their backs.

","Backpacks filled with essentials—plus love!BACK@YOU was created to help open people’s eyes to those that so many of us walk blindly by each day. The homeless are not invisible, and we should not act as if they don’t exist. We all deserve to be treated with dignity and kindness. None of us is less of a person for not having a home. With those principles as our guide, we simply fill backpacks with some essential supplies and basic comforts to share with our homeless neighbors, and our volunteers distribute these backpacks when the cold weather approaches. We make each of our backpacks to show its recipient that someone cares.
What We Need & What You Get:Each backpack costs approximately $75 when filled with the following items (not counting the handmade scarf):
Knit hats
Men's thermal socks
Knit gloves
Composition notebooks
Pens
Disposable razors
Chap Stick
Hand sanitizer
Toothbrushes and toothpaste
Antibacterial wipes
Fleece throws
XLarge hoodies
Small LED flashlights

Citypak Project in Chicago has given away more than 15,000 backpacks to homeless friends across the U.S. This fall we will partner with them to receive over 200 backpacks. We will take it one step further by filling each of these backpacks with the above necessities and a scarf made with love. Each recipient will know that someone cares about and respects them. We want to give them our respect and the knowledge that we've got their backs.Perks:
$15 gives a homeless neighbor a backpack made especially for those living on the streets. These backpacks are made for Citypak Project (http://www.citypak.org/about) by High Sierra.

If you show that you donated $20 on or before our BACKPACK BLUES Benefit on April 26, and you attend, you can have your picture taken with the band Smokin' Section and posted on our BACKatYOU.org website.
For a $25 donation - In October when we hand out backpacks, a recipient will thank you personally in a video on Facebook or Twitter.

YOU: So why should I give you even a Penny of my hard earned money Lizz?
Fair question. Because I think ladies should always have the freedom to be unapologetic sexual beings and part of that means guaranteeing we all have access to affordable reproductive healthcare.
YOU: Well I think that too. But you want my money, how you gonna make that happen?
Because I make shit happen.

I am a comedian, author, co-creator of The Daily Show and a feminist. I am also a fierce supporter of women's reproductive rights and in the past year, I have toured the country doing benefits to raise money for Planned Parenthood and NARAL. TO DATE I HAVE HELPED RAISE WELL OVER A MILLION DOLLARS. I am also one of the co founders of A is For, an organization that raises awareness about repro rights and raises money for The Center For Reproductive Rights.

In addition to the money, by using humor to speak truth to hypocrisy, my shows have energized young people to join the fight because comedy is a medium that has increasingly become a crucial way alot of people get their news these days,
We have seen 75% first time donors in many cities and between 65 and 75% women under 35. I have found humor is a very powerful weapon in this war on women and want to keep the momentum going.
YOU: OK, So if I am gonna pull cash out of my non-offshore account and give it to you, what exactly are you gonna do with it?
I want to produce a PSA reminding people where we are and where we will end up if we allow the anti-choice forces to keep furthering their agenda in November.
I need $7,500 dollars for production costs. I am not taking a dime.
The money will go towards paying a filmographer, an editor and a director plus any equiptment rental we may have to pay for.
If I raise more than my goal, it will be donated to A is For so we can keep our awareness going as well as our continuing support for the Center For Reproductive Rights.

By helping me create this campaign we will be reminding America just how much erosion we are seeing in the area of reproductiove rights and we all know that humor poking at the underbelly of dipshittery makes a HUGE impact.
I have made a living responding to the world through humor. My track record speaks for itself. It is an investment that will pay off.
YOU: So who will see this PSA after you make it?
You will see this PSA on cable news shows and your favorite websites and blogs.
And you will also see that through your donation we can make an impact and remind people that we can combat the diarrhea of Super Pac cash with an impactful message.
And any support is welcome. If you have to choose between buying diapers and donating here, for God sakes, the diapers can wait.
You: What?
I kid. If you are cash strapped but support what I am doing, any amount of tweeting and facbooking and twit facing and tumbrgramming you can do would be so appreciated.
Thanks for your time and support!
Let's vag out together!

Lizz

Who Are they?
Fatma, Nuseybe, Hayat, Suad &
column2: Imen are five refugee mothers currently living in Ankara, Turkey. The mothers are seeking funds and resources so that kids displaced by war (including their own)  can be assisted through art to approach their world in a more healthy manner and to expand on their sense of self. Art workshops often yield great designs by these kids which will then be used by the mothers to create stuffed toys. This can answer their needs for safe and sustainable employment.

column1: What They Need
We have already seen the benefit of involving refugee kids in creative art work that helps them reinvent themselves or imagine &
column2: re-imagine their future. Local and international volunteers, especially university students (some of whom are aiding in this project) have been actively trying to create these opportunities. With your funds the mothers hope to continue , with longer more focused art workshops in a safe environment that really allows the kids to sink into their creativity.  A portion of the funds will therefore be spent on getting materials for the kids alone.

column1: The mothers are also looking to purchase sewing machines for themselves and also training that will allow them to make the toys and other products for which their kids will act as creative designers! The video shows the efforts of the mothers which started out as a one-off activity that soon blossomed into its current ambitious form.
How Important is Your Help?

One thing greatly motivating this project is the sense of accomplishment and pride experienced by the kids and mothers through their creative collaboration. When this activity initially took place, planned very casually, there was no thought given to the possibility that it would be a source of purposefulness for the kids and dignity for the mothers. Your help in perpetuating this experience is important.

This project is also motivated by mothers who have come to realize that the many vulnerabilities they face as refugees cannot be overcome without them seeking and receiving their own empowerment. Just as refugee kids need to explore their sense of self as something more or in addition to being a refugee kid, the mothers seek to be something more than refugee mothers. Your contributions will not change their lives. It will assist the mothers to stand on their own feet. After which they will work to change their lives. So that they can identify themselves as working mothers, shaped by the refugee status but not limited  by it.  So that they can work towards living life instead of just surviving hardships.
","Who Are they?

Fatma, Nuseybe, Hayat, Suad & Imen are five refugee mothers currently living in Ankara, Turkey. The mothers are seeking funds and resources so that kids displaced by war (including their own)  can be assisted through art to approach their world in a more healthy manner and to expand on their sense of self. Art workshops often yield great designs by these kids which will then be used by the mothers to create stuffed toys. This can answer their needs for safe and sustainable employment.
What They Need

We have already seen the benefit of involving refugee kids in creative art work that helps them reinvent themselves or imagine & re-imagine their future. Local and international volunteers, especially university students (some of whom are aiding in this project) have been actively trying to create these opportunities. With your funds the mothers hope to continue , with longer more focused art workshops in a safe environment that really allows the kids to sink into their creativity.  A portion of the funds will therefore be spent on getting materials for the kids alone.

The mothers are also looking to purchase sewing machines for themselves and also training that will allow them to make the toys and other products for which their kids will act as creative designers! The video shows the efforts of the mothers which started out as a one-off activity that soon blossomed into its current ambitious form.
How Important is Your Help?

One thing greatly motivating this project is the sense of accomplishment and pride experienced by the kids and mothers through their creative collaboration. When this activity initially took place, planned very casually, there was no thought given to the possibility that it would be a source of purposefulness for the kids and dignity for the mothers. Your help in perpetuating this experience is important.

This project is also motivated by mothers who have come to realize that the many vulnerabilities they face as refugees cannot be overcome without them seeking and receiving their own empowerment. Just as refugee kids need to explore their sense of self as something more or in addition to being a refugee kid, the mothers seek to be something more than refugee mothers. Your contributions will not change their lives. It will assist the mothers to stand on their own feet. After which they will work to change their lives. So that they can identify themselves as working mothers, shaped by the refugee status but not limited  by it.  So that they can work towards living life instead of just surviving hardships.",3.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Ankara, Turkey",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/kids-draw-love-a-project-by-refugee-mothers/pica

We’re fundraising to become an official 501(c)3 non-profit!

ABOUT: Robinhooding for Homeless (R4H) is a grass-roots organization that provides hygiene items to homeless shelters. Since its formation in 2005, R4H has collected, sorted, and delivered hundreds of boxes of needed hygiene items to shelters in the Northern California and San Francisco Bay areas such as PEACE for Families, Gathering Inn, Salvation Army, Shelter Next Door, Loaves &
column2: Fishes, WEAVE, Peace Union Gospel Mission, and St. John.

column1: MISSION: To provide hygiene items to shelters, creating mindfulness and being the change we wish to see in the world. Our goal is to alleviate some of the financial strain on shelters, so they may allocate more of their resources toward developing programs that assist with housing and job placement.

ISSUE: Up until now R4H has been solely funded, and with great success R4H has gained traction in Northern California. R4H was featured at the Celebrate Natomas community event, and has partnered with the City of Sacramento School District “4th R” After-School Program to encourage individuals and families to donate spare hygiene items. With this new growth have come new expenses for items such as fuel, sorting supplies, donation bins, and informational materials. In order to continue growing R4H it has become imperative to pursue a 501(c)3 status to be able to accept money and provide donation receipts.

FOUNDERS: Michelle Buller, is the outreach coordinator who adopted the idea and turned it into a cause. Our distribution manager you will find in most of the pictures, she's our grass-roots champion, only 12-years-old, Ms. Rachel Buller. She increases our region and number of shelters. Christopher Buller serves on the board of directors and is responsible for the jump start of the organization's direction.
DONATE: By donating towards this drive, you will enable R4H to work with a professional organization to correctly establishing our non-profit status, which is no small undertaking and very costly.
Also, please continue being mindful about this cause, we can pick up your donations or you can email us robinhooding1@gmail.com to arrange a drop off. Please continue spreading the word!
EXPENSES ASSOCIATED WITH PROJECT: Filing fees $900, attorney fees $2500, process service fee $100, preperation &
column2: review fees $200. Total amount required is $3,600, however Indiegogo charges 10% (factored into goal amount)

column1: There's a lot of great organizations that need your help, but choosing ours will go right back into the communities we live in. Thank you so much for your consideration and your donation!

Once we are approved, our foundation will be able to provide receipts to you, retro-actively, for your contributions on this fundraiser. Thank you!

","We’re fundraising to become an official 501(c)3 non-profit!

ABOUT: Robinhooding for Homeless (R4H) is a grass-roots organization that provides hygiene items to homeless shelters. Since its formation in 2005, R4H has collected, sorted, and delivered hundreds of boxes of needed hygiene items to shelters in the Northern California and San Francisco Bay areas such as PEACE for Families, Gathering Inn, Salvation Army, Shelter Next Door, Loaves & Fishes, WEAVE, Peace Union Gospel Mission, and St. John.

MISSION: To provide hygiene items to shelters, creating mindfulness and being the change we wish to see in the world. Our goal is to alleviate some of the financial strain on shelters, so they may allocate more of their resources toward developing programs that assist with housing and job placement.

ISSUE: Up until now R4H has been solely funded, and with great success R4H has gained traction in Northern California. R4H was featured at the Celebrate Natomas community event, and has partnered with the City of Sacramento School District “4th R” After-School Program to encourage individuals and families to donate spare hygiene items. With this new growth have come new expenses for items such as fuel, sorting supplies, donation bins, and informational materials. In order to continue growing R4H it has become imperative to pursue a 501(c)3 status to be able to accept money and provide donation receipts.

FOUNDERS: Michelle Buller, is the outreach coordinator who adopted the idea and turned it into a cause. Our distribution manager you will find in most of the pictures, she's our grass-roots champion, only 12-years-old, Ms. Rachel Buller. She increases our region and number of shelters. Christopher Buller serves on the board of directors and is responsible for the jump start of the organization's direction.
DONATE: By donating towards this drive, you will enable R4H to work with a professional organization to correctly establishing our non-profit status, which is no small undertaking and very costly.
Also, please continue being mindful about this cause, we can pick up your donations or you can email us robinhooding1@gmail.com to arrange a drop off. Please continue spreading the word!

EXPENSES ASSOCIATED WITH PROJECT: Filing fees $900, attorney fees $2500, process service fee $100, preperation & review fees $200. Total amount required is $3,600, however Indiegogo charges 10% (factored into goal amount)
There's a lot of great organizations that need your help, but choosing ours will go right back into the communities we live in. Thank you so much for your consideration and your donation!
Once we are approved, our foundation will be able to provide receipts to you, retro-actively, for your contributions on this fundraiser. Thank you!",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Fair Oaks, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/robinhooding4homeless-we-need-your-help/pica

Daugelis leidybinių sistemų programų, o taip pat ir Hiperteksto kalbos redakta 1.10.33 Cicerovho diela ""De finibus bonorum et malorum"" (O najvyššom dobre a zle), napísaného v roku 45 pred n.l. Táto kniha je pojednaním o teórii etiky, a bola veľmi populárna v renesancii. t en tout cas comparable avec celle du français standard. De nombreuses suites logicielles de mise en page ou éditeurs de sites Web ont fait du Lorem Ipsum leur faux texte par défaut, et une recherche pour 'Lorem Ipsum' vous conduira vers de nombreux sites qui n'en sont encore qu'à leur phase de construction. Plusieurs versions sont apparues avec le temps, parfois par accident, souvent intentionnellement (histoire d'y rajouter de petits clins d'oeil, voire des phrases embarassantes).

 

D'où vient-il?

Contrairement à une opinion répandue, le Lorem Ipsum n'est pas simplement du texte aléatoire. Il trouve ses racines dans une oeuvre de la littérature latine classique datant de 45 av. J.-C., le rendant vieux de 2000 ans. И не само што овој модел опстанал пет векови туку почнал да се користи и во електронските медиуми, кој се уште не е променет. Се популаризирал во 60-тите години наm. De nombreuses suites logicielles de mise en page ou éditeurs de sites Web ont fait du Lorem Ipsum leur faux texte par défaut, et une recherche pour 'Lorem Ipsum' vous conduira vers de nombreux sites qui n'en sont encore qu'à leur phase de construction. Plusieurs versions sont apparues avec le temps, parfois par accident, souvent intentionnellement (histoire d'y rajouter de petits clins d'oeil, voire des phrases embarassantes). D'où vient-il?Contrairement à une opinion répandue, le Lorem Ipsum n'est pas simplement du texte aléatoire. Il trouve ses racines dans une oeuvre de la littérature latine classique datant de 45 av. J.-C., le rendant vieux de 2000 ans. Un professeur du Hampden-Sydney College, en Virginie, s'est intéressé à un des mots latins les pluem ipsum бил индустриски стандард кој се користел како модел уште пред 1500 години, кога непознат печатар зел кутија со буem ipsum бил индустриски стандард кој се користел како модел уште пред 1500 години, кога непознат печатар зел кутија со буs obscurs, consectetur, extrait d'un passage du Lorem Ipsum, et en étudiant tous les usages de ce mot dans la littérature classique, découvrit la source incontestable du Lorem Ipsuна книга. И не само што овој модел опстанал пет векови туку почнал да се користи и во електронските медиуми, кој се уште не е променет. Се популаризирал во 60-тите години наm. Wheelchair for Oskitar!
Oskitar is a little boy in Cuzco, Peru with cerebral palsy. He is unable to sit or stand on his own and needs a wheelchair.

I am a special education teacher in Washington State. Recently I traveled to Cuzco, Peru and spent some time volunteering at an orphanage for disabled children. While there I stayed with a wonderful family. Upon returning home, I found out that they had adopted a little boy with cerebral palsy. They asked if I could help them obtain a wheelchair and I told them I would be glad to.

Oskitar needs a custom wheelchair with supports because he is unable to sit on his own. At this time the family is carrying him, holding him or coming up with creative ways to help him sit without falling.
Please help fund  this wheelchair for him.
Oskitar needs a wheelchair:
This is what is needed for Oskitar to get his wheelchair:
<ul>
• $2,612.75 for his custom wheelchair. This wheelchair has been specially designed for his specific needs based off his measurements.

• $1,700 for the delivery to Cuzco. This includes the airfare and fees for transport. I will take the wheelchair there personally in December  to make sure it arrives safely and does not sit in a warehouse at any time.
<li><span style=""line-height: 1.45em
column2: >All dollars raised will be utilized for the purchase and delivery of Oskitar's custom wheelchair.

column1: • When you support our efforts to buy a wheelchair for Oskitar, opportunities to receive original art work are available to you!
We are one world:
<ul>
• When Oksitar outgrows his wheelchair it will be donated to a local orphanage in Cuzco for another little person to use.
• I have traveled extensively in the last few years and have helped in orphanages and schools around the world. It is unusual for a family to adopt a disabled child anywhere in the world.
• One little act of kindness can ripple.
Other ways you can help:
Share this campaign on your facebook page:
<ul>
• Let others know about the efforts to buy this wheelchair.
• Any donation is accepted and appreciated! However perks are available for certain monetary donations.

Please help us raise money for Razan, Mahbob and Sharifa’s humanitarian parole applications to get them from Kabul, Afghanistan to safety with their family in the US. Razan Mahbob and Sharifa are living in fear everyday, unable to leave their house and need your help. While they have US citizen family members ready to sponsor them and are eligible for expedited immigration processing to get to the U.S. the prohibitively expensive $575 PER PERSON fee is the main obstacle in their way. Please share and help us get them to safety!

This is the story of two brothers wrongfully convicted by an
unethical prosecutor after defending themselves against a
violent attack by a crazed ex-convict in broad daylight. Please
read about this miscarriage of justice and how a dangerous
precedent is being set that could affect any of us. We need
your help

Visit our website today to read about a case that exemplifies how an absolute and unquestionable right to defend oneself is not guaranteed. It is unfathomable to think that one would not be justified under the law to defend their own life. How could you be prosecuted for choosing life over death? All it takes is a prosecutor who is willing to do or say anything to win a case at any cost. Read more at

Read more at
We need your support to reverse this precedent and protect the rights of all Virginians to defend their lives and their loved ones against the violent acts of another.

<h3><strong><span><strong>Close Guantánamo, Support the Pelican Bay Prisoners' 5 Core Demands – End U.S.-sponsored Torture at home &amp

Let's wear 2.7 million orange ribbons (it costs $2.7 million per year to maintain each Gitmo detainee)in solidarity with all prisoners who suffer torture paid for by U.S. taxpayers and perpetrated by U.S. federal, state, county &

CloseGitmo.net has set the goal for 2.7 million people to wear orange ribbons as a way to tell the world we oppose U.S. government-sponsored torture at all levels and in all cases. Our focus is on closing the U.S. Naval Station at Guantanamo Bay and supporting the prisoners of Pelican Bay with their 5 core demands.  We call for an end to torture in municipal and county jails where suicide is epidemic among inmates who suffer from poor mental health. We condemn all state prisons who perpetrate the torture of long-term solitary confinement. We also oppose violations of human rights at U.S. federal detention centers as well as all U.S. secret detention centers around the world known as ""Black Sites"" and military bases where torture is well known, i.e. Bagram Air Force Base in Afghanistan (the ""other Guantánamo"").
Our Appeal
We appeal to the conscience of all decisionmakers who control the fate of prisoners at Guantánamo and say: Close Gitmo!
We support the 5 Core Demands of detainees in prisons throughout California led by prisoners from the Pelican Bay SHU (Security Housing Unit) currently on their 5th week of hunger strike:
<ol>
<li><span>Eliminate Group Punishment
<li><span>Abolish the Debriefing (snitching) Policy and modify active/inactive gang status criteri
<li><span>End long-term solitary confinement
<li><span>Provide adequate food
<li>
Provide constructive programs (education, self-help treatment, religious activities and other productive activities).
Why 2.7 million orange ribbons?

In Senate Judiciary Hearings on July 24, 2013, U.S. Senator Richard Durbin announced that it cost $2.7 million/prisoner/year to keep a prisoner in Guantánamo. This amounts to $7400/inmate/day! Those who wear orange ribbons will help bring awareness to how Gitmo ant Pelican Bay prisoners are being subjected daily to torturous, inhumane conditions.
Hunger Strikes in Guantánamo and in California led by prisoners in Pelican Bay

The hunger strike in Guantánamo began February 6, 2013. Soon thereafter nearly all 166 prisoners participated. Sources report that 38 remain firm and have kept fasting (see ""track hunger strike"" at CloseGitmo.net). The inmates began refusing food in protest against the desecration of the inmates’ Korans and evolved to become a wider protest about President Obama's abandonment of his stated commitments over the past five years to close the facility.

The California prisoner hunger strike led by Pelican Bay detainees in the state's only supermax prison started July 8, 2013, with 30,000 prisoners from 22 prisons around the state and others outside the state. As they begin their 6th week on strike, over 250 refuse to eat. 14 prisoners identified as ring leaders have been put in Administrative Segregation Units (Ad. Seg. or ASUs), equivalent to the hole within the hole. They are subjected to cold air blown into their cells and other punitive actions.
<h2><span><strong><strong><span><span>U.S. Government policy at the Municipal, County, State Federal &amp
column2: Global levels perpetrates torture in 4 main ways:

column1: • Extended solitary confinement: The United Nations Special Rapporteur on Torture, Juan Mendez, has stated that solitary confinement beyond 15 days is equivalent to torture. The U.S. leads the world in the number of those held in extended isolation with more than 80,000 detained in city and county jails as well as state and federal prisons and other detention centers. Prisoners in Guantánamo are routinely held in isolation for extended periods and some in California’s Pelican Bay State Prison Security Housing Unit have spent over three decades in the SHU, i.e. solitary confinement or “the hole”.
<ul><li>

Indefinite detention: In both Guantánamo and in all four California Prison SHUs, prisoners suffer deep psychological torture, never knowing when they will be freed.  One California prisoner has suffered 42 years in solitary!

Beyond indefinite detention, the vast majority of Gitmo detainees are held without being charged and 86 out of 166 have been cleared for release but never freed. The Obama Administration has said 46 inmates will never be charged or tried. Both the military and civilian attorneys for the detainees, as well as the International Committee of the Red Cross, have said despair is widespread because of the prisoners' indefinite detention.
<ul>

• Human contact and communication restricted: Prisoners in SHUs are not permitted any human physical contact and are forbidden from making phone calls. Guantánamo inmates are not allowed family visits or phone calls. Meetings with lawyers are monitored in Gitmo and the California SHUs which violates prisoners' rights to confidential communication with defense attorneys.

• Forced feeding: Over 40 prisoners are currently on hunger strike in Guantánamo and are being forced-fed with nasogastric tubes twice daily.  In a letter to Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, President Dr. Jeremy Lazarus of the American Medical Association (AMA) said force-feeding competent prisoners who consciously choice to refuse food is against medical ethical standards. Dr. Gerald Thomson of the Constitution Project condemned the practice saying it is against international ethical standards. Those in Pelican Bay are threatened with this same kind of torture if they continue their hunger strike begun July 8, now in week 6.
<h2><span><strong><strong><span>2.7 million Orange ribbons – wear them in solidarity with Gitmo and Pelican Bay Hunger Strikers
column2: place the orange ribbon on social media pages, i.e. Facebook

column1: Our goal in the coming months is to get 2.7 million people to regularly wear the orange ribbons in solidarity with ending U.S.-sponsored torture and closing Gitmo. We fundraising campaign will renew until this many ribbons have been circulated or until Guantánamo is closed and prisoners on the Pelican Bay Hunger Strike find their 5 core demands met.
Thousands of ribbons have already been distributed in this effort to End U.S. Torture. A running count of the number of ribbons already distributed will be published at CloseGitmo.net.
Funds raised will build strategies to End U.S-sponsored Torture

In addition to distributing ribbons, funds raised from this campaign will go to building solidarity with prisoners on hunger strike in Guantánamo Bay and Pelican Bay.  Your generosity will go to strengthen the CloseGitmo.net initiative through organizing strategies to End U.S.-sponsored torture.  Strategies involve building educational campaigns, supporting direct nonviolent actions, networking with families of prisoners, encourage citizens to contact their members of the U.S. congress, building ties with human rights advocates, working with the coalition in solidarity with the Pelican Bay hunger strike and promoting the Guantánamo: A Comprehensive Exit Strategy.

To see all the non-profit organizations participating in this campaign, please visit CloseGitmo.net.  Nonviolence International has agreed to serve as the Fiscal Sponsor and channel 100% of funds received to support Ending U.S.-sponsored Torture in Guantánamo, Pelican Bay and elsewhere. column1: S. Brian Willson began a 300 calorie/day fast in Portland, OR and ended his fast 3 weeks later after being hit by an SUV while he was at a stop light on his hand-cycle.
Elliott Adams and Tarak Kauff fasted on 300 calorie/day for weeks. They ended their hunger strike on August 4th at a Mosque in Albany, NY after fasting 80 days and 58 days respectively.
Cynthia Papermaster began fasting on June 15, 2013 and continued her hunger strike on 300 calorie/day for 84 days.

Andrés Thomas Conteris began water-only fasting on July 8, 2013, the same day as 30,000 prisoners in California supporting 5 Core Demands to abolish torture in the state prisons. He fasts in solidarity with Gitmo prisoners and those in U.S. prisons who suffer daily torture in the Security Housing Units (SHUs) and Administrative Segregation Units (ASUs) of Pelican Bay.  On Sept. 6, Day 61 of his water-only fast and 2nd day of Diane Wilson's trial, he was fed with nasogastric tubes at a rally in front of the White House to show how Gitmo prisoners are tortured twice daily through force-feeding which is yet another form of torture the prisoners there are subjected to.  Watch this video to see how Yasiin Bey (aka Mos Def) was fed through a nasogastric tube so protest force-feeding in Guantánamo.  For coverage of the September 6 Rally at the White House protesting force-feeding of hunger strikers in Guantánamo click here (videos, photos, U.S./global news articles).

","Close Guantánamo, Support the Pelican Bay Prisoners' 5 Core Demands – End U.S.-sponsored Torture at home & abroad

Let's wear 2.7 million orange ribbons (it costs $2.7 million per year to maintain each Gitmo detainee)in solidarity with all prisoners who suffer torture paid for by U.S. taxpayers and perpetrated by U.S. federal, state, county & municipal governments.

CloseGitmo.net has set the goal for 2.7 million people to wear orange ribbons as a way to tell the world we oppose U.S. government-sponsored torture at all levels and in all cases. Our focus is on closing the U.S. Naval Station at Guantanamo Bay and supporting the prisoners of Pelican Bay with their 5 core demands.  We call for an end to torture in municipal and county jails where suicide is epidemic among inmates who suffer from poor mental health. We condemn all state prisons who perpetrate the torture of long-term solitary confinement. We also oppose violations of human rights at U.S. federal detention centers as well as all U.S. secret detention centers around the world known as ""Black Sites"" and military bases where torture is well known, i.e. Bagram Air Force Base in Afghanistan (the ""other Guantánamo"").
Our Appeal
We appeal to the conscience of all decisionmakers who control the fate of prisoners at Guantánamo and say: Close Gitmo!
We support the 5 Core Demands of detainees in prisons throughout California led by prisoners from the Pelican Bay SHU (Security Housing Unit) currently on their 5th week of hunger strike:
Eliminate Group Punishment
Abolish the Debriefing (snitching) Policy and modify active/inactive gang status criteri
End long-term solitary confinement
Provide adequate food
Provide constructive programs (education, self-help treatment, religious activities and other productive activities).
Why 2.7 million orange ribbons?

In Senate Judiciary Hearings on July 24, 2013, U.S. Senator Richard Durbin announced that it cost $2.7 million/prisoner/year to keep a prisoner in Guantánamo. This amounts to $7400/inmate/day! Those who wear orange ribbons will help bring awareness to how Gitmo ant Pelican Bay prisoners are being subjected daily to torturous, inhumane conditions.
Hunger Strikes in Guantánamo and in California led by prisoners in Pelican Bay

The hunger strike in Guantánamo began February 6, 2013. Soon thereafter nearly all 166 prisoners participated. Sources report that 38 remain firm and have kept fasting (see ""track hunger strike"" at CloseGitmo.net). The inmates began refusing food in protest against the desecration of the inmates’ Korans and evolved to become a wider protest about President Obama's abandonment of his stated commitments over the past five years to close the facility.

The California prisoner hunger strike led by Pelican Bay detainees in the state's only supermax prison started July 8, 2013, with 30,000 prisoners from 22 prisons around the state and others outside the state. As they begin their 6th week on strike, over 250 refuse to eat. 14 prisoners identified as ring leaders have been put in Administrative Segregation Units (Ad. Seg. or ASUs), equivalent to the hole within the hole. They are subjected to cold air blown into their cells and other punitive actions.
U.S. Government policy at the Municipal, County, State Federal & Global levels perpetrates torture in 4 main ways:

Extended solitary confinement: The United Nations Special Rapporteur on Torture, Juan Mendez, has stated that solitary confinement beyond 15 days is equivalent to torture. The U.S. leads the world in the number of those held in extended isolation with more than 80,000 detained in city and county jails as well as state and federal prisons and other detention centers. Prisoners in Guantánamo are routinely held in isolation for extended periods and some in California’s Pelican Bay State Prison Security Housing Unit have spent over three decades in the SHU, i.e. solitary confinement or “the hole”.

Indefinite detention: In both Guantánamo and in all four California Prison SHUs, prisoners suffer deep psychological torture, never knowing when they will be freed.  One California prisoner has suffered 42 years in solitary!

Beyond indefinite detention, the vast majority of Gitmo detainees are held without being charged and 86 out of 166 have been cleared for release but never freed. The Obama Administration has said 46 inmates will never be charged or tried. Both the military and civilian attorneys for the detainees, as well as the International Committee of the Red Cross, have said despair is widespread because of the prisoners' indefinite detention.

Human contact and communication restricted: Prisoners in SHUs are not permitted any human physical contact and are forbidden from making phone calls. Guantánamo inmates are not allowed family visits or phone calls. Meetings with lawyers are monitored in Gitmo and the California SHUs which violates prisoners' rights to confidential communication with defense attorneys.

Forced feeding: Over 40 prisoners are currently on hunger strike in Guantánamo and are being forced-fed with nasogastric tubes twice daily.  In a letter to Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, President Dr. Jeremy Lazarus of the American Medical Association (AMA) said force-feeding competent prisoners who consciously choice to refuse food is against medical ethical standards. Dr. Gerald Thomson of the Constitution Project condemned the practice saying it is against international ethical standards. Those in Pelican Bay are threatened with this same kind of torture if they continue their hunger strike begun July 8, now in week 6.
2.7 million Orange ribbons – wear them in solidarity with Gitmo and Pelican Bay Hunger Strikers

On Sunday 16 March 2014, news media reported that Fred Phelps, founder of the Westboro Baptist Church, was near death.

Because this man has been instrumental in spewing hatred and intolerance for so long, Coming Together, an independent publisher of erotic fiction to benefit charity, wants to make absolutely certain his death is marked by the largest single donation ever made to the Human Rights Campaign.

Think of it as a virtual picketing... with rainbows. Our efforts are not intended to be mean-spirited or gloating. Rather, we simply hope to turn negatives to positives &
column2:
help to erase some of the pain caused by this man and his followers.

Proceeds from this campaign will go straight to the HRC as a donation in honor of Fred Phelps.

C'mon! Add a little of your green to our Rainbow Campaign.

Please help Elias travel to the US for his speaking tour about the vision and mission of Holy Land Trust for peace . Your generous contribution will cover his flight and accommodation expense during his travel to the US in the month of December 2019.

His time in the US will help in raising awareness among the US citizen about Holy Land Trust work for peace and its vision for the future and to recruit International to join Holy Land Trust programs.

Elias Deis, born into a Christian family with a long history of nonviolent resistance in Beit Sahour, Elias Deis’s life was shaped during the First Intifada, watching his father and his community find the path towards justice through peaceful resistance. It was through his Christian upbringing, holding onto Jesus’s sacred words of “loving thy neighbor,” that led Elias into a life journey of engaging his community in transformation.

Through this challenge, he staked out a path of education that would lead him directly into the middle of peacemaking, seeking a deeper understanding of the nature of the violence, the historical roots, and how generational trauma contributes to cycles of unrest and bloodshed. Watching his father lead by example by organizing within the tax-resistance movement in Beit Sahour, being arrested several times, presented him a real-life example of how a community can combat violence in real ways, preparing him to be a community leader.
Joining Holy Land Trust in 2007 as a travel coordinator, Elias has grown the Travel &
column2: Encounter program of Holy Land Trust. His department now facilitates tours and educational packages to some 1,500 peacemakers and sojourners a year. On top of his full-time job, his quest to change the communities around him has led him into an array of leadership positions across the Bethlehem Governorate. in July 2019 , Elias got promoted to be the Executive Director of Holy Land Trust.

column1: Deis was recently elected to the Beit Sahour City Council - one of the youngest members in the history of the council. While on the board, he manages the tourism portfolio, engaging in international relations and community development projects and has been a critical representative to Japan, Turkey, and Lithuania.

Elias's lived experienced, growing up during the Second Intifada, challenging himself and others to find alternative modes to violence within a Christian framework, and the path it has led him down serves as a remarkable story for every Christian and peacemaker.

About the 2019 SFA Encuentro

The Student/Farmworker Alliance (SFA) is a national network of students and young people organizing with the Coalition of Immokalee Workers (CIW) to eliminate sweatshop conditions in the fields. The Fair Food Program and the CIW’s model of worker-driven responsibility has given hope to many in an era of countless attacks on labor rights.

Students continue to make a difference in the fight for a food system based on justice and dignity for farmworkers. While Wendy’s remains the last major fast food company that refuses to sign on the Fair Food program, students are actively fighting to #BootTheBraids off our campuses. Building on this spring’s “4 for Fair Food Tour,” in which farmworkers visited four key campuses to support student demands to end ties with Wendy’s, SFA leaders are demonstrating that we are more than a market demographic — we are an unstoppable movement!
What's Going Down
<ul>
<li>Celebrating and learning from the CIW’s incredible 25-year history of fighting for dignity and respect in the fields
<li>Crafting back-to-school escalation plans in the Wendy’s Boycott and the Boot the Braids campaign
<li>Sustaining the future of SFA's organizing through skill-building workshops and leadership development
<li>Taking action together to inspire us to make change in our home communities, and
• Building strength and solidarity across global grassroots movements for justice.
Why We Need Your Support

We are dedicated to making this Encuentro the most powerful one yet! But we need your help to make that happen. From securing space to providing travel scholarships, every penny you donate will go towards making this year’s Encuentro possible.
So, chip in a little – or a lot! – to support the movement for student/farmworker solidarity!
Other Ways You Can Help
To support student and youth participation in the Campaign for Fair Food, you can also:
<ul>
<li>Share this fundraising opportunity with your friends, family and community networks
<li>Get the word out on social media (using #boycottwendys and @sfalliance)
<li>Become a Fair Food Sustainer to support student organizing year round, and
• Visit the SFA website to find out how you can stay involved locally.
If you've got ideas or questions you'd like to share, just drop us a line at organize@sfalliance.org or give us a ring at 239-657-8311.

Students continue to make a difference in the fight for a food system based on justice and dignity for farmworkers. While Wendy’s remains the last major fast food company that refuses to sign on the Fair Food program, students are actively fighting to #BootTheBraids off our campuses. Building on this spring’s “4 for Fair Food Tour,” in which farmworkers visited four key campuses to support student demands to end ties with Wendy’s, SFA leaders are demonstrating that we are more than a market demographic — we are an unstoppable movement!
What's Going Down
Celebrating and learning from the CIW’s incredible 25-year history of fighting for dignity and respect in the fields
Crafting back-to-school escalation plans in the Wendy’s Boycott and the Boot the Braids campaign
Sustaining the future of SFA's organizing through skill-building workshops and leadership development
Taking action together to inspire us to make change in our home communities, and
Building strength and solidarity across global grassroots movements for justice.
Why We Need Your Support

We are dedicated to making this Encuentro the most powerful one yet! But we need your help to make that happen. From securing space to providing travel scholarships, every penny you donate will go towards making this year’s Encuentro possible.
So, chip in a little – or a lot! – to support the movement for student/farmworker solidarity!
Other Ways You Can Help
To support student and youth participation in the Campaign for Fair Food, you can also:
Share this fundraising opportunity with your friends, family and community networks
Get the word out on social media (using #boycottwendys and @sfalliance)
Become a Fair Food Sustainer to support student organizing year round, and
Visit the SFA website to find out how you can stay involved locally.
If you've got ideas or questions you'd like to share, just drop us a line at organize@sfalliance.org or give us a ring at 239-657-8311.",0.0,0,"6 Campaigns
|","Immokalee, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/2019-student-farmworker-alliance-encuentro/pica

Introduction

UNIVERSOLE empowers women caught in the bondage of human trafficking through SHOE MAKING!

column1: <ul>
• Erika Lynn McKelvey, founder and CEO of UNIVERSOLE, graduated from Savannah College of Art and Design with a BFA in Accessory Design.
• Erika created UNIVERSOLE to use her skill to help others in need so they can become productive citizens in their country.
• Human trafficking is the fastest growing criminal enterprise in the world.
Universole travelled to India in February of 2013, working with survivors of human trafficking, teaching them the basics of leather working and sandal making.
We need your help getting back to India in November 2013 to continue what we started in February bringing Hope and Future to the women in India.
<h3>What We Need &amp
We NEED to raise $10,000.
<ul>
• $6,000 is needed for equipment and materials used for making the shoes.
• $4,000 is needed for training expenses while in India.
• The amount raised over what is needed will go into an account for setting up a new vocational center.
• Check out the perks to receive a wonderful handcrafted item from India with your donation!
PERKS: (Pictures not shown for all perks)
<ol>
• $15 donation ~ You will receive a vintage hand painted postcard from India with an update on our training in India.
• $25 donation ~ You will receive a 100% pure silk scarf from India with an update on our training in India.
• $30 donation ~ You will receive a set of bangles from India with an update on our training in India.
• $50 donation ~ You will receive a gorgeous 3 hook Blue Pottery wall hanger from India with an update on our training in India.
• $65 donation ~ You will receive a handmade basket filled with Indian Spices with an update on our training in India.  This is perfect for the chef in your family!
• $100 donation ~ You will receive a pair of Layaka {WORTH} Sandals, your choice of color, handmade by survivors of human trafficking with an update on our training in India.
• $200 donation ~ You will receive a hand-carved block print of your logo or favorite design with an update on our training in India.
• $350 donation ~ You will receive a hand block printed quilt from India with an update on our training in India.
• $1,000 donation ~ You will receive a striking and colorful 15.5"" x 16"" hand carved/hand painted wood elephant from Jaipur, India with an update on our training in India.
Our Story
created to partner with organizations and vocational centers in impoverished
areas
column2: to teach at risk women, orphans aging out of the orphanage, and

column1: survivors of human trafficking a way out, via leather skills and SHOE
MAKING.
is to empower the survivors with sustainable skills.  These skills allow
these women to earn a respectable income and provide for their families with
DIGNITY
column2: to have HOPE and a FUTURE. UNIVERSOLE will only work with proven

column1: vocational centers that do not use or exploit children or women.
leather products are purchased from the vocational centers, shipped back to the
United States, marketed and sold.  The sale of these items helps sustain
training and bring attention to the plight of women being sold into human
trafficking.
future ambition to expand into multiple countries, teaches product designs that
have been specifically created with the culture and products indigenous to that
country in mind.  For example, in India, the traditional sari was
incorporated into their shoe design.  All materials and equipment were
purchased locally, helping the merchants and economy of that community.

column5: >Find out more on our website www.universolehope.com

<ul>
• Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
• Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!
• Go like our facebook page and follow us on twitter!

Thank you for your support and helping us reach our goal to go back to India in November!

Sahodaran:
column2: >Due to the current legislation of India, the

column1: LGBT-community consists of exposed individuals who face various issues
injustices, refused health care and sometimes even legal discrimination.
column3: >, which means “brother” in Malayam, one of South India’s official languages, is a safe space for people of the LGBT (lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender) and MSM (men who has sex with men) community of Pondicherry,
column4: >where homosexuals and transgender women or men feel secure, accepted and loved.

column1: Sahodaran works as a supporting association for
LGBTs and MSMs, providing health promotion and education for these vulnerable
groups. Since these groups have very little chance of proper health care, Sahodaran offers health counseling and treatment as well as counseling concerning mental
health and well-being.  Furthermore, Sahodaran promotes education both for
their own members and the rest of the community as well as offering
skill-building training and executing human rights campaigns.
In the near future Sahodaran hopes to extend their activities
by offering shelter for those LGBTs who have no place to live, due to family issues
or other community challenges. Sahodaran also wants to fight discrimination in the
workplace by reaching out to different organizations and factories in order to help
them understand that homosexuals are equal members of society. However, with
the current regulation in India that is a difficult task.<div>
Sahodaran and a transgender. She has always known that she was different from the
other boys in her hometown. People used to ask her why she acted like a girl
and why she was only playing with the girls and not with the boys, but Sheetal
couldn’t answer them. Playing with girls just came natural to her. Sheetal, who
then was named Rajesh, was sexually abused for the first time by the neighbor
of her parents when she was 8 years old. He held her captive in his house for a
day and consistently raped her until the parents returned home. However, it
wasn’t until the age of 17, when she moved to Goa to study engineering, that
she was confronted with her sexuality. The first night she spent in her new
dorm the general secretary of the dorm came to her room and raped her. Sheetal
received no compassion from her friends. Instead they started calling her
“homo” and wrote it in big letters on the wall of the hallway where she lived.

column2: >Sheetal didn’t know what “homo” meant so she contacted a doctor, who told her

column1: to come back in the evening for a consultation. When she came back, the doctor
bound her and raped her. Eventually she came to understand what she was and she
found a small group of friends in Goa who supported her. As a group of
homosexuals they were exposed to scrutiny and discrimination, especially by
authorities. One night in particular stands out for Sheetal, when the police
took her and four of her friends to the police station, where they tortured and
abused them throughout the night for no reason other than that they were gay.
she returned to her hometown as gay or MSM (the Indian term for gay is “men who
have sex with men”) she came to realize that her sexuality was not a private
matter. Both of her parents got fired from their jobs, they threatened to
commit suicide and they burned her certificate in engineering from Goa. They
told her that she brought shame on the family and that she was dead to them.
Sheetal was devastated and left the home of her parents. She moved to Chennai
where she worked scrubbing floors to earn a living. Today she lives in
Pondicherry with her husband and she’s happy and hopeful. She started SCOHD as
a home where homosexuals and transgender can talk freely and be themselves,
however it has turned into so much more. Today Sahodaran has 2233 members and the
LGBT-community of Pondicherry is growing.
“We
will not stop being who we are, and at some point they will have to acknowledge
us. India is changing, but the government is not. We won’t give up and I am
hopeful. We will get there one day. I just hope I will be alive to witness it
once we do.”
Members of Sahodaran:
Rukshana is a Muslim and a transgender. Her family always knew that she was
different than other boys her own age and she was therefore kept inside the
house of her parents throughout most of her childhood. She wanted to become a teacher,
but when she went to Chennai in order to pursue her dream, some of her old
classmates told her parents that she had gone to Chennai just to undergo the
sex reassignment surgery (SRS). When she came home to her family after a couple
of weeks in Chennai they all turned against her. She was forbidden to go back
to Chennai and at home she was tortured on a regular basis, beaten by her
father and brothers, she was often not allowed in the house and she was
deprived of both food and water.
Thus, she was forced to move, and as many
other transgender men, she moved to Mumbai, where she was quickly inducted into
the “transgender community”. This is a harsh community run by gangsters, and
due to lack of education, social acceptance and her looks, she was forced into
prostitution. She managed to escape and moved back to Pondicherry. Her
neighbors in Pondicherry were, however, far from welcoming. One evening in
Auroville seven of them attacked her, took her into a cashew field, held a
knife to her throat and raped her. They told her that she deserved it and that
“this was the way she should have sex with men.” After years of low-wage jobs
in Pondicherry, she finally saved up the money for the SRS procedure.
After
coming home to Pondicherry from the operation in Mumbai, her neighbors were
standing outside the building waiting for her to come home. They ripped the drain
out of her stomach and beat her to the point where she could no longer stand on
her feet. She was thrown on the street covered in blood and it was made clear
that she was not welcomed in the house again. At that point, Rukshana was
ready to commit suicide. But instead she called Sheetal, who saved her. And her
life has not been the same since. At Sahodaran she has found a place where she
belongs, a place that accepts her for who she is and for the first time of her
life, she has found real friends. Sheetal has helped her to get an identity
card as a transgender, she has helped her to get a job and first and foremost
she, and the community at Sahodaran, has helped her heal the psychological scars
her life has left her with. When her father died a couple of years ago she was
not allowed to attend the funeral. She came anyway, and as a consequence a
grave was dug next to her fathers and her family told her that this grave was
for her and if she ever came back, they would kill her.
“Everyday was a struggle and I wanted to kill myself,
because I thought that society didn’t want me. Sahodaran has given me a reason
to live. They’ve given me an identity. For that I’m forever grateful.”
When the community where the now 18-year-old Madhavi used to live realized that he was
gay, they excluded him from day-to-day life. His friends distanced themselves
from him and everywhere he went, he was met with closed doors, whispers and
homophobic names being shouted at him. In the classroom the teachers used to
put him down in front of the other students, calling him names and the other
children used to laugh at him. Throughout 10<sup>th</sup> grade, when Madhavi
was only 14 years old, he was left to himself. He had no friends and no support
from his family, which led him to two suicide attempts. When the senior students
at his school realized that he was gay they made his life a living hell. One
day, after school, 6 of them attacked him, dragged him into an empty room and
forced him to take off his pants so they could have sex with him. When Madhavi
refused, they beat him up until he fainted. While he was unconscious, they
raped and tortured him. Madhiva was hospitalized for a week after that incident
and the police refused to investigate the case further. Madhiva was only 14
years old when this incident took place. When he graduated high school he met
his first boyfriend. However, as soon as the relationship became sexual, his boyfriend
invited 4 of his friends over to his house, where Madhiva was staying, and he
forced Madhavi to have sex with them.
Only 6 months ago Madhavi decided to move to
Mumbai and he, as many others before him, got pulled into the destructive
transgender/homosexual environment of Mumbai. Because Madhiva is gay and it is
illegal for men to have sex with other men according to article 377 of the
Indian Penal Code, he was automatically excluded from society. When you are
homosexual in India, no one wants to be seen with you or even sit next to you
on the bus. Thus, you have two options in order to survive: begging or
prostitution. Madhiva chose the latter and worked as a prostitute for several
months in Mumbai. Today Madhiva lives in Pondicherry and is a proud member of
Sahodaran. Not only has he found friends at Sahodaran, he has found “best friends”, who
accept him for who he is and who makes him feel special. At Sahodaran he helps
other boys in his situation and he finally feels that his life has meaning.
“Sahodaran
has given me a place where I belong. I now see my sexuality as a gift rather
than as a burden. I’m special. My life has value and now I go through life with
my head held high.”
The Rainbow Walk

column2: >Sahodaran would like to raise money for a

column1: Rainbow Walk in order to help the Pondicherry government realize how large the
LGBT-community is in Pondicherry and that they need their rights as homosexuals to
be respected by society. As the situation is now, article 377 of the Indian
Penal Code is ruining the lives of numerous men and women in India.
Article 377 of the Indian Penal Code is the
law against “unnatural offences.”—<i>Whoever voluntarily has carnal intercourse
against the order of nature with any man, woman or animal, shall be punished
with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a
term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
Article
377 entails the complete prohibition of the penetrative sexual acts engaged in
by homosexual men, which initially criminalizes their sexual expression and
identity. Furthermore, article 377 has a severe impact on their dignity and
self-worth. Police harassment, social exclusion and legal discrimination have

become everyday-life for most homosexuals in India. As in the case of Sheetal and Rukshana, homosexuals are often shunned by their families when they come out to their parents and they are often forced to live in the streets. It is very hard for homosexuals to enter the job market and discrimination on the
workplace and by employers is common. This often forces them into
prostitution and begging in the streets.
The
stigma and prejudice has fostered a culture of silence around homosexuality,
which results in a vast number of male rapes and male prostitutes in India.
Before Rukshana became
a woman, she was stopped one night by the police in the streets of Pondicherry, where they ordered her to take off all of her clothes in front of a
crowd of people. The police officers pocked her genitals with their knight sticks and made fun of her to great amusement for the surrounding bystanders. Sadly this situation is
far from unique. Thus,
many are forced to hide their sexuality because they are afraid. However,
hiding one’s sexuality is difficult and often the family will find out
eventually. One week ago Sheetal helped save a boy from a middle class family
in Pondicherry, whose parents had wrapped him in a fishing-net with the
intention of setting fire to him and drop him into the sea. Luckily he escaped.
Sheetal: “The
Rainbow walk is so important to us, because we feel like the homosexuals of
Pondicherry have no voice. Whenever we seek funding for campaigns that aims at
creating awareness of homosexual’s rights, people refuse to have anything to do
with us due to article 377. Because of the government, everyone is afraid to
support us. That is why we desperately need help from abroad. T
column2: >he Rainbow Walk will be a dream come

column1: true, not only for the members of Sahodaran but also for other homosexuals in
Pondicherry who are afraid to come out. They need to know that they are not
alone and that we are standing up for their rights. Homosexuals don’t even have
an identity, they are just “men who have sex with men” and that is not right.
What about the lesbians? What about the bisexuals? Even though many are afraid
of coming out, it is a consolation for them to know that we are here. They just
want to be who they are, feel loved and like a part of the society. I think
that’s a human right.”
Gandhi: “Be the change you wish to see in
the world”
Imagine
that every time you take a seat on the bus, no one wants to sit next to you,
because people are disgusted by you. The repulsion the Indian society has for the
LGBT community is rooted in ignorance and the social stigma of being seen with
someone who is homosexual. This falls back on the government of India and article
377, which is still used as a tool by the police to harass, extort and
blackmail homosexual men, hindering them from seeking legal assistance because
they too would be penalized for having “unnatural sex.” Sadly, this is everyday life for homosexuals in India. By contributing to this project you’re first and foremost helping
Sahodoran fund their Rainbow Walk, but you’re also showing the government of India,
that a change is not only needed but also demanded. The money that is not spend on the Rainbow Walk will help Sahodaran in their further work for the LGBT community of Pondicherry!
Please help Rukshana, Madhavi, Sheetal and the rest of Sahodaran raise awareness of the devastation Article 377 has caused homosexuals in India by making a small contribution to their Rainbow Walk!
- Love is a human right

illegal for men to have sex with other men according to article 377 of the
Indian Penal Code, he was automatically excluded from society. When you are
homosexual in India, no one wants to be seen with you or even sit next to you
on the bus. Thus, you have two options in order to survive: begging or
prostitution. Madhiva chose the latter and worked as a prostitute for several
months in Mumbai. Today Madhiva lives in Pondicherry and is a proud member of
Sahodaran. Not only has he found friends at Sahodaran, he has found “best friends”, who
accept him for who he is and who makes him feel special. At Sahodaran he helps
other boys in his situation and he finally feels that his life has meaning.
“Sahodaran
has given me a place where I belong. I now see my sexuality as a gift rather
than as a burden. I’m special. My life has value and now I go through life with
my head held high.”
The Rainbow Walk
Sahodaran would like to raise money for a
Rainbow Walk in order to help the Pondicherry government realize how large the
LGBT-community is in Pondicherry and that they need their rights as homosexuals to
be respected by society. As the situation is now, article 377 of the Indian
Penal Code is ruining the lives of numerous men and women in India.
Article 377 of the Indian Penal Code is the
law against “unnatural offences.”—Whoever voluntarily has carnal intercourse
against the order of nature with any man, woman or animal, shall be punished
with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a
term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
Article
377 entails the complete prohibition of the penetrative sexual acts engaged in
by homosexual men, which initially criminalizes their sexual expression and
identity. Furthermore, article 377 has a severe impact on their dignity and
self-worth. Police harassment, social exclusion and legal discrimination have

become everyday-life for most homosexuals in India. As in the case of Sheetal and Rukshana, homosexuals are often shunned by their families when they come out to their parents and they are often forced to live in the streets. It is very hard for homosexuals to enter the job market and discrimination on the
workplace and by employers is common. This often forces them into
prostitution and begging in the streets.
The
stigma and prejudice has fostered a culture of silence around homosexuality,
which results in a vast number of male rapes and male prostitutes in India.
Before Rukshana became
a woman, she was stopped one night by the police in the streets of Pondicherry, where they ordered her to take off all of her clothes in front of a
crowd of people. The police officers pocked her genitals with their knight sticks and made fun of her to great amusement for the surrounding bystanders. Sadly this situation is
far from unique. Thus,
many are forced to hide their sexuality because they are afraid. However,
hiding one’s sexuality is difficult and often the family will find out
eventually. One week ago Sheetal helped save a boy from a middle class family
in Pondicherry, whose parents had wrapped him in a fishing-net with the
intention of setting fire to him and drop him into the sea. Luckily he escaped.
Sheetal: “The
Rainbow walk is so important to us, because we feel like the homosexuals of
Pondicherry have no voice. Whenever we seek funding for campaigns that aims at
creating awareness of homosexual’s rights, people refuse to have anything to do
with us due to article 377. Because of the government, everyone is afraid to
support us. That is why we desperately need help from abroad. The Rainbow Walk will be a dream come
true, not only for the members of Sahodaran but also for other homosexuals in
Pondicherry who are afraid to come out. They need to know that they are not
alone and that we are standing up for their rights. Homosexuals don’t even have
an identity, they are just “men who have sex with men” and that is not right.
What about the lesbians? What about the bisexuals? Even though many are afraid
of coming out, it is a consolation for them to know that we are here. They just
want to be who they are, feel loved and like a part of the society. I think
that’s a human right.”
Gandhi: “Be the change you wish to see in
the world”
Imagine
that every time you take a seat on the bus, no one wants to sit next to you,
because people are disgusted by you. The repulsion the Indian society has for the
LGBT community is rooted in ignorance and the social stigma of being seen with
someone who is homosexual. This falls back on the government of India and article
377, which is still used as a tool by the police to harass, extort and
blackmail homosexual men, hindering them from seeking legal assistance because
they too would be penalized for having “unnatural sex.” Sadly, this is everyday life for homosexuals in India. By contributing to this project you’re first and foremost helping
Sahodoran fund their Rainbow Walk, but you’re also showing the government of India,
that a change is not only needed but also demanded. The money that is not spend on the Rainbow Walk will help Sahodaran in their further work for the LGBT community of Pondicherry!
Please help Rukshana, Madhavi, Sheetal and the rest of Sahodaran raise awareness of the devastation Article 377 has caused homosexuals in India by making a small contribution to their Rainbow Walk!
- Love is a human right",7.0,0,"1 Campaign

Feed 2000 families in the month of Ramadan
Ramadan Campaign for this year (2019) will be allocated to distribute food aid baskets to 2000 families in the capital Sana'a.
Mona Relief has carried out twice two campaigns for Ramadan we have been able reach out more than 3000 families just in the holy month of Ramadan the two last years.
Food baskets

Each food aid basket will contains 25 kg of flour, 5 kg of rice, 5 kg of sugar, 2 litters of cooking oil, 2 kg of red lentils, 1 kg of powdered milk, 4 kg of dates and 4 packages of pasta. Each food basket will cost $ 40 and will feed a family from 6-8 members for the whole month.
Why your donation and support is important

Four years of conflict have left 22.2 million people in need of humanitarian assistance, 11.3 of which are in acute need. This increase is driven by a deterioration of the situation in key humanitarian sectors. And millions of Yemeni people have no idea how can they get their next meal.

As a matter of fact, your donation and support are very important to help to alleviate the suffer of Yemeni people not only in Ramadan but for the whole year and much more in this holy month because there is many people if we don't help them by delivering food baskets they otherwise will have nothing for iftar, the nightly meal when families break their Ramadan fast.

In fact, After 15 hours of fasting these people need something to break their fast, as a gift they give their selves and because those people have nothing as they are almost poor, we are at Mona Relief trying to help them and delivering them food aid baskets for this holy month of Ramadan.
Since it was established in 2015, Mona Relief has been carried out over 250 projects in Yemen and reaching our more than 45000 families all over the country.

This year, 2019, unfortunately, the war is still going on, but that doesn't stop us. Our goal this year will be to provide Ramadan packages to 3000 families with food aid baskets which contains wheat, rice, sugar, cooking oil, powdered milk, dates, lentils, and pasta.
Mona Relief, a 100% Yemeni Organization based in Yemen took the initiative with this campaign. With as simple as 40 dollars, you are able to feed a family for a whole month.
Thanks in advance to every single person who donated and support our humanitarian work in Yemen.
Past work by Mona Relief
Mona Relief has been carried out over 200 projects in Yemen since the war started in 2015.
<h3 style=""text-align: center
column2: >See all of our latest projects here: https://www.monareliefye.org/en-news

column1: To get more information about the current situation in Yemen you have to read this

Yemen has become a failed and devastated state. Since March 2015, 9,245 people have been killed and 52,800 injured. Coalition air strikes are the leading cause of civilian casualties. According to the U.N. Human Rights Council, civilians have repeatedly been the victims of ""unrelenting violations of international humanitarian law."" About 75 percent of the population — 22.2 million people — needs humanitarian assistance. Some 17.8 million people do not know where their next meal is coming from, and 8.4 million are considered at risk of starvation. Severe acute malnutrition is threatening the lives of almost 400,000 children under the age of 5. Half of the country's 3,500 health facilities are functioning and at least 16.4 million people lack basic health care. Medics have struggled to cope with the world's largest cholera outbreak, with more than 1 million suspected cases and 2,248 associated deaths since April 2017. More than 3 million people have been forced to flee their homes, including 2 million who remain displaced.
Key Facts about Yemen

Three and a half years of conflict have left 22.2 million people in need of humanitarian assistance, 11.3 of which are in acute need. This increase is driven by a deterioration of the situation in key humanitarian sectors.
Food Security and Agriculture

17.8 million people in Yemen are food insecure. Out of this, approximately 8.4 million people are severely food insecure and at risk of starvation - a worrying increase of 24 per cent. The conflict has destroyed people’s livelihoods and reduced their purchasing power, making it difficult for many Yemenis to meet minimal food needs.
Health

With only 50 per cent of health facilities fully functional, and a disruption of salaries paid to health personnel, 16.4 million people in Yemen require assistance to ensure adequate access to healthcare – 9.3 million of whom are in acute need.

The overriding humanitarian need is access to minimum healthcare for people whose lives are at risk due to illness or injury. The latest cholera outbreak has underscored the impact of the failing health system.
Water, Sanitation and hygiene

An estimated 16 million Yemenis need humanitarian assistance to establish or maintain access to safe water, basic sanitation and hygiene facilities, out of which 11.6 million are in acute need. Collapsing urban water and sanitation systems, deteriorating water and sanitation conditions in rural areas, and lack of means to maintain personal hygiene and purchase safe drinking water all contributed to one of the worst cholera outbreaks.
Malnutrition

Some 1.8 million children and 1.1 million pregnant or lactating women are acutely malnourished, including 400,000 children under the age 5 who are suffering from severe acute malnutrition. An estimated 7.5 million people are in need of nutrition assistance, with 2.9 million people who will require treatment for acute malnutrition in 2017.
Shelter and essential items

An estimated 5.4 million people need emergency shelter or essential household items, including IDPs, host communities and initial returnees. Ongoing conflict-related displacements, as well as initial returns to some areas, are driving these needs. 2.6 million people are in acute need of assistance.
Protection

With the increasing conflict, Yemen is one of the world’s largest protection crises. About 12.9 million people need assistance to protect their safety, dignity or basic rights, from violations of IHL, grave violations of children’s rights and gender-based violence.

Displacement and conflict has impacted vulnerable households and persons with specific needs, resulting in negative coping mechanisms and mounting psychosocial support needs. 4.9 million people are living in acutely affected areas.
Education

The 2017/2018 school year started with a setback in the education process in 13 out of 22 governorates. This is due to the extended time of non-payment of salaries for teachers. Schools across the country are unfit for use due to conflict-related damage, hosting of IDPs, or occupation by armed groups. An estimated 4.1 million school-age children require assistance to continue their education.
Livelihoods and community resilience

Around 8 million conflict-affected individuals require livelihoods assistance to enhance their selfreliance to address basic needs and reduce dependency on relief assistance. Communities require support to promote resilience, including clearance of landmines and other explosives in up to 22 governorate

column1: <h3 style=""text-align: center

Mona Relief is a 100% Yemeni Organization based in Sanaa, Yemen. We are an internationally recognized by U.N. and other organizations. We carry out projects in accordance with Yemeni relative laws and regulations.

We are recognized by the many different communities across Yemen. All of our work is documented with pictures, videos and stories directly from within Yemen. We are completely independent and none of our work is politicized.
Mona Relief, a 100% Yemeni Organization based in Yemen took the initiative with this campaign. With as simple as 40 USD, you are able to feed a family for a whole month.
The organization activities are mainly focused in the field of humanitarian relief and development by motivating and organizing volunteer, charitable and humanitarian work.

We had great success with the campaign from 2016 (#20foryemen) , 2017 and 2018 (Ramadan Campaign), we hope for an even greater success for this campaign. Our activities during 2017 increased rapidly with many projects. Our fundraising campaign for Aslam area of Hajjeh sets to begin here, and we hope you will help the people of Yemen to achieve it.
<h3 style=""text-align: center
column2: >We do all the work ON THE GROUND in Yemen.

column1: OUR MISSION:
To prevent and alleviate human suffering in the face of emergencies with the power of collaborative efforts and the generosity of donors.
OUR VISION:
To be the most effective humanitarian organization in Yemen, with a view to preventing and alleviating human suffering, and promoting human dignity.
OUR VALUES:
Our fundamental principles promote: Humanity, Impartiality, Neutrality, Independence, Voluntary Service, Unity, Transparency.
You can have more idea about Mona Relief through visiting our website at this link: www.monareliefye.org
Or through our accounts at social media

-- Twitter --
www.twitter.com/monarelief
www.twitter.com/monareliefye
-- Facebook --

www.facebook.com/monareliefye
www.facebook.com/monareliefarabic

-- Instagram --
www.instagram.com/monarelief

-- Flickr --
www.flickr.com/monareliefyemen
Cant Donate? That's Okay.. Raise Awareness!

Not everybody can donate, but everybody can make a difference - it doesn't always have to be money, you can raise awareness by using the twitter hashtag: #yemen #saveyemen #monarelief to raise awareness about this campaign.
Don’t forget to include a link to the campaign. Share it with family and friends and help spread the message!
Last Words
This concept comes to fruition with the aim that every human being should be able to live with dignity without having to worry about the very basic right of sustenance.
Please give generously because the only way to live a pleasant life is either in someone's heart or someone's prayer. And in this case you get both!
Mona Relief is nothing without donors, and therefore we hope you will keep making us strong.
Don’t forget to visit our website https://www.monareliefye.org previous projects.
