Short Summary
Short Summary:

My name is Alonzo “Zochi” Young: I am a teacher, mentor, and founder of njiamovement, ""The Way of Embodied Leadership through Movement"".  I help youth and adults in underserved communities to discover and explore their untapped potential, empower them as leaders, and provide these communities with tools and interpersonal skills to manage conflict nonviolently. The core vehicles I use for this unique, transformative work are the introspective and centering peaceful practices of Taiji, Meditation, and Aikido. These modalities provide an intersection of self-sustaining life skills to support communities to:
• Manage Anger and Conflict
• Reduce Stress
• Increase Capacity
• Face Fear
• Improve Relationships
• Enhance Health and Well-Being
• Discover inner PEACE

The OPPORTUNITY

I have a unique opportunity to teach in Africa this winter in Ethiopia and Kenya - from  January to March  2015.  This journey will serve as a building block for a cultural bridge between communities in Africa and the communities I serve in the Bay Area and throughout the U.S.

Hawasa Ethiopia:

My first leg of this pilgrimage will be to Hawasa, Ethiopia.   With your assistance and the support of organizations such as Aiki Extension's Aikido Ethiopia Project (http://www.aikiextensions.org/programs/ae-progr...), Action For Youth ( http://actionforyouth.org ), Awassa.org http://awassa.org), and Pushing for Peace (http://www.pushingforpeace.org/)
I will be able to:
• Teach Aikido and introduce creative facilitation skills, games, and activities to various age youth throughout the region.
<li>Prepare, support, and witness 9 youth with their historical ""Rite of Passage"" exam for their Black Belts in Aikido.
• Assist with the opening of a new facility built specifically to provide youth with and adequate space to support future growth of youth to embody peace and leadership skills.
• Support various organizations and communites in the region with these practices

Nairobi, Kenya

The
details for Kenya have not be full worked out yet.  There are
several youth organizations in Kenya presently requesting me to bring  njiamovement and Peace Games
to their communities. As the details of this leg of my itinerary in Kenya become clearer I will update my
schedule.

""If you want to go fast, go alone.  If you want to go far, go with others.” 

In order to take full advantage forward into this marvelous
opportunity, I need your help. As the African proverb states, <i>“If you
want to go fast, go alone.  If you want
to go far, go with others.”  I  need your help to raise $5,000 (to cover transportation cost)
for this venture.
The Impact

With your contribution to this journey, I will be able to extend this work and practice to the peoples of Ethiopia and Kenya - as well as create a cultural bridge that will connect many communities across continents and oceans.  This exchange will have a tremendous influence on the inner work I teach and will have positive impact on youth and communities I work with in the Bay Area and beyond. 

Immediate and long term Impact of this work is to help communities:
<li>Develop
and refine non-violent communication skills that can be used to transform
conflict.
<li>Hone
critical thinking skills necessary to explore, appreciate, and articulate
the complexity of cultural and national identity.
• Develop leadership skills through experience, including the increased confidence to lead in formal and informal situations.
<li>Cultivate
internal capacity to manage responses to stressful external conditions and
simultaneously maintain centered composure.
<li>Restore community health and well-being, and reconnect communities with their own truth.
<li>Share
practices and knowledge with others, catching a world on fire with
evolutionary, sustainable, and peaceful change.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate to the campaign right now, please help me spread the word in reaching this goal: tweet, retweet, post, like, share, e-mail, send, talk... anything you can do to help will be so very much appreciated. 

Lastly, don't hesitate to reach out to me if you have any questions at all:

  • njiamovement@gmail.com

""True Victory is Victory Over Oneself"" – Morihei Ueshiba

for this venture.
The Impact

With your contribution to this journey, I will be able to extend this work and practice to the peoples of Ethiopia and Kenya - as well as create a cultural bridge that will connect many communities across continents and oceans.  This exchange will have a tremendous influence on the inner work I teach and will have positive impact on youth and communities I work with in the Bay Area and beyond.  Immediate and long term Impact of this work is to help communities:
Develop
and refine non-violent communication skills that can be used to transform
conflict.
Hone
critical thinking skills necessary to explore, appreciate, and articulate
the complexity of cultural and national identity.
Develop leadership skills through experience, including the increased confidence to lead in formal and informal situations.
Cultivate
internal capacity to manage responses to stressful external conditions and
simultaneously maintain centered composure.
Restore community health and well-being, and reconnect communities with their own truth.
Share
practices and knowledge with others, catching a world on fire with
evolutionary, sustainable, and peaceful change.

Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't donate to the campaign right now, please help me spread the word in reaching this goal: tweet, retweet, post, like, share, e-mail, send, talk... anything you can do to help will be so very much appreciated. Lastly, don't hesitate to reach out to me if you have any questions at all:njiamovement@gmail.com""True Victory is Victory Over Oneself"" – Morihei Ueshiba",7.0,0,"2 Campaigns
|","Oakland, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/movement-for-peace--2/pica

Short Summary

Girls Rock! RVA is a musically oriented, youth empowerment non-profit based in Richmond, VA. Our mission is to facilitate a space in Richmond that empowers girls, gender non-conforming, and trans youth to collaborate creatively in an environment of mutual respect and positive self-expression.  We operate a week-long, free summer camp that focuses on empowering young people through collaborative musical learning and expression through performance.  Our organization is entirely volunteer-run, and camp week can involve the efforts of over 40 volunteers.  As we enter our 5th camp season, we are trying to build a more sustainable volunteer base.

We would like to pay 25 camp volunteers a $200 stipend for their hard work during camp week.  We have asked a lot of our volunteers in the past - some committing to working as many as 50 hours during camp week, and many taking days off from jobs that don't provide paid vacation - for which they get a positive camp experience in return.  But we don't want our instrument instructors, band coaches, or camp counselors to have to make a choice between a positive experience and paying their electric bill.  We want to make it easier for these talented people to commit to volunteering with us year after year, and to start we have set a goal for 2015 of paying 25 volunteers a $200 stipend.

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

In order to pay $200 to 25 volunteers, we need at least $5,000 in contributions.  Girls Rock! RVA has focused on fundraising, camp coordination, and community partnerships to improve the camper experience, and now we want to focus on improving service to our volunteer staff.  We have been lucky to receive so much community support over the years, and we hope you will continue to support us in this initiative!

column1: If we make our goal of $5,000, we will pay $200 stipends to 25 volunteers, prioritizing those who work full camp-days, take time off of work to join us without paid personal or vacation days, or commute from other cities in order to participate.  Girls Rock! RVA already provides two meals per day to our volunteers, and we feel that a $200 stipend plus free food is a great start.  If we exceed our goal, we will first extend the offer of stipends to other volunteers who may be in need.  If no other volunteers apply for a stipend, we will increase the stipend amount for our original 25 volunteers.  If we do not meet our goal, we will reduce the number of stipends offered, and give funds to the volunteers most in need of a stipend.

We have some exciting perks for you if you choose to donate!  If you donate $25 or more, we will give you a digital download code for a recording of last year's rock camp dress rehearsal, featuring all-original songs by Girls Rock! RVA campers.  If you donate $75 or more, we will send you an assortment of zines made by campers and camp staff over the past few years.  If you donate $200 or more, we will have the volunteer(s) you sponsored write you a letter detailing their work during camp, giving you an inside look at the work our volunteers do to instruct and empower young people at rock camp.  If you donate $500 or more, we will send you letters from the staff you sponsored, as well as have you over for a nice home-cooked meal with the Girls Rock! RVA organizers!

The Impact

Girls Rock! RVA provides an opportunity for girls, gender non-conforming, and trans youth to create and express themselves in a safe, non-judgemental and non-critical space surrounded by working artists and musicians.  The experience of our volunteers as working artists, the musical instruction, and the unfettered creative process available to young people at camp are totally unique aspects of Girls Rock! RVA.  Our staff are not just instructors, but creative role models to our campers.  In addition, our camp is free to attend, because access is one of our top priorities.  There simply are no other summer camps like ours in Richmond.  Campers receive a crash course in an instrument, and through group work and encouragement from instructors, gain the confidence to write and perform an original song with a band in five days.  We also provide workshops on body image, healthy relationships, gender stereotypes, song and lyric writing, zine making, screen printing, and the history of women in popular music, among others.

By contributing to Girls Rock! RVA for this fundraising initiative, you will help ensure that local artists and musicians can confidently choose to volunteer with us in 2015 and beyond.  We want to make the choice between camp and day job easier for a working musician.  We want our talented volunteers to continue to choose Girls Rock! RVA year after year.

In the past, we have handled funds raised from benefit shows, parental and other individual donations, and a grant from Richmond CultureWorks with the utmost responsibility.  The funds we raise from shows, individuals, and grants are used to run our Free Richmond Instrument Lending Library, repair equipment, replace components such as cables or guitar picks, purchase art supplies and camper tote bags, print zines of camper artwork, and to purchase ingredients for healthy meals for our volunteers and healthy snacks for our campers during camp week.  We successfully incorporated as an LLC in Virginia and received 501(c)3 non-profit status last fall.  We have been building trust and cultivating relationships within the Richmond community for five years, and can be trusted to be accountable with your donations.
Risks &
column2:
Challenges

 In the event we do not reach our goal, Girls Rock! RVA will award as many stipends as possible with the donated funds to the volunteers most in need of financial assistance.  We will determine need during the volunteer application process and through interviews thereafter if our funds raised from this initiative do not meet our $5,000 goal.

column1: In the event we exceed $5,000, we will either award additional stipends, or increase the amount of the stipend by no more than $50 to volunteers with the most need.  If we greatly exceed our goal, we will roll over funds to provide stipends to next year's volunteer staff.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, but are interested in getting involved with Girls Rock! RVA to help in another way, we would love to hear from you.  We always need help planning and staffing camp and events.  If you want to help out, please write us at info@girlsrockrva.org.

Var med och stötta vår crowdfunding-kampanj!

Över hela världen är kvinnors frihet begränsad – från Boliva till Papua Nya Guinea, Kenya till Libanon, Sverige till Bangladesh. Utbildning, sexuellt våld, krig och klimatförändringar är några områden där kvinnor drabbas hårt.
Under flera år har vi, fotografen Martina Holmberg och journalisten Maria Hagström, rest till olika delar av världen för att skildra kvinnors villkor.  Alla har sin unika historia.

Nu är vi äntligen klara att sammanfatta det omfattande och viktiga projektet. Med foton och berättelser från olika länder visar vi, i en utställning- och bokform, hur det kan vara att leva ”In a WoMAN's world”. En värld där det också finns hopp om förändring.
Vad vi behöver och vad ni får:

I oktober 2021 är vandringsutställningen planerad att ha sin start - i Stockholm. Finansiering av material och tryck saknas ännu. Vi vill med denna kampanj kunna möjliggöra finansieringen och vi hoppas på er hjälp!
Vernissagen ska hållas samtidigt som boken In a WoMAN's world ges ut av Verbal Förlag. Det är en påkostad bok av hög kvalitet, rikt illustrerad med foton och djupgående reportagetexter. När du deltar i crowdfunding-kampanjen, genom att köpa böcker eller sponsra på annat sätt, får du självklart en inbjudan till vernissagen också.
Varje bidrag är värdefullt och gör så att vi kan nå ut till fler. Hjälp oss att sprida kvinnors viktiga röster från olika delar av världen!
Här följer några exempel på platser som finns med i projektet:

PAPUA NYA GUINEA. Det är gryning i Port Moresby. Utanför bussens fönster trängs morgontrafiken och på marknaden har försäljarna precis brett ut sina filtar täckta med betelnötter. Platserna i bussen fylls under färden in mot huvudstadens centrum. Kvinnor på väg till jobbet, skolflickor i ljusblå uniformer och damer som ska handla på marknaden.
Här ombord möts kvinnor från olika kulturer, stammar, samhällsklasser, och som pratar olika språk, men på bussen upplever de en säker zon tillsammans - fri från män.

I huvudstadens offentliga bussar blir kvinnor ofta utsatta för sexuella trakasserier. Det är svårt att åka fritt i staden. Därför trafikerar nu ett antal kvinnobussar, som kallas Meri Seif, Port Moresbys gator. Dagligen reser hundratals kvinnor och barn med bussarna.

DEMOKRATISKA REPUBLIKEN KONGO. I Demokratiska republiken Kongo sker över 1 000 våldtäkter varje dag. På Panzisjukhuset och transitboende Maison Dorcas i Bukavu får utsatta kvinnor och barn en chans att läka fysiskt och själsligt. När Justine kom till centret var hon så rädd för andra människor att hon ofta svimmade och gömde sig under sängen.

Hon hade våldtagits av flera män när hon gick till skogen för att samla ved. Under lång tid var hon djupt deprimerad och vågade inte närma sig andra människor. I dag deltar hon i flera olika aktiviteter och i framtiden vill hon starta sin egen syateljé.

En grön oas omringas av de olika huslängorna som utgör Masion Dorcas. I en av salarna hörs glada röster och en sliten bandspelare spelar hög musik. Dansterapeuten Amie Alices vägleder eleverna i rörelserna. Svettdroppar yr genom den kvava luften. I slutet av lektionen fylls salen med mammor och barn som spontandansar tillsammans.
KENYA. För tio år sedan var ""Skolan under trädet"" allt som fanns. I skuggan intill den tjocka trädstammen lärde Mama Ledo byns barn allt hon kunde. Hon ville ge dem en annan framtid.
– Om jag inte hade gått i skolan hade jag varit gift nu. I vår kultur gifter man bort flickor tidigt, ibland är de inte äldre än nio år, berättar 14-åriga Dorah Apetet Emase.

DEMOKRATISKA REPUBLIKEN KONGO. Byn Mimia är omgiven av tät regnskog. Här lever människor så gott som helt isolerade från omvärden. Att resa på floden till närmaste stad skulle ta flera dagar. Det är på dessa stigar som många av omgivningens kvinnor färdas i timmar - ibland dagar - för att komma till en läkare.

– Hade jag inte tagit mig hit till Mimia hade varken jag eller mina barn levt idag, berättar Joceline Ngongona, en av de unga nyförlösta kvinnorna som skjutsades med värkar till Mimia på pakethållaren på en cykel.

BANGLADESH. Det som kan tyckas vara en självklarhet i många länder - att äga en cykel eller att som kvinna ha rätt att cykla - är långt ifrån verkligheten för många i Bangladesh. 2007 startades ett cykelprojekt för flickor. Målet är att kvinnor ska vara likvärdiga män, socialt och ekonomiskt, med samma frihet och möjlighet att röra sig överallt utan ledsagare.
*Utställningen och boken är på svenska.

Members of Workers' Dignity and local supporters are going to Washington, D.C. to be part of a massive rally for comprehensive immigration reform — one that is just, fair, and covers all workers. This action is part of a nationwide movement that has escalated in the past few months to say ""enough is enough"" to the separation of families and the exploitation of workers due to their immigration status.

Who we are:
Workers’ Dignity is a
low-wage worker-led center organizing for economic justice. With workers leading the way, we've won the unpaid wages of hundreds of workers in Nashville affected by wage theft.
Where we are going:
Members of Workers' Dignity and local supporters will travel to Washington, D.C. to participate in a massive rally for
comprehensive immigration reform — a reform that should end the separation of families and the exploitation of workers due to their immigration status.
Who is going:
Workers’ Dignity members and allies will be
attending the rally in DC. The
caravan also will stop in Knoxville to meet with Jobs with Justice and other
supporters who will join us.
Why we are going:
Workers' Dignity has always been pro-immigration reform. Recently, Workers' Dignity members have been
sharing their testimonies of immigration and speaking out about the injustices
in the current systems.  In the words of Workers' Dignity member Daniel Lopez (pictured above): “there are many in my situation — we have to start talking about
this publicly in order for things to change.”
What we need:

We need to rent a van to take us to D.C. We can cover this if (for example):
15 people donated $25 and 10 people donated $10.

Workers’ Dignity members and allies are donating their own personal resources for the

cost of gas and housing.  Workers' Dignity is an organization with very limited resources — we need your support to make this happen!

After my third trip working with orphaned youth to Nicaragua, I realized the critical need for empowerment in the lives of young women, specifically those trapped in sexual slavery and trafficking. Nineteen years old at the time, I had just met another 19 year old Nicaraguan girl who had been trafficked, raped, and abandoned to an orphanage with her newborn baby. Intrinsically concerned, I tried to come up with a way to make an impact in the lives of similar young women who so desperately need help. And the answer came in the form of a bra.  

See our interview on TV

Today, millions of women and girls are trafficked for sex. You can be a part of the change
column2:
be one of the people who stand up against this injustice. It's as easy as buying a bra. Money used to purchase each bra from Supported Girls will be used to provide jobs for women and girls rescued out of sex trafficking, preventing retrafficking and promoting self-sustainability. You can support the girls with your bra.

We need YOU to help us get this started. Your contribution will help us buy sewing machines, train women on the machines, jumpstart the business, and put money towards a building space where we can operate. Help make this a reality
column3:
it's as easy as clicking ""Contribute Now.""


Visit our website: supportedgirls.com

And like us on facebook: https://www.facebook.com/supportedgirls

If you're on twitter: https://twitter.com/supportedgirls

(Founder Lauren Delk with Fox 59 anchor Angela Ganote showing off SG Bras)

","After my third trip working with orphaned youth to Nicaragua, I realized the critical need for empowerment in the lives of young women, specifically those trapped in sexual slavery and trafficking. Nineteen years old at the time, I had just met another 19 year old Nicaraguan girl who had been trafficked, raped, and abandoned to an orphanage with her newborn baby. Intrinsically concerned, I tried to come up with a way to make an impact in the lives of similar young women who so desperately need help. And the answer came in the form of a bra.  See our interview on TVToday, millions of women and girls are trafficked for sex. You can be a part of the change

ADDENDUM:  Zdravko is now saftely here in Vancouver.  He is gearing up to be one of the 3 grand marshals of Vancouver Pride.  Exciting times!

We are now hoping to exceed the $500 goas for information for his booth and there is not much time for that happen.  Please consider a small donation now.  You will be helping an organization that is working for GLBT rights in a country where the majority - so far - are less than supportive.

As gay men who are fortunate enough to live in a country that values the rights of the GLBT community my partner and I were thrilled to meet Zdravko last year while visiting Montenegro. He is an amazing young man who has been bold enough to come out in a country that is far from supportive of its gay community.  In fact Zdravko made the bold decision to come out, after being attacked because of his sexual orientation, so that others would ultimately feel safe to be who they are in a country that is presently less than supportive. He has since gone on to create the first Gay Rights organization in Montenegro that is doing great work to create improvements in the situation for the GLBT community.
Despite his work he continues to be greeted each day by taunts and threats by the general population of his country. And yet he continues to tirelessly fight for what he feels is right.
<h3><strong style=""font-size: 10px

I am thrilled to say that I nominated Zdravko to be one of the 3 Grand Marshals at the Gay Pride Parade in Vancouver and he was unanimously voted in.  This is a huge honour and well deserved in his case.

Zdravko is not only excited to be a Grand Marshal but he is excited about the opportunity to help others become aware of the issues that the community have in Montenegro and throughout the Balkans. He will have a booth in the community area of the parade where he will talk to people about the situation in Montenegro as well as the progressive and powerful work that he is doing.
Where do the funds go?

The funds that you contribute will pay for a large, professionally developed, banner that will appear above the booth on Gay Pride day as well as offset the costs of print materials that Zdravko would like to have available for interested parties. Any remaining money will go directly to Zdravko to support the work of his organization.
What this will mean for the GLBT community in Montenegro.

The fact that Zdravko will be a Grand Marshal in one of the largest Gay Pride Parades in the world is already hugely significant for him and his organization. Bringing awareness to human rights issues in a country such as Montenegro not only supports those who have been repressed but also challenges the country to move forward.

I am so grateful for what I have in terms of rights in Canada and I'm sure that you are too.  Helping Zdravko and his organization is a way to show that we support GLBT rights throughout the world.

REMEMBER: TO GET ONE OF OUR PRODUCTS AS A REWARD, CLICK IN THE DONATION CATEGORY ON THE RIGHT SIDE – DONATIONS COMING FROM THE BUTTON  “BACK IT” ARE WITHOUT THE GIFTS INCLUDED.

*To know more about each reward, click on it on the right side to read the details. 

(PARA PORTUGUÊS VERIFICAR LINK BENFEITORIA)

(FÜR DIE DEUTSCHE VERSION SIEHE WEITER UNTEN)

Hello everyone, here we go again, counting on your support for this amazing new endeavor!

The dream of having a physical space in India hasn’t come through yet, because we had to prioritize paying women’s wages. When I went to India before, I used to rent a small house where we could work together, but between paying a rent or providing them with more work, I always chose the second option. But to put ourselves in a next level and unlock bigger opportunities, is time for us to have a permanent space.

In the past 2 years, we have managed to grow, we have learned so much, changed so many lives, but having this center for empowerment and development of individuals, will give us the opportunity to master what we already do and expand. It will give the women an opportunity to develop their own dreams in a safe space, rebuilding their confidence and a change of a bright future. There, they will also be able to sell our products directly to tourists and to welcome volunteers and visitors from all over the world to exchange skills with them. With our center, it will be possible to provide shelter for the most vulnerable ones in cases of abuse or divorce, being the first shelter to offer all this in Anjuna, Goa, where we are located.

By reaching our goal, I will be going to India one month after the campaign ends, documenting all the process of getting our space ready, as well as the feedback from our artisans on how do they feel with the progress, sharing their life-changing experiences and what their expectations for the future are.

I hope you join us making this vision becoming a reality because everyone involved, from wherever in the world you might be, will be responsible for every and each little detail we will accomplish from now on.

 

Love and light always,

 

Carla.

Money breakdown:

The money we fundraise will be used to rent our space in Goa for at least one year, cover the expenses with the furniture, machines, and tools we need to set up our space, investment in new techniques (handloom training, tools for natural dying, organic fabrics).

We need at least 10,000 USD to make this project come to life.

We will be doing this campaign on 2 different platforms, Indiegogo (worldwide) and Benfeitoria (Brazil) to raise the whole amount.

Follow below the estimated costs we will have during the campaign:

 

Pledges:

For the assorted pledges, the pictures are just one example, you will not be able to choose exactly which color or design of that product you are getting it.

For the exclusively developed products, after you choose your reward, we will get in touch with you over email to start the exclusive product development.

For the “Giving Back Pledges” covering the school fees of our kids, the average school expenses yearly per kid is around 200 USD. The difference donated in these categories will be invested in the realization of our center.

ASSORTED REWARDS - your item will be randomly selected from our collection, colors and style may vary.

 

Assorted bracelets and keychains - sizes, colors, and handwork will vary - Pledge comes with one OR another: 

 

Assorted necklaces - design and colors will vary:

 

Assorted make-up bags - sizes, colors, and handwork will vary:

Assorted pillows - sizes, colors, and handwork will vary: 

Assorted scarves - sizes, colors, and handwork will vary: 

 

Chetan elephant pillow:

 

Illustration by Carolina Buzio - unframed - SOLD OUT

T-shirt by Carolina Buzio:

T-shirt by Paola Saliby:

Silver Earring + Recycled Soapstone: 

Recycled Soapstone Necklace:

Production + shipment timeline:

Some of the products we are offering in the campaign are ready to go! We will do our best to start sending the pieces as soon as possible, but as the campaign time is always very hectic, check the shipping schedule for more details. We can’t assure you will receive your items before that.  

 

DEUTSCHE VERSION

ACHTUNG!!! UM DIE ENTSPRECHENDE SPENDEN-BELOHNUNG ZU ERHALTEN BITTE IM RECHTEN FENSTER UNTER “DONATION CATEGORY” KLICKEN. SPENDEN VON “DONATE NOW” SIND OHNE GESCHENK!  

Liebe Leute,

Project Três geht in die nächste Runde und ich hoffe ihr unterstützt uns mit unseren neuen Vorhaben.

Der Traum ein eigenes kleines Zentrum in Indien zu haben ging bisher nicht in Erfüllung, da wir an erster Stelle die Gehälter unserer Frauen zahlten und sonstige anfallende Kosten, wie Arztrechnungen etc. Bisher mietete ich (Carla) ein kleines Haus in Indien, in dem wir zusammen arbeiten konnten, denn ich wollte als erstes sicherstellen, dass ich die Gehälter bezahlen konnte.

Aber jetzt wollen wir den nächsten Schritt wagen - ein eigenes kleines Zentrum für “Women Empowerment”.

In den letzten 2 Jahren ist Project Três deutlich gewachsen, wir haben viel gelernt und das Leben unserer Frauen verbessert. Es ist jetzt die Zeit gekommen unabhängiger und mehr organisiert zu werden mit unserem Zentrum. Ein eigene Begegnungsstätte für “Women Empowerment” bietet unseren Frauen einen sicheren Arbeitsplatz, der Platz bietet für persönliche Entwicklung und an dem sie sich vollkommen auf die Arbeit konzentrieren können. Außerdem können wir so direkt vor Ort unsere Produkte verkaufen und Freiwillige sowie Besucher willkommen heißen. Wir sehen unser Zentrum auch als ein Ort des Austausches, wo Leute aus aller Welt ihr Wissen / Handwerkliches Geschick mit uns teilen können. Unser Haus in Anjuna, Goa wäre so eine einzigartige Begegnungsstätte für die Region, wo es bisher noch keine Möglichkeiten gibt für hilfesuchende Frauen z.B. während einer Scheidung oder häuslicher Gewalt zu entkommen.

Einem Monat nach dem Ende der Crowdfunding Kampagne werde ich wieder in Indien sein und unsere Fortschritte mit unserem Zentrum dokumentieren sowie unsere Frauen interviewen, wo sie über ihre einschneidenden Erlebnisse, Fortschritte und Erwartungen an Project Três berichten werden.

Ich hoffe ihr helft mit unsere Vision Wirklichkeit werden zu lassen, denn jeder der jetzt mitmacht, von allen Teilen der Welt, wird verantwortlich sein für den kleinsten Fortschritt, den wir in der Zukunft erreichen werden.

Eure, Carla.

 

Wofü r brauchen wir das Geld?
Von dem gesammelten Geld des Fundraise wollen wir die Miete unseres Zentrums in Goa für mindestens ein Jahr bezahlen können. Weiterhin wollen wir unser Haus mit den Basics an Möbeln ausstatten und benötigen neue Maschinen und Werkzeuge für unsere Arbeit.  Zu guter Letzt wollen wir noch mehr nachhaltigere und hochwertige Produkte in Zukunft herstellen und planen Investitionen in neue Techniken (Handwebstuhl-Training, Materialien für natürliche Textilfärbungen, biologische Textilien etc.)

Um unseren Plan Wirklichkeit werden zu lassen brauchen wir mindestens 10,000 USD.

Unsere detaillierte Kostenanalyse:
column3:
'>Miete mit nebenkosten + monatl. Essensausgaben = 380 USD/Monat x 12 Monate = 4,600 USD

Gesundheitsvorsorge / Notfälle + Investitionen in neue Handfertigkeiten &
column4:
Training = 1,500 USD

Nähmaschinen - 3 normale Singer + 2 Overlock Singer mit 6-Fadenmaschine = 1,300 USD

Investitionen in neue Materialien und Werkzeuge = 1,200 USD

Steuern für die Kampagne = 8% des gesamten Betrags

Ausgaben für die Kampagne = 700,00 USD

Steuerabgaben für das Zentrum in Indien  - 600,00 USD

Möbel + Bauarbeiten am Zentrum = 500,00 USD

 

Produktion + Versand Zeitplan

Viele unserer für die Kampagne bereitgestellten Produkte sind fertig für den Versand!

Wir werden versuchen die Spenden-Geschenke so schnell es geht zu versenden, aber da wir während der Kampagne oft gestresst sind, kann es zu Verzögerungen kommen (siehe auch unseren Versand-Zeitplan für mehr Details). Wir können leider nicht sicherstellen, dass dich das Produkt genau bis zu diesem Zeitpunkt erreicht.

Für die exklusiv entwickelten Produkte werden wir mit dir per Email in Kontakt treten um Details zu besprechen. Mit den “Giving Back Pledges” wollen wir unter anderem auch die Schulkosten unserer Kinder im Projekt abdecken (ca. 200 USD pro Kind pro Jahr). Alle weiteren Erträge von den “Giving Back Pledges” werden für die Finanzierung unseres Zentrums genutzt.

The BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color) portion of the Racial
Justice Collective is planning a weekend long retreat for their members in
an effort to concentrate their energy on nurturing our resilience and
building a solid foundation with one another to move forward in doing
radical racial justice work on the Olympic Peninsula. This weekend will be
filled with conversations about our visions for our lives and racial justice,
the political climate of the U.S., the increasingly tumultuous ways these
forces are playing out as well as planned exercises and actions that will
center around the needs of our group now and in the future. The BIPOC
portion of the RJC is a minority group in the larger sense of our
geographical region and as a label of pride. It is a role and narrative we
have lived our whole lives, and we are asking now for your help in
materially supporting the retreat in an effort to continue the work we have
started.

All funds raised will go toward transportation, lodging and study materials throughout the weekend. Our hope is to provide this opportunity to BIPOC members in our community every year. Please help us with our first annual retreat.

Welcome to the Warriors for Women Campaign! Warriors for Women is a group of students at the University of Tennessee partnering with the Young Women’s Christian Association (YWCA) of Knoxville &
column2: the Tennessee Valley. Our goal is to raise money for the YWCA to assist them in fulfilling their mission statement: eliminating racism, empowering women and promoting peace, justice, freedom and dignity for all. We ask that you use this page as a resource to learn more about the YWCA and donate to their cause to make a difference in the lives of women and children in our community.

column1: Our Mission

The main focus of our campaign is to raise money for Keys of Hope, a program facilitated by YWCA that provides transitional housing to women. Women come to the YWCA for a variety of reasons and needs. Some are victims of domestic violence, one of the most common crimes committed in the United States. According to studies, at least 1 in every 3 women will become victims of a form of domestic violence. Since 1899, the YWCA Knoxville has been serving women and their families in the community. The YWCA provides support and assistance to women that are survivors of domestic violence in addition to housing needs, allowing them to escape dangerous or abusive situations. While women are living in the facilities provided by YWCA, they are also provided with career counseling and a support system to help them get back on their feet and find an independent and safe living environment. This program has changed the lives of hundreds of women by allowing them to regain control over their lives and get a fresh start.
How can you help?

As a non-profit, the YWCA relies on the donations and volunteer work of others to continue assisting women in the Knoxville community. That’s where you come in! The YWCA needs your help to continue empowering the women of Knoxville &
column2: the Tennessee Valley through their programs. By donating to our campaign, you will be helping to change the lives of women in our community. Anything you are able to give will go directly towards the YWCA and the Keys of Hope Women's Housing program to help with renovation, furnishing, and simply providing for the residents of the transitional housing programs. If you are unable to donate monetarily, you can still show your support by volunteering at any of the YWCA’s numerous locations or by working to raise awareness about domestic violence. The YWCA also welcomes any donations of food, clothing, and gently used household items. If you do decide to donate, you may be eligible to receive “perks” as a thank you. For donating $5, you will receive a handwritten thank you note from our team members. For donating $10, you will receive a Warriors for Women sticker. We value any and all donations that we receive, and want to express our gratitude to you!

column1: Below are some of the programs you will be supporting by donating to the YWCA through the Warriors for Women Campaign.
<ul>
• Keys of Hope (transitional housing program for women)
• Victim Advocacy Program (program offering support and assistance to victims of domestic violence)
• Club W (fitness center for residents and community members)
Thank you for taking the time to explore our page, and we hope that you decide to donate to our cause!

","Welcome to the Warriors for Women Campaign! Warriors for Women is a group of students at the University of Tennessee partnering with the Young Women’s Christian Association (YWCA) of Knoxville & the Tennessee Valley. Our goal is to raise money for the YWCA to assist them in fulfilling their mission statement: eliminating racism, empowering women and promoting peace, justice, freedom and dignity for all. We ask that you use this page as a resource to learn more about the YWCA and donate to their cause to make a difference in the lives of women and children in our community.
Our Mission

The main focus of our campaign is to raise money for Keys of Hope, a program facilitated by YWCA that provides transitional housing to women. Women come to the YWCA for a variety of reasons and needs. Some are victims of domestic violence, one of the most common crimes committed in the United States. According to studies, at least 1 in every 3 women will become victims of a form of domestic violence. Since 1899, the YWCA Knoxville has been serving women and their families in the community. The YWCA provides support and assistance to women that are survivors of domestic violence in addition to housing needs, allowing them to escape dangerous or abusive situations. While women are living in the facilities provided by YWCA, they are also provided with career counseling and a support system to help them get back on their feet and find an independent and safe living environment. This program has changed the lives of hundreds of women by allowing them to regain control over their lives and get a fresh start.
How can you help?

As a non-profit, the YWCA relies on the donations and volunteer work of others to continue assisting women in the Knoxville community. That’s where you come in! The YWCA needs your help to continue empowering the women of Knoxville & the Tennessee Valley through their programs. By donating to our campaign, you will be helping to change the lives of women in our community. Anything you are able to give will go directly towards the YWCA and the Keys of Hope Women's Housing program to help with renovation, furnishing, and simply providing for the residents of the transitional housing programs. If you are unable to donate monetarily, you can still show your support by volunteering at any of the YWCA’s numerous locations or by working to raise awareness about domestic violence. The YWCA also welcomes any donations of food, clothing, and gently used household items. If you do decide to donate, you may be eligible to receive “perks” as a thank you. For donating $5, you will receive a handwritten thank you note from our team members. For donating $10, you will receive a Warriors for Women sticker. We value any and all donations that we receive, and want to express our gratitude to you!
Below are some of the programs you will be supporting by donating to the YWCA through the Warriors for Women Campaign.
Keys of Hope (transitional housing program for women)
Victim Advocacy Program (program offering support and assistance to victims of domestic violence)
Club W (fitness center for residents and community members)
Thank you for taking the time to explore our page, and we hope that you decide to donate to our cause!",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns

If not a human issue, toilets certainly are a women’s issue.

column1: of my daughter, I moved back to India to provide clean toilets so that no
daughter, no mother or sister ever has to lose her dignity just in relieve
herself.
Join me in protecting dignity of 1
daughter at a time.
You only have few days to become part

of our journey and to create enormous impact in the lives of 5000 Girls.It is an undeniable fact that the absence of safe toilet adds to the vulnerability of women. A man can unzip anywhere without fear and shame. It is the women, who lack access to private toilets and have to wake up before sunrise or wait for the sky to get dark and walk miles to find the right and safe place to defecate. If not a human issue, toilets certainly are a women’s issue.  SCENARIO
Imagine being a
mother of a bubbly 12 year old girl in a house, the size of 2 dining tables, in

an urban slum.You don't have a toilet not just because of a financial crunch, but also because of a space crunch. In dense Urban slums, in-home toilet is rarely an option. So Community toilets are an appropriate sanitation solution. But many urban slums do not have community toilets and even if community toilets are present, they are FILTHY and unused as not properly maintained.
CONSEQUENCES

At dinner you eat little and drink less to reduce the pressure of the basic call of nature, because you know that  it might be too difficult to find a clean toilet and too dangerous to find a safe place amidst the evil  forces of night
column2: when men shine torch on women defecating, or hide behind the adjacent bush to peep and pelt stones to tease. Moreover, you also ask your daughter not to take more than a few sips of water else she would have to step out of the house at night, And you know it's not going to be safe. You get up early in the morning, walk a mile (or two or three) to find a spot away from the normal gaze and finally relieve. And this continues. Day-after-day-after-day until eternity. Holding your pee and poo leads to severe health complications like UTIs (Urinary Tract Infections).

Iris Andhra Pradesh, an Iris Nashville mission base that is an anti-profit organization that rescues child slaves and feeds hungry people.
The organization began in 2009. It was founded by Lyle Phillips, an Iris Ministries missionary.
After just three years in India, Iris AP has grown to more than 1600
children, with 400 of those children being rescued directly from human
trafficking, prostitution, and forced labor.
Our founder, Lyle, with our children rescued from human trafficking.
This Christmas..
Our Director of Operations, Emily Yeatman,
will be leading a team to Andhra Pradesh, India. While there, she and
the team will visit our eight homes for rescued children, and personally
give each child an amazing Christmas present!
TO MAKE THIS POSSIBLE....
We need $15,000 that will provide one $10 gift for each one of our children this
Christmas. By partnering with us, you will receive an array of rewards
for your contribution, as well as a HUGE BLESSINGS from our children in
India.
One of our beautiful girls.
Jesus teaches us..
""Truly I tell you, whatever you did for one of the least of these brothers and sisters of mine, you did for me.""
Our Christmas Trip Team Leader, Emily Yeatman.
<h3>Let's celebrate Jesus together, by adopting a rescued child into
your family this Christmas. It only takes $10 to change one life
forever!
Help us get the word out!
Share this project with others using the Indiegogo share tools!
*Photos by Logan Z. Hunt and Emily Yeatman

Champions Against Human Trafficking is a Latin Style dance showcase used as a platform to bring the awareness of Human Trafficking in prominate cities across the United States.   The night consist of a networking reception where two awards will be given to women who are making major impact to combat Human Trafficking in St. Louis. Networkers will be able to meet a survivor and end the night watching ...a stellar Las Vegas Style Latin Dance Showcase by ESPN World Salsa Champions. Proceeds will go to support three area safe homes in St. Louis. But the vision does not stop there. In 2015 we will begin a nation wide Latin Dance Champion tour in all major cities with the highest Human Trafficking crime rates, and connect with the homes that are making a difference in these girls lives. The cities listed are Atlanta, New York, Chicago, Los Angels, Houston, and Miami. My goal is to be a voice for those who are unheard in a powerful way. These girls are precious and valued. I want to be able to support the homes that are showing these ladies just that.
<strong>
What we are up Against…..

Born In America, Hidden in Plain View – Child trafficking is defined as the transport of persons, by means of coercion, deception or consent for the purpose of exploitation such as forced or consensual labor or prostitution. Human trafficking generates $9.5 billion yearly in the United States. And an estimated 300,000 American children at risk of being exploited and trafficked for sex and labor in America. Between January 2008 and June 2010, Forty percent of all human trafficking cases were for the sexual trafficking of children.
<table>
<tbody><tr></tr></tbody>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>
o  Child Trafficking is the 2nd fastest growing crime on the planet
o  Human Trafficking generate $9.5 Billion a year
o  2 plus children are forced into slavery every minute
o  Average age for sex trafficking 13  years old
o  Average Price $90 / victim (endless profit margin
</tr>
</tbody>

Department Of Justice has identified the top twenty human trafficking jurisdictions in the country: Houston • El Paso • Los Angeles • Atlanta • Chicago • Charlotte • Miami • Las Vegas • New York • Long Island • New Orleans • Washington, D.C. • Philadelphia • Phoenix • Richmond • San Diego • San Francisco • St. Louis • Seattle •
Perks

We are really excited about our perks! We know you donate to support the girls restoration from Human Trafficking and the education about the crime. So part of our perks we would like to recognize you or your organization on various levels on the work that you are doing and support you through our media base.
What’s the Impact?  Why Donate

Proceeds from the trafficking event will go towards supporting area safe homes in perspective cities the event is held.  There isn’t a single young girl or boy who is victimized from this crime that doesn’t have a compelling story that wont touch your spirit.  So many dream of an opportunity to heal and to feel safe and loved by someone who truly cares for them.
Secondly it give our organization to continue to use Afro- Caribbean music and dance as a platform to spread the awareness about human trafficking to the dance and entertainment community and beyond.
Other Ways You Can Help
Any financial contribution is appreciated
column2: even $5 helps us to reach our goal!

column1: However, if you cannot contribute financially there are many other ways you can help. Please:
• Use the Indiegogo Share icons above to share our campaign on Facebook and Twitter.
• Write about our campaign on your blog, website, or publication. We are happy to provide promotional material, and will in turn share your link on our social media channels.
·  Help us connect with safe homes in those cites mentioned or organization that are making a difference. We already have a connection for Atlanta
·  Donate to the campaign so that we are able to raise funds to raise awareness and support the safe homes.

I want to thank you all so much for allowing me to share my story and my vision with you. Just that alone is a blessing. One of the flyers for the St. Louis event is below. I will keep you all posted.

Homeless Veterans Care Bags

Join me in a gesture of instant care for homeless veterans in the Everett area with a care bag. This bag holds snacks, the basics to keep warm, toiletry essentials, a haircut, hot coffee, a Christmas card and connections to local resources.

Our goal of $1,600 will reach over 50 homeless veterans with a care bag.

Why are we choosing this cause?

We saw a homeless man outside of
Costco. Cole was taken with his plight and wanted to help. He talks

about helping all the time. When the weather is bad, he wants to make sure they are warm. When we see a homeless person, he wants to make sure they are ok. Cole is 4. We are taken with his interest in helping others and proud of his daily pursuit to remind us of those in need. So we started this campaign as the first of
many steps to join him in helping out the homeless men and women in our

area.

What We Need
A care bag includes:
• Protein bars, beef jerky, trail mix
• Gloves, hat, socks, heat bags
• Toiletries: deodorant, soap, toothbrush/ toothpaste, wet wipes, kleenex
• First aid kit
• Gift certificate for haircut
• Gift certificate for coffee
• A Christmas card with a message that we care. Personal messages welcome.
• Contact information for local homeless veteran resources, holiday connections and resources for job assistance.

The Impact

1 in 4 homeless are Veterans. Why?

• Homeless veterans struggle to maintain civilian life after enduring difficult events in service. Some struggle to find work upon return, while others experience traumatic events that result in PTSD, mental illness, disabilities or substance abuse.

• Washington State alone shelters more than 2.7% of the homeless veteran population. The Everett area is stretched thin to provide resources and connecting with homeless veterans can be challenging. Care bags offer an instant connection with the message that we care.
• We've all seen the difference that can be made when veterans see that they are not forgotten: Homeless Veteran Timelapse
Can't Contribute?
Being noisy helps just as much.
• Share this campaign with friends, family and co-workers.
• Share this campaign with a former service member.

Care bags are coordinated with the Everett Veterans Assistance Program to assure our donations reach DD214 Veterans. 

You'll receive photos of the bag build and delivery!

(TO SKIP READING PREFACE START READ BOLD) 

I'm a big believer of independence, and self-inherited success so every time I've hit a rough patch along this road to ""success"", I found it increasingly difficult to ask for help. I often acted like all was good when really it wasnt. One year I stopped eating lunch just so I could get myself home after my dead beat job. Family and friends always offered help of course, but my pride got in the way.

Now that I understand that help is something that is necessary and not optional in times of despair, I want others to learn that too.

A few weeks ago I offered a homeless man a fresh bottle of water since I had no cash and he furiously refused it saying he was hungry.People started bashing him tryna make me feel better but I stood up for him. I bumped into him last night but thought he'd a) forgotten me or b) hated me.. Instead he pointed, smiled and said I remember youuu, and started chatting with me then I remembered the plate of fries I didn't eat and offered it to him and for each thank you he said another beat in my heart skipped. 

He isnt the first homeless person to accept my blessing, nor the first to tell me everything he wants to eat off the menu he only dreams about so on December 23, im planning on raiding Jetro and BJ's for supplies and making sandwiches/food, packing hygiene kits and getting stocking stuffers for my own Midnight Run. A midnight run is when a group of volunteers travel out to homeless sheters or just random spots where homeless people usually are (ie subway, churches, parks) and give out the things listed.

Ive done it a couple times with my church and it was the funnest and greatest experience of my life, and im pleading for you guys to join me on the 23rd at around 7-8PM to get things packed.

The only things i ask of you guys, is that if you are interested please bring your biggest duffel bag, any kind of supplies you think would help ( i can also assign what to bring if necessary), and if you can throw some $ (any amt) to help buy food and gloves/hats that would be great.

If you have my number contact me through phone and let me know what youre bringing if not, a fb message always works, or just post if youre coming and what youre bringing on this page :) THANK YOU, GOD BLESS, AND HAPPY HOLIDAYS

|","Manhattan, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/a-christmas-midnight-run/pica

""I have lost all my dignity. I do not feel like I am a human being. I
have lost my home, my job, my family and my country, which I always

loved.""

I use the name Milo – I am a gay man from Uganda and cannot use my real name because I fear for my life. Last year, President Museveni signed a Bill into law that could have placed me in prison for life. It was terrifying. Many of us were outed in the Ugandan press and we were targeted by family, friends, landlords, school principals, employers and community.

My life changed dramatically when my family found out I am gay and then one day my brothers beat me so badly I had to run for my life. I was sure they would find me and kill me. So I fled to Kenya where I am a refugee with UNHCR.

I have lost all my dignity. I do not feel like I am a human being. I have lost my home, my job, my family and my country, which I always loved.

It is not safe for gays and lesbians and trans people in the refugee camp as the other refugees call us Satan and want to beat us. So I had to find a place to stay. I was given a small amount of money each month by an organization to survive. I could pay small rent to live in a slum area and I could eat food once a day.

I did not have a bed to sleep on no blanket and no pot to cook in. I joined with other refugees and now we are four together sharing our small money, but we still cannot pay the rent this month because the organization that helped us before is no longer giving us any monthly money.

So we are told we have one day to pay or go to the street.

It will be a long time before my next appointment with UNHCR and I do not even know where they will send me or if I will be lucky enough to be resettled.

I am told that it could take even more than another year. If I go back to Uganda I am sure I will be killed. If I stay how will I survive this nightmare? I am not sure how I can hold this life in place. I may not have a place to sleep even from tomorrow. I am so urgently in need of your help.

Now my only hope is African Human Rights Coalition. If they can raise enough money they will provide us with money for rent and food. And we will have the security we need to survive each month until our fate is decided by UNHCR.

African Human Rights Coalition has over 50 refugees asking for help and with stories similar to my story.

With your help we can find safe places to stay and eat 2 meals a day.

So I am asking LGBT people and friends for help. We need to raise $1,050 per person to provide food, rent and utilities for the next 6 months while UNHCR continues to process our claims. The more AHRC raises, the more people can be helped. Please chip in now. Our situation is urgent and critical.

With my prayer for a better day and I thank you - Milo.

This campaign for direct humanitarian relief is not tax deductible - however from this campaign all the money goes to refugees except a percentage for Indiegogo and Paypal.

The money raised here will be shared equally amongst 4- 50 refugees in Kenya - depending on the amount raised.  The first $160 will go to immediately pay this months rent for Milo and his friends. The second $85 will pay for another 4 men who are also short on this months rent.

*******

You can also DONATE HERE to the organization AHRC which is tax deductible.

This Campaign is being managed by The African Human Rights Coalition, and Melanie Nathan.  To read more about our work please visit www.africanHRC.org 

READ MORE

Our Story

Hello! We are Mai and Naomi. Our vision for The Birth Talks Presents! began in Naomi's living room, one year ago. We both believe in the power of story telling and that women and girls are and can be community leaders, change-makers and healers.

We are both mothers with different lived experiences. This is what brought us together. Naomi's work with Branch Out Theatre came out of her love of acting, story telling and dedication to working with marginalized communities all over the world.

Mai's passion project, The Birth Talks Podcast, came out of her desire to tell stories of pregnancy, birth and parenting that often got left out of the mainstream. She began working on it with a laptop and recorder in her closet at home.

When we got together a year ago it was simply to record the first episode of The Birth Talks. We laughed and joked as both of our baby girls played on the ground and realized we had a shared desire to celebrate and showcase the stories/experiences of women and girls in our community. 

We will work with 10 women-identified-folk from across all walks of life so they can celebrate and share their experiences of pregnancy, birth and parenting, while building community, solidarity and support with one another. Our participants will go through a facilitated training with Naomi to learn how to write and perform their experiences. Mai will produce 5 episodes so their stories are shared via podcast.
More about The Birth Talks and Branch Out Theatre

The Birth Talks is a 2018 Femmy award winning podcast about pregnancy, birth and parenting with an intersectional feminist twist. The podcast gives listeners the lowdown on how gender, race, sex, sexuality, class and life experiences affect pregnancy, birth and parenting. The producer and host, Mai Ngo, is a birth advocate in Ottawa who is committed to powerful stories from the lived experiences of women across diverse communities.

Branch Out Theatre uses popular theatre to create transformative social change for individuals and communities. Trained in New York, its artistic director Naomi Tessler has been working with communities globally for 13 years, using theatre and storytelling to inspire community building, conflict transformation and positive change.
What We Need
We need $4,500 for our campaign which we plan to use for launching and implementing the program.
We will be using workshop and performance space that is accessible and close to transit.
We will be renting equipment for the program that includes a projector, videographer, sound equipment, lighting and microphones.
We would like to produce a short video that will allow us to showcase the program.
We would also like to provide light refreshments, transportation, childcare and beverages for the rehearsals and performance.
The money raised will also go to the overall design, facilitation, and promotion of the program so that we can reach as many people as possible.
Impact

When we bring the stories of women and girls from the page to the stage, we can continue to grow and empower people through arts/media. We can also continue to do what we do best - that is to teach others how beautiful and important their experiences and stories are to the vibrancy of our community. We want to create an environment that is nurturing and inclusive for women-identified-folk to be a part of. We hope that you can contribute and be part of our vision.
Other Ways You Can Help

We grew our work from word of mouth and social media. Share our video, our story or tell all your friends what we are doing at The Birth Talks Presents!. Use Instagram, Twitter, Facebook or whatever social media platform you use to get our story out and reach other networks. And come to the performance on JUNE 10, 2018 - 4PM LOCATION TBA!!

THANK YOU (all of you) for your support in our vision that women and girls across all walks of life matter. The stories of our experiences - the loss, the joy, the fears, the pain, the triumphs - is the stuff life's made of.

Thank you for checking out our campaign and we hope we make our goal with your help! 

xo

Mai Ngo and Naomi Tessler

Short Summary

Hi, my name is Joshua Faulkner, I'm the youth pastor at FBC of Hampton, GA, husband, father of 4, 12 year US Army veteran, and passionate follower of Christ. A few years ago, God began placing a huge burden on mine and my wife's hearts to rescue and restore victims of human trafficking. Our calling became more and more clear as we fasted and prayed through the process, and the people of Nicaragua became the focus of that passion. God has been organizing and unifying a team of adults called to build a restoration home in Nicaragua for victims of human trafficking. We have established and co-founded a non-profit organization called Relentless Pursuit Ministries International and we have a team that is here in the US raising awareness for human trafficking and raising funds for the launch of the ministry. We have partnered with other non-profit organizations and are currently completing rescues and joining efforts to change legislation within the local and federal government.

The reason that I have started this fundraiser is because as we begin this process of establishing a restoration home in Nicaragua, I will need to take several trips to Nicaragua prior to us moving there full-time. The estimated cost for 3 trips this year is $7500. As we raise this money, it will not only give me the opportunity to network and make essential connections with the local government in Nicaragua, but it will allow me time to seek God's clear voice and direction for our ministry and the future of Relentless Pursuit Ministries International. 

God has given us such a huge vision for this ministry, yet we need financial partners to help support the ministry as it gets off the ground. Please pray diligently over partnering with us and supporting us so that I can make the necessary trips to Nicaragua while we are in the planning stages of glorifying God through steps of faithful obedience.

I fully expect that God will honor the vision He has placed in our hearts and I pray that you will help us get to the point to where we can begin rescuing these precious creations of God out of the bondage that they are in and give them an incredible place where they can be restored and healed into the women and men that God intended for them to be.

If you can't help today, please visit our website at www.relentlessinternational.org and pray with us that God would find favor upon our ministry that we might reach the lost and hopeless of this world with the beauty and hope of Jesus.

column8: >The Veterans Relief Fund, Inc is a registered 501(c)3 charity.  It was founded by vets for vets.  We provide several services:

column1: <ul>
• We help vets obtain the benefits they qualify for from the Veterans Administration and other government agencies.
• When no benefits are available through the VA or government agencies we assist vets with grants and interest free loans.
• We provide comfort and hygiene items such as blankets and toilteries.
• We provide funding to help needy veterans travel to their medical appointments.
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column8: >The Veterans Relief Fund spends virtually all the monies it receives on direct benefits.  Only a small percentage is spent on overhead costs.  Much of the work done by the Veterans Relief Fund is done by volunteeers.

column2: >For many veterans the Veterans Relief Fund is their only hope.  These men and women risked their life to protect our freedoms.  Please make a difference in their lives.
>If you cannot donate, please help us by spreading the word about this campaign.

column1: ","The Veterans Relief Fund, Inc is a registered 501(c)3 charity.  It was founded by vets for vets.  We provide several services:
We help vets obtain the benefits they qualify for from the Veterans Administration and other government agencies.
When no benefits are available through the VA or government agencies we assist vets with grants and interest free loans.
We provide comfort and hygiene items such as blankets and toilteries.
We provide funding to help needy veterans travel to their medical appointments.

The Veterans Relief Fund spends virtually all the monies it receives on direct benefits.  Only a small percentage is spent on overhead costs.  Much of the work done by the Veterans Relief Fund is done by volunteeers.
For many veterans the Veterans Relief Fund is their only hope.  These men and women risked their life to protect our freedoms.  Please make a difference in their lives.
If you cannot donate, please help us by spreading the word about this campaign.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Coeur d'Alene, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/veterans-relief-fund--2/pica

Kent Refugee Action Network (KRAN) support refugees and asylum seekers with language lessons, a drop-in service, and life-skills classes for younger clients (including cooking, food hygiene, budgeting, healthy relationships and organisational skills). They also run a number of events to facilitate integration (including the recent Living Advent Calendar event on 23 December where young refugees worked with local primary school children to create art work and decorations, and cooked food for the 200 or so people who attended. Help us raise some much needed funds by sponsoring us to chuck ourselves in the English Channel on Boxing Day. Every pound is greatly appreciated!

MLK said ""There are millions of poor people in this country who have little or nothing to lose. If they can be helped to take action together, they will do so with a freedom and a power that will be a new and unsettling force in our complacent national life.""

Fifty years later this statement is still true, and in many ways, conditions are worse. The Pennsylvania Chapter of the Poor People's Campaign: A National Call for Moral Revival is an all-volunteer effort, but we do need resources to help many people take action together. We will be arranging buses, childcare, food, and sleeping arrangements for poor and dispossessed people from around the state to come together in Harrisburg this spring for the launch of this campaign. Over six weeks, we will bring a moral agenda to Harrisburg with creative actions that are led by and center directly impacted people.

Why is this campaign important? Because 1 in 2 people in the U.S. are poor or near poor. Because living in poverty is not a sin, poverty is a sin. Because being homeless should never be a crime - homelessness should be a crime. 

$15 will pay for one hour of childcare to enable parents to fully participate

$25 will pay for art supplies to create banners and posters so that everyone can see what we're doing!

$50 will pay for a tank of gas to support a van load of people to attend an action

$75 will pay for breakfast for 25 people 

$100 will pay for dinner for 25 people

$250 will pay for two full days of childcare

$500 will pay for American Sign Language interpretation for five actions

$1000 will pay for a busload of people to attend

Any amount will help and we appreciate your support!

The mission of The Ms. Wheelchair California Foundation is to recognize the achievement of women in wheelchairs. Each year the chosen Ms. Wheelchair California will strive to educate and advocate for Californians with disabilities. Ms. Wheelchair California is not a beauty pageant. It is a competition based on advocacy, achievement, communication and presentation. Its purpose is to select the most accomplished and articulate spokeswomen to represent people living with disabilities. The selected titleholder must be able to communicate both the needs and the accomplishments of her constituency to the general public, the business community and the legislature.

Your contribution will help us continue to grow as an organization, teach others with disabilities leadership skills and bring forth to society the achievements of the disability community.

We thank you, tremendously for your continued support!

Justice for Donald
Donald Perry is a 60 years-old loving family man. He is a compassionate
community servant, with a generous spirit. Donald has earned the
respect, admiration, and trust of countless community members who have
witnessed his tireless work on behalf of poor and homeless persons in
Hampshire County.
Donald was working full time as the coordinator for the
single room occupancy Outreach program and kitchen manager at the local
soup kitchen when he was pulled over and arrested in 2011. <b>The MA Parole
Board imprisoned him for 2 years and 8 months for a crime he did not
commit, and was acquitted of. (Read about The Case)
At present, Donald is on parole for life based on his imposed
sentence. Donald, Elaine, close family members, and friends well
understand after this recent incident, that Donald can be picked up and
returned to prison any moment regardless of what he does or doesn’t do. <i>Donald says
he’ll never be FREE until he’s off parole, period.
<h4><b>The idea and much effort now is Donald going back into court on a
RULE 30 motion to hopefully get his life sentence vacated.
<h3>What We Need &amp
This fundraiser is CRITICAL because:
1. Donald faces legal expenses– A $5,000
retainer, court fees, securing expert witnesses, travel costs,
obtaining record's, processing evidence, etc. Donald’s supporters can mobilize
to raise funds that will ensure that he has resources for the trial, increasing
his chances of securing freedom.
2. Our
continued organizing will make sure that justice will be served in Donald’s
case and that our commitment to his true freedom remains active. It also
creates opportunities for us to continue to raise awareness about mass
incarceration and issues around parole.
3.WE ARE RAISING
AWARENESS! By having a series
of panel discussions to raise awareness and educate people about parole. We are
also having events such as dinner and a movie where we will show Joe Berling’s
documentary “The System” Parole with a free spaghetti dinner and discussion.
WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO?
This fundraiser is accountable to Donald Perry and his partner Elaine Arsenault. The money raised will help with:
• $5-10k for the lawyer
• $2-3k in court fees, securing expert witnesses, obtaining record's, processing evidence, etc.
• $15k debt/bills that piled up for almost 3 years while Donald was in jail for a crime he didn't commit and was acquitted of
• Travel Expenses: to meetings, appointments, etc.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help!
•  Follow our campaign at justicefordonald.org
• Help spread the word by sharing our story and linking others to our website
• Take a look at what we need the money for, maybe you can help with something there :)
THANK YOU!
We appreciate all individual donations! We also encourage people
to organize community fundraisers to connect with each other and bring more

","Justice for Donald
Donald Perry is a 60 years-old loving family man. He is a compassionate
community servant, with a generous spirit. Donald has earned the
respect, admiration, and trust of countless community members who have
witnessed his tireless work on behalf of poor and homeless persons in
Hampshire County.
Donald was working full time as the coordinator for the
single room occupancy Outreach program and kitchen manager at the local
soup kitchen when he was pulled over and arrested in 2011. The MA Parole
Board imprisoned him for 2 years and 8 months for a crime he did not
commit, and was acquitted of.  (Read about The Case)
At present, Donald is on parole for life based on his imposed
sentence. Donald, Elaine, close family members, and friends well
understand after this recent incident, that Donald can be picked up and
returned to prison any moment regardless of what he does or doesn’t do. Donald says
he’ll never be FREE until he’s off parole, period.
The idea and much effort now is Donald going back into court on a
RULE 30 motion to hopefully get his life sentence vacated.
What We Need & What You Get
This fundraiser is CRITICAL because:
1. Donald faces legal expenses– A $5,000
retainer, court fees, securing expert witnesses, travel costs,
obtaining record's, processing evidence, etc. Donald’s supporters can mobilize
to raise funds that will ensure that he has resources for the trial, increasing
his chances of securing freedom.
2. Our
continued organizing will make sure that justice will be served in Donald’s
case and that our commitment to his true freedom remains active. It also
creates opportunities for us to continue to raise awareness about mass
incarceration and issues around parole.
3.WE ARE RAISING
AWARENESS! By having a series
of panel discussions to raise awareness and educate people about parole. We are
also having events such as dinner and a movie where we will show Joe Berling’s
documentary “The System” Parole with a free spaghetti dinner and discussion.
WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO?
This fundraiser is accountable to Donald Perry and his partner Elaine Arsenault. The money raised will help with:
$5-10k for the lawyer
$2-3k in court fees, securing expert witnesses, obtaining record's, processing evidence, etc.
$15k debt/bills that piled up for almost 3 years while Donald was in jail for a crime he didn't commit and was acquitted of
Travel Expenses: to meetings, appointments, etc.
Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help!
Follow our campaign at justicefordonald.org
Help spread the word by sharing our story and linking others to our website
Take a look at what we need the money for, maybe you can help with something there :)
THANK YOU!
We appreciate all individual donations! We also encourage people
to organize community fundraisers to connect with each other and bring more
people into the movement. Organize community potlucks, local concerts, raffles,
talent shows, parties for MLK Day. Fundraising
is a huge part of movement building!
PS: If you want to send a donation via check, you can mail the check to:
Elaine ArsenaultP.O. BOX 3660Amherst, MA 01004

With just over 48 hours left in our campaign, we ask that you share this page widely with your friends and family, and hey, why not your coworkers!

--------------

Thank you everyone for helping us reach our minimum goal of 5000$.  While have reached our minimum, we are not stopping here. We are hoping to continue raising fund to ensure that we can send even more children to camp, and maybe even cover some of the travel costs for the camp leaders we are sending to Ukraine from Canada. In addition to volunteering their time for these camps, they also generally cover their own travel costs - over 1000$ to travel to and from Ukraine.

_______________________________  

Each summer the Ukrainian Youth Association (UYA) runs summer camps across the globe for all ages. Last year, UYA Canada participated in a new summer camp for a special group of children
column2:
those displaced by the war in Eastern Ukraine. 

Last year's camp, A road though our ancestry, was a grand success, as was last year's Indiegogo fundraiser,  Send a Ukrainian Displaced Child to Camp, which raised over $7,000 CAD.

With the war in Eastern Ukraine continuing and hundreds of thousands of children who have lost their homes or have been relocated away from friends and family, it is our hope that you will help us make this year's camp even better than last year!

Many of these children have lost loved ones to this war and others still have parents on the war front.  A recent UNICEF report  has indicated that half a million children are currently being affected by the ongoing violence in Eastern Ukraine.  It is for these reasons that the UYA has decided to run a 2nd camp for Displaced Ukrainian Children.

Based at the Rovesnyk Base  in Chervonohrad, Lviv Region, Ukraine, and under the watchful eyes of volunteers from around the world, this year's camp,  - We are Ukraine - will take place from August 1st though to August 12th, 2016 and, this year, hopes to double the number of participants, taking us from 75 to 150 children and youth.  The Canadian executive of the UYA has pledged to cover costs for at least 20 to 25 of the 150 participants.  The additional participants will be funded by other National Executives of the association.  

The costs to send a single child to a two-week camp (including two travel days) is between $250-$300 CAD depending on the value of the Canadian dollar.  This cost includes 3 meals and 2 snacks, travel costs for all campers to and from the camp, and any and all activities planned. 

This year the Canadian Ukrainian Youth Association has committed to a minimum of $5,000 CAD to ensure that as many children as possible can attend.  Funds above and beyond $5,000 CAD will be used for administrative costs and to improve and add activities to the camp.   With an adult to child ratio of no more than 1:10, the Canadian UYA Executive hopes to be able to subsidize travel costs for 2 or 3  volunteer staff they will be sending this year.

Planned activities at this year's camp include: Sports, arts and crafts, health and wellness, water activities, singing and the opportunity for these children to make lifelong friends from around the world.

We ask that you visit  the Gallery and Updates sections of the campaign page as well, as we will be posting additional information and photographs as they become available. 

If you are unable to donate but wish to contribute in another way please email us. Last year a donation of 250 stuffed Canadian teddy bears was made and each child got to take home a souvenir from camp.

Should you have any questions or concerns, please contact the UYA of Canada at: 

416-537-2007
KY-Canada@cym.org

or in Ukrainian only, The UYA in Ukraine here.


Contact information for individual branches of the Canadian UYA can be found here, while information regarding other national executives can be located by clicking here. Please choose the country that interests you at the top right of the page.

We ask that you note that tax receipts for these donations will not be provided as the funds collected are being used outside of Canada and our charitable status does not apply for these types of donations.
