column1: More than a bookstore, Revolution Books is the political, intellectual, and cultural Center of a movement for revolution. Important Books. Pulitzer and Grammy award winners mixing it up with youth and ex-prisoners. Scholars and writers engaging with spokesperson Andy Zee and other revolutionary thinkers and fighters. RB is a place of radical and revolutionary ferment. A place that hosts a culture of revolt against a revolting culture.For all of this, your support is essential. Your contribution makes it possible for the new Revolution Books in Harlem to be viable and thrive.This can't happen on the sale of books alone, especially when so many still don't know about the new RB in Harlem. Your contribution this year will go to a vibrant promotion campaign so that many more people learn about and make our RB a destination. This is crucial to getting the store on a sustainable path.RB has an important curated collection of thousands of books... but more titles are needed to serve the wide scope of our global mission and as part of making RB viable.Without you, RB cannot meet the needs of today. But with your generous contribution, Revolution Books will meet that need with the books, the engagement, and the understanding to forge a culture, a people, and a movement for a whole new world.TOGETHER, WE CAN WIN THE REVOLUTION BOOKS FUND DRIVE --$25,000 BY AUGUST 2* * *NEWS: Journalist and author HERB BOYD (Baldwin in Harlem, Black Detroit) speaks on C-SPAN Book TV about Revolution Books and the history of independent bookstores in Harlem.&amp
column175: * * *At a time when a fascist regime has come to power in the U.S. and is bent on a horrific course for humanity and the planet…Revolution Books has to be much more widely known and have far greater impact.

column1: $25,000 by August 2!* For promotion and publicity to let the world know* For more books that matter...to take Revolution Books to a whole new level of impact
RB can’t survive and rise to this urgent moment without YOU. Donate now.
Watching RevBooks' Indiegogo video on Sunday afternoon in the bookstore

RB is a unique and vibrant space: a bookstore that is the political, intellectual, and cultural center of a movement for revolution. This summer Revolution Books launches its third annual crowd-funding campaign. RB must expand its reach and base of support at a time when this bookstore matters more than ever.

From an NGO consultant: ""...This fund drive for Revolution Books is not just a ""feel-good"" moment but an absolute imperative for anyone who sees what is going on in this country and around the world and who desperately wants to learn more, do more, have more of an actual impact ...""To read the whole statement, go here: http://www.revolutionbooksnyc.org/NGOstatement.htm
At Revolution Books the lights are holding steady and people are talking...""

--so wrote LitHub on Nov 30, 2016... ""There was a time when it wasn’t so peculiar to believe that a new world order might be launched from a bookstore. In Harlem, on the stretch of Lenox Avenue also known as Malcolm X Boulevard, across the street from St. John’s Pentecostal and two doors down from the House of Seafood, that time persists—at least inside Revolution Books, which is either a throwback to a bygone era or the vanguard of a strikingly new one, depending on whom you ask and whether a bigoted oligarch has recently been elected to serve as President of the United States. On that latter subject, the signs propped up on the sidewalk and hanging in the front window make the store’s position fairly clear: “Mein Trumpf: A Thoroughly American Fascist Pig!” declares one, with a graphic mashup of Trump, Hitler and a Klansman. Another: “In the Name of Humanity We REFUSE to Accept a Fascist America”... Read whole article here
A BOOKSTORE THAT CHANGES LIVES…

* Parents bring their kids to discover books that promote values of cooperation, appreciation for diversity, and the ability to learn about the world and make it better. One Saturday morning program taught young children about evolution.

* A high school intern on his first day says he doesn’t know much about the world and wants to learn. He talks to RB staff, finds the book Enrique's Journey about children from Central America who travel to the US on top of trains
column2: he observes: “People are forced to escape to America because of what it does to their countries, but when they come, America  doesn’t want them.”

column1: * Professors and Harlem neighbors come to find the new scholarship on slavery and the true history of Black people in the US
column2: high school and college students come to explore and debate the causes of women’s oppression and how that oppression can be overcome.

column1: Revolution Books can change more lives -- with your donation today.

...When an HIV awareness event I was planning could no longer be accommodated at our first venue, Rev Books became a home for the event. I'm thankful and pleased that Revolution Books has a place in our community. It's more than a bookstore
column2: it's a panel discussion on Mondays, or an open mic night on Fridays. Its purpose morphs and serves our neighborhood and its people as a hub for exploration and knowledge. -- Marvin, works at Harlem social service organization

column1: MISSION: THE EMANCIPATION OF HUMANITY…

This is a place where people of all ages find the books and discussion with each other about why the world is the way it is, and how it could be transformed in the interests of the people of the world. At RB, revolution is the foundation for the rich engagement with the world of ideas. Rev Books features incredible books: fiction, history, art, philosophy, science, memoir, revolutionary theory... children’s literature.
Carl Dix, RB spokesperson Andy Zee and Dr. Cornel West, October 2016,at the launch of Bob Avakian's book The New Communism

At RB, people discover and can take up a truly scientific approach to the problems confronting the 7 billion on this planet, and the way out of the madness--the new synthesis of communism developed by Bob Avakian—and the leadership he is giving to the revolution to emancipate humanity. Watch BA here.
Donate now to make RB more widely known and visited.
A GREAT BEGINNING, NOVEMBER 2015…

We converted a former beauty parlor into a beautiful bookstore and performance space. A local architect donated the design. Students and neighborhood people helped spackle and paint. Intellectuals, people in the book world, and neighborhood activists fed in ideas and helped spread the word. People from different walks of life and raised the funds to acquire new books and make the initial renovations.
Sunsara Taylor and Dr. Willie Parker, one of the last abortion doctors in the South at Revolution Books on June 4, 2017 (Photo: Ronald Dennis)
REVOLUTION BOOKS IS MAKING A REAL DIFFERENCE.

Since opening, RB has hosted dozens of author programs and cultural events. Two 2017  Pulitzer Prize winners, novelist Colson Whitehead (Underground Railroad) and historian Heather Ann Thompson (Blood in the Water on the Attica rebellion), have appeared in conversation with RB spokesperson Andy Zee.

Programs on mass incarceration have gotten into how America’s history of white supremacy and current political economy have produced this situation. A scientist/author who spoke at RB was asked: “What would be the ideal way for science to be taught and conducted in a just society?” The Revolution Club’s “Future People” open-mic nights have become a platform for music, spoken word, poetry -- and for discussion over what young people’s lives should be about.
The possibility of a radically different world opens up at RB
column2: the fiction, poetry, plays and performance reveal the soaring heights of human achievement
column3: and there is stimulating discussion, sharp and often jolting debate that challenges preconceptions. But it’s more than that. People who experience and are part of the life of RB—they go back out into the world. They influence and challenge others … and some become part of the movement for revolution. Yes, Revolution Books changes lives.

column1: Benefit Concert with Grammy-award winner Arturo O'Farrill in December 2016,on RB's new performance stage, funded by last year's Indiegogo campaign.
AT THIS DANGEROUS TIME, RB MATTERS EVEN MORE.

When Donald Trump came to power, RB swung into action with “65 Defiant Days of Talks, Culture, and Dialogue: In the Name of Humanity, We Refuse to Accept a Fascist America.”  We’ve continued to hold programs on and debated the roots of fascism in America, the lessons of history, and the kind of movement and struggle necessary to stop it.
Where else but at Revolution Books? Donate now.Revolution Books is a not-for-profit bookstore with an all-volunteer staff.
At a recent Future People Open-Mic at Revolution Books

At a moment of peril for humanity and the world, RB is providing a forum for addressing the specific crisis facing humanity, with the rise of a fascist regime in America and with repression, displacement and proxy wars sweeping across the world. Come to Revolution Books to find the questions being asked and debated and the scientific means being put forward for answering them. We all need to help make sure – right now – that Revolution Books will be there when it is most needed. – International human development consultant, Brooklyn

Revolution Books is a magical place.  A treasure of radical thinking, dreaming and planning.""  -- Award-winning playwright Naomi WallaceNaomi Wallace and Bruce McLeod recently donated $500 to the Revolution Books Education Fund (RBEF). FYI:  If you want to make a tax-deductible donation, go to Revolution Books Education Fund a 501(c)3 entity which sponsors RB events.

* * *The discourse and engagement at Revolution Books involve people from around the world, and from around the corner. People are coming to Harlem because of RB -- and people in Harlem are learning about the world and the potential for a real revolution because of RB.
BUT WE ARE AT A CROSSROADS.YOUR DONATION MAKES A DIFFERENCE:

* We need thousands more people coming to the store, buying books, attending our programs and donating—in order to generate revenue to pay our rent and expand our selection. But that potential customer base doesn’t yet know about the store! Your contribution will enable us to publicize and promote RB, buy advertising including in social media, and improve our signage.

* When the thousands come, they need to find hundreds more of the books that open pathways to understanding the past and present, the possibilities of the future, and the yearnings of humanity. Your contribution will fund the purchase of books about the global refugee crisis, Spanish-language, new African fiction, children’s literature, and more.

$25,000 by August 2!* For promotion and publicity to let the world know* For more books that matter...to take Revolution Books to a whole new level of impactDonate and participate.BECAUSE RB CHANGES LIVES.BECAUSE WITHOUT RB THE WORLD STAYS AS IT IS.   * * *PERKS
$25 - Red Star enamel pin. Donated by Peoples Pins, Everitt, WA.  3/4"" wide
$50 - Revolution Books mug
$50 - RB mug with Dancer from Red Detachment of Women  ballet
$75- RB heavy red canvas tote bag

NEW!  $75- Yusef Salaam's new book of poetry, ""Words of a Man: My Right To Be."" We have 5 signed copies from the Yusef's book release party at Revolution Books. Yusef was one of the Central Park 5-- Black youth 14-16 years old who were framed up for the rape of a jogger and spent years in prison before being exonerated. Hard-to-get paperback.
$75 - Color poster from a benefit concert for Revolution Books with Afro-jazz great Arturo O'Farrill and his ensemble. 8.5""x11""
NEW! $75- Novel ""Here Comes the Sun,"" signed by the author Nicole Dennis-Benn during her evening at Revolution Books, July 7, 2017.  Paperback. Story of 3 women living in Montego Bay, Jamaica.

NEW!! - $75  Voucher good for 1 Homemade Pie donated by ""Fancy Pies: A Seasonal Pop-Up Pie Shop"" in Washington Heights. ""Just Peachy,"" ""Dave's Mixed Berry,"" and on and on. Take a look:  https://twitter.com/fancy_pies?lang=en

$100 - 2017 Hardback, signed by James Forman Jr. when he spoke at RB in June. A New York Times Book Review Editors' Choice, on how so many Black judges, prosecutors, politicians ended up ""locking up our own.""

NEW!   $100 -  Book by Professor Cheryl Wall, ""Women of the Harlem Renaissance,"" This hard-to-get acclaimed history was signed by the author during her evening at Revolution Books in June 2017. Watch here: vimeo.com/222786509

$150 - Bob Avakian Essentials.  Books by Bob Avakian: The New Communism and BAsics. Book by Ardea Skybreak: Science and Revolution. Includes Pin: ""There is no app for critical thinking."" -- Bob Avakian

NEW!  $150  - ""Life + Debt"" DVD, Collector's edition. Acclaimed documentary on imperialism, Test-case: Jamaica.  Directed by Stephanie Black who donated 3 copies. Narration by Jamaica Kincard, music by Mutabaruka. ""Powerful. Offers the clearest analysis of  globalization and its negative effects that I have ever seen."" -- Stephen Holden, NY Times

NEW! $200 - Amazing Dinner for 2, donated by Harlem Bar-B-Q, 547 Malcolm X Blvd. Specializes in ribs, wings, frozen margaritas!  ""Harlem Bar-B-Q believes in giving back to our community so that we all may move forward together. We support Revolution Books for being a staple bookstore in Harlem and a valuable resource for future generations to come.""

NEW!  $250 - Just published (July 2017) hardcover book: Conversations with Edwidge Danticat, edited by Maxine Lavon Montgomery, Literary Conversations Series, University Press of Mississippi. Includes interviews with the acclaimed Haitian novelist and essayist, ranging from 2000 (on Breath, Eyes, Memory) to a previously unpublished 2016 interview which offers insight into her life, art, and politics.

$500 - Rare poster of famous Chinese peasant painting from Huhsien County, revolutionary China circa 1973. This poster was brought back from China at that time, and recently donated to Revolution Books.  20"" x 30""

$750 - Screen Print by Shepard Fairey, in collaboration with Glen E. Friedman who took the photograph of Cornel West at the first dialogue between Dr. West and Carl Dix in July 2009. Edition of 450. Rare. Donated to RB by Shepard Fairey and Glen E. Friedman, signed by both artists + Dr. West.  18"" x 24″

NEW!  - $1500  Wooden carving of a young woman, with beads, Ivory Coast circa 1970.Created by master carver from Atsei tribe. Carving of young woman, with beads at waist. Used in initiation ceremony for young woman going from puberty to adult. The figure's arms move forward and back.  Donated by a Harlem collector. 12"" x 4.5""",29.0,2,"3 Campaigns

Ad.dar (“home” in Arabic) is an all-volunteer, non-political, non-religious community center for Syrian refugees in Istanbul.

Ad.dar’s main objective is to provide the tools to Syrian refugees in Istanbul to rebuild their lives with dignity after the trauma of war and displacement.

Through our education programs, we help children, youth and adults to return to their education. For this purpose, it has provided advanced linguistic and university preparation education and support along with basic linguistic education for the improvement of livelihood opportunities for Syrian refugees.

Ad.dar also holds regular workshops to mentor Syrians with their resumes and applications and to help them understand their rights in Turkey.

Weekly workshops for children provide a place to allow children to play, socialize, and enjoy the freedom to be a child.

Through cultural events, such as Friday film evenings, poetry readings, concerts, cooking club and community meals, Ad.dar brings together Syrian, local and international communities, which makes Ad.dar a shared place of solidarity to keep Syrian culture alive.

Humans for Humans

We can no longer stand to see so many people in our community living on the streets, without doing what we can to help them out.

We hope to raise $1500 to purchase food, water and essential necessities like socks, toiletries, blankets, reusable water bottles, and information on where they can get assistance. Then, we will go to places with large homeless populations like the Tenderloin in SF, People's Park in Berkeley, and West Oakland, set up a couple buffet tables, fire up the grill, and serve a meal. We will play awesome music and bring friends who are live painters, hula hoopers, and performance artists to create a fun, positive environment for everyone to feel a sense of community and joy.

We will run these fundraisers and events as regularly as possible, and then begin teaching people how to use crowdfunding and social media to provide assistance to the humans who need it in their community.
We have researched what items are most useful, and what resources &
column2: information are most important for them to know about. In addition to food and water, we will buy and collect these items, with the goal of giving people immediate assistance and empowerment:

column1: - A laminated packet of information with important resources (numbers to call &
column2: places to go where they can get help
column4: times of upcoming outreach programs, free clinics, free meals, free haircuts, free classes, etc.)

column1: - Food to be cooked for the buffet, non-perishable food for them to take with them, and gift certificates to restaurants (very helpful, as it gives them access to a bathroom and a hot meal).
- Backpacks, sleeping pads, sleeping bags, blankets.
- Reusable water bottles, thermoses, and cutlery.
- Clothes, socks, shoes and gift cards to Goodwill/Salvation Army stores.
- Toiletries / Hygiene products.
- Gift cards to local laundromats
- Books like ""The Alchemist"" and other similarly inspiring stories.
Until there are enough beds and programs made available for those of us who need them, we want to help people living on the street be as self-reliant as possible.

There are an estimated 36,000 homeless people in the Bay Area, and only about 10,000 beds available to them. There is an untold number of people in our community living on the street. Large numbers of visibly homeless residents started to appear in the Bay Area during the 1980’s, when many of the social protections introduced in programs like the New Deal were eroded in the name of the free market. President Reagan cut the budget for Section 8 assistance in half during his first year in office. This funding was meant to keep low-income Americans off the streets by subsidizing their housing costs.

In 1987, an economic downturn did even more damage to people on the brink, who had already been left behind by unequally distributed prosperity earlier in the decade.  According to the  2013 Homeless Point-In-Time Count &
column2: Survey released by San Francisco’s municipal authority, the last decade has seen the same relationship between economic failure and increased homelessness.

column1: 1 in 3 homeless people in the Bay Area suffer from a mental health condition, with 23% citing a specific illness such as Schizophrenia, 42% suffering from chronic depression, and 15% with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.  According to Dr. E Fuller Torrey’s 2013 article, “Ronald Reagan’s shameful legacy: Violence, the homeless, mental illness,” the increase in mentally ill homeless people is also relatively recent. Just as Reagan ended many of the New Deal programs, he also closed state mental hospitals and cut mental health funding during his time as Governor of California and as President of the United States.
29% of respondents said they became homeless after losing a job, while only 11% cited alcohol or drug use as the main cause.

The Vision

    For 6 months out of the year, we go on a national tour with electronic musician Phutureprimitive, so we will be able to teach people across the country how to crowdfund through social media to provide for homeless people in their local communities.

Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people can't donate money, but that doesn't mean they can't contribute:
<li>If you live in the Bay Area and would like to donate any of the items listed, send an email to caeli426@gmail.com, and we'<span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >ll schedule a time to come pick them up from you!

column1: • If you would like to help us serve the food, or volunteer as an entertainer, live painter, dancer, healer, musician, or if there's anything else you'd like to do, email caeli426@gmail.com.
• If you have any suggestions for items/information/resources that we should include, or people/organizations/etc. that we should link up with, let us know!

My brother and I have been investigating child sexual abuse cases since 1990. We have been working on a case involving child pornography and child sexual abuse in the mid-west for the past several years. By contributing to this project, you will enable us to bring additional researchers into this investigation so that we can bring an end to the suffering of children, expose and prosecute the perpetrators.

It has taken several years to identify perpetrators and locate witnesses, as well as finding capable investigators to take on this endeavor. If our $4000 goal is reached, we will be able to bring researchers and investigators (including one from overseas) together to collaborate, share findings and strategize in order to move the investigation forward.

Le projet

Établi à la Maison de la solidarité internationale depuis mars 2017, le Comité régional d’éducation pour le développement international de Lanaudière (CRÉDIL) souhaite aménager un espace unique dans la région : une salle multifonctionnelle qui favorisera le rapprochement interculturel entre Lanaudois et Lanaudoises de toutes origines!

Le CRÉDIL met la priorité sur l'aménagement de cette salle qui permettra notamment la tenue d’ateliers interactifs, de conférences et d’activités d’éducation populaire. Avec cet espace, le CRÉDIL souhaite créer des liens et des échanges entre les différents groupes d’individus de la société, en plus de favoriser le partage et le rapprochement interculturel. Par conséquent, ce nouvel espace aura comme objectif de favoriser l’inclusion sociale, entre autres des familles réfugiées et immigrantes que le CRÉDIL reçoit chaque année, depuis 20 ans, en permettant d’accroître l’implication citoyenne, de faciliter l'établissement d’un réseau social et de renforcer les capacités de transformation sociale.

Avec une capacité d'une soixantaine de places assises, cette salle permettra également à différents groupes communautaires de la région de se prévaloir d'un nouvel espace accueillant, inclusif et muni de technologies adaptées. Dans la région de Lanaudière, peu de salles sont disponibles, et elles sont souvent très coûteuses pour les organismes communautaires qui doivent composer avec des budgets limités.

 

À quoi serviront les fonds?

Nous nous sommes fixés l’objectif de 5 000 $ à amasser en engageant la communauté à travers le sociofinancement. Ce montant nous permettra d’entreprendre les travaux pour la mise en place de ce lieu de rencontre et d’échange.

Concrètement, vos dons permettront :
<li>L’organisation d’activités visant le rapprochement interculturel auprès du réseau du CRÉDIL qui incluent des personnes immigrantes et réfugiées, bénévoles, membres et partenaires
<li>L’engagement citoyen de Lanaudois et Lanaudoises de toutes origines qui prendront part à des formations, ateliers, conférences, etc.
• La tenue d’ateliers et de conférences organisées par divers groupes et organismes communautaires de la région de Lanaudière.

En soutenant cette campagne de financement, vous contribuez donc à soutenir de nombreuses initiatives d’inclusion sociale dans la région de Lanaudière! Pour vous remercier de votre générosité, nous vous offrons en retour diverses contreparties dans la section « Perks » à droite de cet écran. Selon le montant de votre don, vous pourrez bénéficier d’une invitation à l’inauguration de la salle, votre nom sur la plaque des donateurs affichée dans la salle ou encore de locations gratuites de la salle pour une journée. Si ces locations ne vous sont pas utiles, nous vous invitons à en faire don à un organisme communautaire de la région qui pourra en bénéficier. Une belle manière de soutenir l’initiative du CRÉDIL tout en redonnant à la communauté!

Pour plus de détails sur l'aménagement de salle ou sur la campagne de sociofinancement, veuillez consulter la section « FAQ ». Pour toute question, vous pouvez aussi nous écrire à communications@credil.qc.ca ou nous joindre au 450-756-0011 poste 210.

 

Pourquoi donner?

Le CRÉDIL possède plus de 40 ans d’expérience en rapprochement interculturel et mobilisation citoyenne dans la région de Lanaudière. Il accomplit sa mission par le biais de trois axes d’intervention : l’éducation à la citoyenneté mondiale, la réalisation de projets et de stages internationaux et l’accompagnement des nouveaux arrivants.

Oeuvrant dans la région depuis 1976, le travail du CRÉDIL vise à renforcer les capacités d’actions des communautés et favoriser l’intégration interculturelle en collaboration avec des partenaires régionaux et internationaux. Les projets du CRÉDIL incluent l’installation et l’accompagnement de personnes réfugiées et immigrantes, des initiatives qui contribuent aux efforts de développement des communautés du Sud, ainsi que des activités et projets visant à sensibiliser le public aux enjeux internationaux.

En soutenant cette campagne de financement, vous contribuez à un monde plus juste et solidaire.

","Le projetÉtabli à la Maison de la solidarité internationale depuis mars 2017, le Comité régional d’éducation pour le développement international de Lanaudière (CRÉDIL) souhaite aménager un espace unique dans la région : une salle multifonctionnelle qui favorisera le rapprochement interculturel entre Lanaudois et Lanaudoises de toutes origines!Le CRÉDIL met la priorité sur l'aménagement de cette salle qui permettra notamment la tenue d’ateliers interactifs, de conférences et d’activités d’éducation populaire. Avec cet espace, le CRÉDIL souhaite créer des liens et des échanges entre les différents groupes d’individus de la société, en plus de favoriser le partage et le rapprochement interculturel. Par conséquent, ce nouvel espace aura comme objectif de favoriser l’inclusion sociale, entre autres des familles réfugiées et immigrantes que le CRÉDIL reçoit chaque année, depuis 20 ans, en permettant d’accroître l’implication citoyenne, de faciliter l'établissement d’un réseau social et de renforcer les capacités de transformation sociale.Avec une capacité d'une soixantaine de places assises, cette salle permettra également à différents groupes communautaires de la région de se prévaloir d'un nouvel espace accueillant, inclusif et muni de technologies adaptées. Dans la région de Lanaudière, peu de salles sont disponibles, et elles sont souvent très coûteuses pour les organismes communautaires qui doivent composer avec des budgets limités. À quoi serviront les fonds?Nous nous sommes fixés l’objectif de 5 000 $ à amasser en engageant la communauté à travers le sociofinancement. Ce montant nous permettra d’entreprendre les travaux pour la mise en place de ce lieu de rencontre et d’échange.Concrètement, vos dons permettront :
L’organisation d’activités visant le rapprochement interculturel auprès du réseau du CRÉDIL qui incluent des personnes immigrantes et réfugiées, bénévoles, membres et partenaires
L’engagement citoyen de Lanaudois et Lanaudoises de toutes origines qui prendront part à des formations, ateliers, conférences, etc.
La tenue d’ateliers et de conférences organisées par divers groupes et organismes communautaires de la région de Lanaudière.

En soutenant cette campagne de financement, vous contribuez donc à soutenir de nombreuses initiatives d’inclusion sociale dans la région de Lanaudière! Pour vous remercier de votre générosité, nous vous offrons en retour diverses contreparties dans la section « Perks » à droite de cet écran. Selon le montant de votre don, vous pourrez bénéficier d’une invitation à l’inauguration de la salle, votre nom sur la plaque des donateurs affichée dans la salle ou encore de locations gratuites de la salle pour une journée. Si ces locations ne vous sont pas utiles, nous vous invitons à en faire don à un organisme communautaire de la région qui pourra en bénéficier. Une belle manière de soutenir l’initiative du CRÉDIL tout en redonnant à la communauté!Pour plus de détails sur l'aménagement de salle ou sur la campagne de sociofinancement, veuillez consulter la section « FAQ ». Pour toute question, vous pouvez aussi nous écrire à communications@credil.qc.ca ou nous joindre au 450-756-0011 poste 210. Pourquoi donner?Le CRÉDIL possède plus de 40 ans d’expérience en rapprochement interculturel et mobilisation citoyenne dans la région de Lanaudière. Il accomplit sa mission par le biais de trois axes d’intervention : l’éducation à la citoyenneté mondiale, la réalisation de projets et de stages internationaux et l’accompagnement des nouveaux arrivants.Oeuvrant dans la région depuis 1976, le travail du CRÉDIL vise à renforcer les capacités d’actions des communautés et favoriser l’intégration interculturelle en collaboration avec des partenaires régionaux et internationaux. Les projets du CRÉDIL incluent l’installation et l’accompagnement de personnes réfugiées et immigrantes, des initiatives qui contribuent aux efforts de développement des communautés du Sud, ainsi que des activités et projets visant à sensibiliser le public aux enjeux internationaux.En soutenant cette campagne de financement, vous contribuez à un monde plus juste et solidaire.",2.0,0,"1 Campaign

WHERE WILL YOUR DONATION GO?
<ul><li><span>I am seeking funds to cover airfare, a travel visa, travel
insurance, and internship costs so that I can live and work in Jodhpur
India. I will be engaging in community outreach, sustainable development,
teaching youth and women, and legal advocacy. FSD partners in India have pledged to
provide full room and board.
<ul><li><u>All additional
funding will go directly to the successful growth and expansion of the
FSD.
WHAT IS THE GOAL?
<ul>
<li>
To live and volunteer in Jodhpur, India where
I will impact the lives of disempowered and marginalized Indian women by working
as a legal advocate for victims of rape and abuse, and together with other
local non-profits groups, ensure that women are protected from abuse, rape, and
discrimination.
<li>
To implement gender sensitivity education into
the Indian curriculum for young boys.
<li>
To provide support and counselling, assist in
the development of community workshops on rights, leadership, life skills and
empowerment
<li>
I will also be living with a host family, and
chronicling my work for all of you to see on my blog
CALL TO ACTION

The people of the Earth have entered in varying degrees into a universal community, and it has developed to the point where a violation of rights in one part of the world is felt everywhere. In our rapidly changing world, we are more connected and more aware of the human rights violations and crimes against humanity, even if they are unfolding oceans apart. Whether human rights violations are being committed locally, or internationally, all humans should regard themselves as being part of a single community where it is our responsibility to take collective action to protect the most vulnerable from suffering and injustice.
DECEMBER 16TH 2012
Almost everyone today has heard of the gang rape of
a young Indian student that occurred in Delhi on December 16th, 2012. The
newspapers reported that the victims’ intestines were ripped out by the group
of men who also suggested that she be thrown naked from the bus.
The rape resulted in the young girls death. Immediately
following the announcement of the incident, a series of demonstrations in
support of the victim followed. The demonstrators were demanding legal and
policing reforms from the Indian government.
The mass
demonstrations, outrage and media coverage is illustrative of how communal the
world has become and that women’s issues in India, or any part of the world,
are personal issues too.
The
significant amount of attention attracted by the tragic event and the indignation
expressed by demonstrators and international organizations worldwide led the
Indian government to openly recognize the existence of a problem and adopt some
measures to address it.
The details
of this brutal rape are difficult to shake, however it is encouraging to know
that we, as a collective community, can make a difference in various ways.
A protester at Jantar
Mantar in New Delhi - The crowds chanted slogans against the government for its
perceived inaction in preventing cases of rape and being unable to better
protect women in the capital.
THE SITUATION IN INDIA
Rape in India
has been described as one of India's most common crimes against women and by UN's human-rights chief as a “national problem”.
According to 2012 statistics, New Delhi has the
highest number of rape-reports among Indian cities, while Jabalpur has the per capita incidence of reported rapes.
<ul>
<li>
Official data in India show that rape cases have jumped almost 875% over
the past 40 years -- from 2,487 in 1971 to 24,206 in 2011
<li>
A new case is reported every
20 minutes
Let us take
a closer look at the situation in India. Almost all newspapers repeat the sad fact that
Delhi can be described as a world capital of rape. However, more generally, we can see that rape
is a wide-spread and silently tolerated phenomenon in India, especially in its
northern provinces. Reports often link
this prevalence of rape with patriarchal and degrading traditional attitudes
towards women.
CASTE DISCRIMINATION -
Caste-based discrimination remains a problematic practice in India which labels
individuals as ‘outcastes’ or dalits. This
deep-rooted discrimination causes marginalisation, social and economic
exclusion, severely poor work conditions, and limited access to basic services
such as water, sanitation and employment. In India, caste systems divide people
into social groups (castes) where their rights are determined by birth and are
permanently fixed.<span>  Unequal and
hierarchical, those at the top enjoy comfortable social positions, while those
at the bottom struggle without any rights.
Dalit
women and girls are especially vulnerable, experiencing not only the
discrimination of caste, but also of class and gender – ‘triple discrimination’
as it’s called in India – leaving them in a vicious cycle of marginalisation
and exploitation. National crime statistics indicate an average of over 1,000
rape cases against dalit women are reported annually, the highest of any social
group.
In addition,
such factors as insufficient punishment and unsatisfactory judicial system which
is particularly slow and overloaded are also often cited as being part of the
problem.
Many other
shocking stories of rape have made headlines in Western media, but we’ve
forgotten them. For some reasons, at
certain points of time, one or another particular case is able to mobilize
opinion and action.
India can be seen as a
country permeated with a violent mentality. Few can claim not to have been on the
receiving end of physical violence from family members and many who suffer at
the hands of violence go on to perform similar acts themselves. Ninety per cent of sexual attackers are known
to their victims, dispelling the myth of attackers as random offenders.
WHAT NEEDS TO BE DONE? India needs to
chip away at the patriarchal and misogynistic mentality.<span>  Education on gender equality has to begin with
the youth, within homes and primary schools, and be reinforced with a strong
and sustained anti-violence government-funded campaign.
India needs to start at the fundamental
basics and reprogram the way that Indian society thinks about gender, about
masculinity, about femininity and women’s position in society. These are basic
notions that have been accepted into the Indian Constitution but have NOT been
accepted into India’s social mentality and actions.
More preventative measures are required to
tackle the problem.
One of my projects will focus
on the <u>lack of gender education in the Indian curriculum.</u> Youth needs to
be asked and encouraged to think about certain questions.
1. How do young Indian
boys and girls grow up to think about sex and about gender and about sexual
relationships or even emotional relationships?
2. What is adolescent
education, and what should it be, and what are the issues that really need to
be in the public sphere?
People generally are not
comfortable talking about sexuality or reproductive rights or issues like sexual
desire, even within the family, let alone within the classroom or the
workplace. These issues are avoided. As a
result, there’s an enormous amount of ignorance and denial. Teachers are likely
to have difficulty answering questions about sexuality as well.
It’s hard to generate the political will for
people in senior positions in the education system to support teachers and to
train teachers to talk about these issues. So there is a second critical element: finding
ways to challenge boys and girls to think about what it means to be “cool,” to
impress one’s peers, and what it means to be a strong boy or man.
What is needed is a dramatic shift in the
gender norm balance. There are all sorts of ways one can do that: of course,
formally in the classroom, but also through extracurricular activities.
We need to work on education and on promoting
healthy and non-predatory relationships between boys and girls, and getting
away from a lot of the hypocrisy that exists.
THE VISION &
As an intern
for FSD I will work to support and educate the women of the local communities. The work I do will change their lives.
I will be
focusing on three projects.
1. Education for Youth on
Equality and Women’s Rights
<ul>
<li>
Gender education
in the Indian curriculum that we aim to teach young boys about gender equality.
<li>
Support teachers
and equip them with tools so they can educate and discuss issues such as
sexually, reproductive rights, and women’s equality with students.
2. Legal Counseling, Education
on Rights, &amp
<ul>
<li>
I will be supporting marginalized women by educating them to better
understand their basic human rights and how to assert these rights. The aim
here is to promote self-efficacy and empower these women so that they may
effectively combat violence.
<li>
Educate local women through a series of workshops about the Indian
Constitution, laws that benefit and protect women and their families, gender
sensitivity, leadership, and empowerment
<li>
Provide legal and/or psychological support for victims of violence who
decide to take legal action
3. Lobbying
<ul>
<li>
Support the lobby of government and legislative authorities about issues
and solutions regarding violence against women
<li>
Connect on a global level— create more international
awareness, engage in demonstrations, and mobilize collective action.
WHAT IS FSD?
The Foundation for Sustainable
Development (FSD) is a volunteer-based organization specializing in
international development and operations in Nicaragua, Bolivia, Argentina, Kenya, Uganda, and India.
FSD's volunteers are primarily
college students or recent graduates who focus their work in one of several areas,
including
<ul>
<li>
Health
<li>
Education
<li>
Community development
<li>
Women's empowerment
<li>
Human rights
• Micro-enterprise
<li>
Environment
The mission of FSD is to enhance
the capacity of international communities in hopes of improving health, social
issues, environmental and economic issues.
FSD, together with many indigenous
entrepreneurs, is trying to lessen a variety of environmental, social and
economic deficiencies that haunt global communities.
ABOUT ME
As a recent
University graduate, writer, and humanitarian, I have a wide array of skills I
can contribute to a non-profit organization. Throughout my university career I
developed a strong interest in community work, sustainable development,
political relations, women’s issues, human rights, and animal rights
advocacy.<span>  Considering my interests I
have decided to study law at Leeds University, focusing on human rights. My
studies don’t begin until September 2014 and in the meantime I would like to utilize
knowledge, volunteer experience, and passion for improving the lives of others
by providing social and legal assistance to disadvantaged Indian women. My
experience and knowledge has left me feeling very equipped to volunteer as an
intern with a non-profit organization.
BUDGET BREAKDOWN
A
total of $7,850 is needed to
cover all of my travel expenses and to ensure that I can safely and securely live
and work in India. This is what the funds will cover:
<ul><li>
Airfare: $1,600
<ul><li>
FSD Internship Cost: $4700
<ul><li>
Immunizations: $300
<ul><li>
Transportation within India: $250
<ul><li>
Miscellaneous Expenses (internet, phone, etc.): $300
<ul><li>
Indiegogo Fees / PayPal Fees / Perk Fulfillment: $700
THE PERKS (AKA WHAT YOU GET IN RETURN)
Anyone
who contributes $5 or more to this campaign will be able to follow my work by
gaining access to my weekly blog.  Here I will post writings, insights,
photographs, quotes, and more.
Contribute
more and you can receive beautiful photographs taken during my stay in India.
THE IMPACT
By
contributing to this campaign, you will give me the chance to visit Indian
schools and speak to young boys about gender sensitivity and work with teachers
to implement gender sensitivity education into the curriculum.
You will also
give me the opportunity to devote myself to the women of India and enable me to
provide support, counseling, and legal aid.
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
Tell everyone you know about my campaign: Share
using the Indiegogo share tools located below my video, click the
like"" button for my campaign, post on social networks such as Facebook
and Twitter, email people or share by word-of-mouth.
Keep contributing! Any excess funds I raise beyond the needed
amount will be given as a monetary donation to the organization that I
volunteer for. This means that once I’ve met my goal, you can still contribute
and make a difference!
Thank you for your generous support!!

Who are y'all?!

Before anything, I want to introduce myself and my church to the lovely audience reading this message. My name is Charlie Kim, a freshman in college at Rice University in Houston, TX (Go Owls!). Ever since I moved to Houston from South Korea, I have been attending an amazing church filled with loving brothers and sisters of Christ called KCPCH, or the Korean Central Presbyterian Church of Houston. Though I have been attending this church for over 13 years, this summer will mark the first mission trip in my long journey as a Christian. Personally, I feel that this is God's plan for me, and I'm excited to fulfill his calling and see what He has in store for me. We will be working with an organization called Mission of Hope and hope to make an impact during our stay in Haiti. I hope that you will join me and my church in our journey to make an impact in Haiti and any form of support whether through prayer or financial means are appreciated. 

Your Impact!

ALL and I mean every penny of the funding will go towards healthcare, education, orphan care, and church advancement for the Haitians. In Haiti, 96% of the population lacks basic health coverage, a blessing many of us take for granted. With your help, we will help provide over 40,000 Haitians with access to a healthcare clinic and provide about 10,000 patients with healthcare education. Speaking of education, over 55% of the Haitians are illiterate and only 5 in 100 children will graduate from high school. With your help, we will help educate over 3000 students on a daily basis while providing them with meals. With over 400,000 orphans in Haiti, we are helping to provide orphanages that will help the children of Haiti grow up with a normal childhood filled with loving caretakers and peers. Your help will allow the orphanage to continue providing the children with the care they deserve. Not only will YOU take a part in providing healthcare, education, and orphan care to the people of Haiti, you will change their whole life by providing them with the greatest gift of all: God's love. Your donations will help us to spread God's love and His words so that the Haitians will be able to openly worship God in their own church and have access to the Bible. No matter the amount, your donations will definitely have an impact!!

Prayer

Of course, even if you are not able to make donations, you can still help us out by praying for us! Thanks and God bless!! :)


","Who are y'all?!Before anything, I want to introduce myself and my church to the lovely audience reading this message. My name is Charlie Kim, a freshman in college at Rice University in Houston, TX (Go Owls!). Ever since I moved to Houston from South Korea, I have been attending an amazing church filled with loving brothers and sisters of Christ called KCPCH, or the Korean Central Presbyterian Church of Houston. Though I have been attending this church for over 13 years, this summer will mark the first mission trip in my long journey as a Christian. Personally, I feel that this is God's plan for me, and I'm excited to fulfill his calling and see what He has in store for me. We will be working with an organization called Mission of Hope and hope to make an impact during our stay in Haiti. I hope that you will join me and my church in our journey to make an impact in Haiti and any form of support whether through prayer or financial means are appreciated. Your Impact!ALL and I mean every penny of the funding will go towards healthcare, education, orphan care, and church advancement for the Haitians. In Haiti, 96% of the population lacks basic health coverage, a blessing many of us take for granted. With your help, we will help provide over 40,000 Haitians with access to a healthcare clinic and provide about 10,000 patients with healthcare education. Speaking of education, over 55% of the Haitians are illiterate and only 5 in 100 children will graduate from high school. With your help, we will help educate over 3000 students on a daily basis while providing them with meals. With over 400,000 orphans in Haiti, we are helping to provide orphanages that will help the children of Haiti grow up with a normal childhood filled with loving caretakers and peers. Your help will allow the orphanage to continue providing the children with the care they deserve. Not only will YOU take a part in providing healthcare, education, and orphan care to the people of Haiti, you will change their whole life by providing them with the greatest gift of all: God's love. Your donations will help us to spread God's love and His words so that the Haitians will be able to openly worship God in their own church and have access to the Bible. No matter the amount, your donations will definitely have an impact!!PrayerOf course, even if you are not able to make donations, you can still help us out by praying for us! Thanks and God bless!! :)",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Houston, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/haiti-needs-you/pica

What to expect in a package

These monthly capsules of the future are going to have a variety of awesome gear to help us in a number of ways:

  To help make our stand: it will include a clothing item like a shirt or hat. The more people who openly and proudly wear messages for a better future, and against the darker, more discriminatory one, the better.

  To help spread a culture of resistance: we plan to include digital music from progressive bands and art from ground-breaking artists.We plan to focus regularly on local artists, promoting and building the best and most positive of what is coming out.

  To spread the message: they will include two stickable/wearable items such as a temporary tattoos or stickers. One for you and one for a friend!

  To challenge ourselves: every package will have a challenge card. A challenge (or two) of a way to act for our future. Challenges such as making people feel welcome, wearing a safety pin, going to an event, sharing a progressive article online, reaching out to others … Each challenge will be something that is positive and helpful.

  To help connect with our community: packages will include news of upcoming events and ways to get involved. Whether it is numbers to call, educational gatherings, or planned demonstrations, we will provide means to act with others.

   And, of course, a mystery item. Items that run the gamut from the humorous to the serious, including voodoo trump dolls to protest flags to car license plate frames.

We are calling on people to Subscribe To Our Future. Back us with this project and help make a difference, Get your monthly activist kit, get a way to make a right-on-time, meaningful, and creative stand for our future. 

Right now, our future is in danger. We all know that we need more positivism, more light in opposition to the Trump-era darkness. We need to see more people welcoming others, and sharing their opposition, whether boldly or subtly.

Imagine, a package every month, sent to thousands across the country. Each package full of quality gear and information that gives us ways and ideas to fight for a better future. The monthly nature allows us to respond in a timely way to the constant insanity. We can get the gear and information we need, when we need it most!

Fun, varied, and timely materials that help people react against the key issues of the day will be empowering and help empower others to take their stand.

We will make donations and give money every month. This giving will be in line with getting the money needed to the right organizations and groups at the right time.

Our plan for themed boxes

Our plan is to provide progressive-minded materials to the broadest section of people in the domestic United States. Fun, varied, and timely materials that help people react against whatever may be coming. At this particular moment in the US, there is a broad segment of progressive-minded people who are desperate for a way to react against negativism with a positive, pro-active message. Among the larger mainstream of the US, there is large section of people who do not consider themselves liberal, or even politically-minded, who are also looking for ways to spread positivism.

The theme and contents of any particular months’ box will be based on the political situation at the time of planning. Another influence on the content may be upcoming events such as black history month, pride, or national days of protest.

We need backers. We are calling on people to Subscribe To Our Future!

We are a part of the broad segment of progressive-minded people who are desperate for a way to react against a dark future with a positive, pro-active message.

The more prevalent these positive messages are in everyday life, the more that people feel confident and a part of a community, pushing back feelings of isolation and despair and emboldening progressives to stand for what they believe is right. These packages will give us a means to act individually, or connect with others in order to better the world.

The theme and contents of each months’ box will be based on the political situation at the time of planning. Rapid and timely response to pivotal events is the goal. We aim to hound the negative, backwards actions of the Trump presidency.

 

 

 

Icons made by Freepik and Madebyoliver from www.flaticon.com is licensed by CC 3.0 BY

#YESOn3TransRightsMA
My name is Ryley Copans, my pronouns are they/them/theirs.

On Tuesday, November 6, 2018, Massachusetts is voting on Transgender Rights. Two years ago, the State House added gender identity to the list of protected classes in public accommodations law, but this November, these rights are at risk! This isn’t just about ‘bathrooms
column2: ’ public accommodations are about health care, jobs, housing, education, parks, restaurants, and so much more.

column1: To encourage people to VOTE YES ON 3, and support transgender rights in Massachusetts, community members and I are filming a short video featuring transgender people from MA, talking about what this ballot question means to them. This equally educational and personal video will be featured on social media, and we would also love to air it on t.v., at least via the news.
<h3>What We Need &amp
We are asking for support in any form possible.
Our primary needs include:
<ul>
• Funding toward transportation for filming
• Funding toward production and editing so that we may
-Rent equipment
-Compensate talent and labor.
<ul>
• We are also seeking donations of production equipment.
• Above all, we would greatly appreciate endorsements of our message by public figures in the form of a brief recorded statement expressing your support.

• We will complete filming by the end of August, and production by mid-September, at which point we can send final video prior to endorsement recordings, and we can edit your support into the video. Our goal is to have the video online by the end of September.
Perks for Our Contributors:
• TBD
The Impact
Vote yes on 3. Protect kids like me! -Olivia, trans girl, 6 years old.

Half-a-century ago, 16 Rabbis and one Reform Movement administrator came to St. Augustine at the request of Reverend Martin Luther King, Jr. On June 18, 1964 they were swept up in the largest mass arrest of Rabbis in US history. Justice Justice 1964 is part of the St. Augustine Jewish Historical Society, a group committed to the telling of the story of the roles played by Jews in the ""Oldest City's"" 450 year history. Let's all bring back to St. Augustine those among the 17 who are able so that they might retell their story, igniting a sense of national commitment to the ideals of the Prophet Amos (5:24), as often quoted by Dr. King, וְיִגַּל כַּמַּיִם, מִשְׁפָּט
column2:
וּצְדָקָה, כְּנַחַל אֵיתָן  Let Justice well up as the waters and righteousness like a mighty stream! 

The task before us requires $3600 to provide airfare, ground transportation and accommodations for those heroes who are able to join us.  Donors at appropriate levels will have an opportunity to meet and speak with these heroes at a special luncheon, a wine and cheese reception, to hold reserved seats at the forum on the eve of the 50th anniversary ceremony, to have names included in the event program.  All funds, whether our goal is reached or not, will be used to the benefit of our visiting heroes. 

Donors are partners in the effort to let the world know that silence is not an acceptable response to injustice and inhumane behavior wherever and whenever it takes place. The darkness that fell across Europe from 1933 through 1945 helps explain why we can never stand ""idly by the blood of our neighbors!"" 

This story of the support for human dignity is one of the most ""undertold"" episodes in the ongoing history of  Jewish involvement in the struggle for Civil Rights.  It is equally ""undertold"" within the saga of the St. Augustine Movement that ultimately led to the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. 

As an Internal Revenue Code Section 501 c 3 organization, reports detailing income and expenditures are available for public inspection in the St. Augustine Jewish Historical Society's IRS Form 990 available on line.  Participation, at any level, in this campaign elevates us all.  Tell your family, friends and neighbors!


“Some of the funding for this program was provided through a grant from the Florida Humanities Council with funds from the National Endowment for the Humanities. Any views, findings, conclusions or recommendations expressed in this program do not necessarily represent those of the Florida Humanities Council or the National Endowment for the Humanities.""

The visionary of this endeavor is Saadia White. Saadia White is a wife, mother and grandmother, but most of all, a Generational Survivor. She is an inspirational speaker and community activist with a mission of service.

Saadia White is no stranger to perseverance, courage and resilience. Her mission has always been to serve. From former law enforcement officer to today’s modern activist, she brings her words of encouragement and wisdom to the masses as the Amazine Amazon.
Out of pain, she birthed her PASSION!

By supporting this project, you support the publication of this book series, comic book series for children, discussion panels and clinical expertise along with community events centered on mental wellness.
The fundraising goal for the first phase of this campaign is $5,000.
Please help us spread the word for this effort in the following ways:
<ul>
• Follow us at https://www.facebook.com/generationalsurvivors/
• Visit http://www.amazineamazon.com/
• Share this campaign on your social media accounts and encourage friends to do the same
• Invite Saadia to speak at your next organization's or community's event

What is wheelchair sports Hull and why was it set up??


Wheelchair Sports Hull was set up June 2013 due to the need of extra funding needed to kick start and keep clubs going in the Hull and East Riding area. Every bit of money we earn goes back into sports teams or into projects that help the growth of wheelchair sports for example our ‘teach program’


One of our goals was to bring Hull and East Riding its disability sports awards awards. On Friday 21st February we made this happen with the help of our sponsors we got over 200 to attend the awards.


We also run projects to teach staff and learners about disability sports, we show that disability sports like wheelchair basketball is not just for people that have a disability but for everyone. We are set to launch our ‘teach, grow and learn about disability sports program’ in 2015 set for the paralympic games in 2016 .


The program helps teach people people with disabilities and without the importance of working in a team and that even if someone is disabled there can do much more than most people would think. We help people aged 8-60+ to help show what sport can do, after all sports does more than keep people fit. It improves people mental health and makes them think there are worth something.



How we work :


35% of our money that we raise goes back to sports clubs right away in some way.


35% goes into a fund that when a sports club needs a large amount of money for a reason for example a clubs clothes are damaged because of floods, the money is there for to help them out straight away.


30% goes into our school project program where we go into school and teach about disability sports. School project page will be coming very soon.


No funds are ever paid out to wages, as everyone that works for us does so by putting in there hours for free.

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><h2 style=""text-align: center
column2:
>Block: The Story

After realizing she's gay, Kit O'Brien is soon accompanied by a not-so-friendly sidekick named BLOCK- which just so happens to take the form of a literal 30 pound cement cinder block.

Invisible to everyone else but her, Kit realizes that the only way to shake this burden is to face her fears - She's gotta come out. What starts off as a fight to show her true colors to the world, turns into a remarkable journey of release, acceptance, and celebration.
column3: >Why are We Telling This Story?
column5:
>(Let's Be Real:  Why Are We Telling a Story About a Cinder Block)

First off, yes... We realize that casting a cinder block as one of the main characters in a film sounds a bit insane. (Don't worry though, all cast members were paid equally.) But the truth is, no matter where you come from or what your background is, everyone has their own BLOCK. By making this movie, we aim to put a face to each of our unique struggles, spark a conversation, and simply remind others that love starts with yourself. Some of the hardest fought battles are those that happen within our own heads. By loving, accepting, and celebrating who we are (and where we are in our journeys), we can start to rid ourselves of our personal blocks.

BLOCK is a unique LGBTQ+ story, depicting the search for self acceptance without the typical narrative that involves two people falling in love. It’s a film that advocates for an open dialogue surrounding the greater topic of mental health. It’s a look into the intimate relationship of two sisters, and how they find themselves, as they help and support each other. It’s a love story, about loving and accepting yourself just as you are.

Not everyone in our film cast and crew is gay. We have different backgrounds, experiences, opinions, and upbringings. But we’ve all come together because we all can relate to the film’s universal message.
column6:
>We Need Your Help...

In order to film the rest of this movie, we need your help. The value you add to this project by contributing monetary donations is astronomical. To put it straight- we couldn’t do it without you! By backing BLOCK, you are supporting advocacy. You’re supporting mental health. You’re supporting independent filmmakers and the arts. Every last cent goes towards carrying out our mission to spread a positive message and shed some light in the world. We can’t say it enough, thank you!

To break it down for you, this is where your contribution goes towards:

column1: • Professional crews (DP, Gaffer, AC, Key Grip, ect.)
• Location rentals
• Production Insurance
• Costumes
• Makeup
• Props
• Equipment rentals
• Food for the cast and crew

column4: >Carrie Brennan - Writer, Producer, Cast
column5: >Carrie Brennan is a New York-based actor and writer who is passionate about LGBTQ+ film and writing. After living and learning through her own coming out experience, Carrie wrote the film BLOCK while attending Playhouse West Acting School and investing in Tony Savant’s screenwriting course. Carrie  is most excited about getting to work alongside such talented and ambitious actors and collaborators.
column7: >Monica O'Hara - Producer, Promo Video Director
column10: '>Monica O’Hara is a New York based filmmaker. Working as a producer for the film, Monica believes in the personal truth behind the script.
column12: >Alex Krumpholz - Producer, Production Coordinator, Marketing
column13: >As social media aficionado and marketing specialist, Alex uses her skills to foster her passions: promoting mental health awareness and decreasing the stigma surrounding taboo, diverse ideas and experiences. She is working with our team as a Production Coordinator and Social Media Manager!
column16: >Victoria Ratermanis is an actor, writer, and director. She likes to focus her attention towards stories that seek to reach universal audiences by sharing the personal elements of one’s mind and heart. She is exceedingly proud of the truth and soul behind this story and is excited to have the honor of playing Abbi.
column19: >Carly is a Philadelphia based actor who has been studying acting at Playhouse West Philadelphia since 2014.  She has appeared in several independent short films including Contrition and The Reckoning.  She has also co-starred in and co-written two short films Corn Chip Feet, for which she was nominated for a Grand Jury award for best supporting actress at the 2017 Playhouse West Philadelphia Film Festival and Hot Mess Buns for which she won the audience choice award for Best Actress in a comedy at the 2018 Playhouse West Philadelphia Film Festival.
column22:
>Social worker by day and creative any time she can get away, Amanda strives to attract others by the way she lives. Amanda brings an energy to projects that leave people wondering whether or not she is s working or if she is playing. Nothing energizes Amanda than performing, connecting, and inspiring others. She is working with this wonderful team as one of their Production Assistants!

WHO WE ARECarrie Brennan - Writer, Producer, Cast Carrie Brennan is a New York-based actor and writer who is passionate about LGBTQ+ film and writing. After living and learning through her own coming out experience, Carrie wrote the film BLOCK while attending Playhouse West Acting School and investing in Tony Savant’s screenwriting course. Carrie  is most excited about getting to work alongside such talented and ambitious actors and collaborators.Monica O'Hara - Producer, Promo Video DirectorMonica O’Hara is a New York based filmmaker. Working as a producer for the film, Monica believes in the personal truth behind the script. Alex Krumpholz - Producer, Production Coordinator, MarketingAs social media aficionado and marketing specialist, Alex uses her skills to foster her passions: promoting mental health awareness and decreasing the stigma surrounding taboo, diverse ideas and experiences. She is working with our team as a Production Coordinator and Social Media Manager!Victoria Ratermanis - Cast Victoria Ratermanis is an actor, writer, and director. She likes to focus her attention towards stories that seek to reach universal audiences by sharing the personal elements of one’s mind and heart. She is exceedingly proud of the truth and soul behind this story and is excited to have the honor of playing Abbi.Carly Mazzochetti - Cast Carly is a Philadelphia based actor who has been studying acting at Playhouse West Philadelphia since 2014.  She has appeared in several independent short films including Contrition and The Reckoning.  She has also co-starred in and co-written two short films Corn Chip Feet, for which she was nominated for a Grand Jury award for best supporting actress at the 2017 Playhouse West Philadelphia Film Festival and Hot Mess Buns for which she won the audience choice award for Best Actress in a comedy at the 2018 Playhouse West Philadelphia Film Festival.Amanda Mazzone - Production AssistantSocial worker by day and creative any time she can get away, Amanda strives to attract others by the way she lives. Amanda brings an energy to projects that leave people wondering whether or not she is s working or if she is playing. Nothing energizes Amanda than performing, connecting, and inspiring others. She is working with this wonderful team as one of their Production Assistants!",6.0,0,"1 Campaign

Nous sommes une organisation de solidarité fondée en 1976 qui travaille à la défense et à la promotion des droits humains en réciprocité avec les mouvements sociaux et les communautés d’Amérique latine dans la lutte en faveur d’une justice sociale, environnementale, économique et culturelle.

Les actions urgentes constituent le pilier de notre travail et c’est à travers celles-ci que nous entretenons des liens de réciprocité avec les mouvements sociaux et les groupes de base en Amérique latine. Le CDHAL effectue un suivi de l’actualité d’Amérique latine et la diffuse au Québec et au Canada, reçoit des demandes d’appuis des communautés et des mouvements sociaux, participe à de nombreuses campagnes de dénonciation, et rédige et traduit des communiqués, déclarations et pétitions ayant pour objectif de faire pression pour des cas particuliers et de contribuer à l’éducation du public.

Les actions urgentes appuient nos allié.e.s d’Amérique latine en dénonçant auprès des gouvernements latino-américains et canadien des situations d’oppression, de répression et de violations des droits humains qui réfèrent au droit à la vie et à un environnement sain, à l’autodétermination, à l’intégrité, à la sécurité et à la liberté des personnes ou groupes, au droit de se défendre, ainsi qu’à la criminalisation de la protestation sociale.

Cette campagne vise à appuyer le dossier des actions urgentes du CDHAL, c'est-à-dire le suivi rigoureux des actions en cours, mais également à alimenter et approfondir la compréhension et l’analyse des enjeux sociaux, politiques et environnementaux auxquels nous nous intéressons à travers nos liens avec les mouvements sociaux latino-américains et les communautés affectées par les projets extractifs et des organisations alliées en Amérique latine.

Le CDHAL est en lien avec une quinzaine de mouvements sociaux et groupes de base en Amérique latine, spécifiquement au Mexique, Guatemala, Honduras, Salvador, Colombie, Équateur, Brésil et Chili. Nous sommes particulièrement interpellées par la situation de défenseur-e-s des droits humains. Nous avons récemment contribué à des actions urgentes en solidarité avec les communautés paysannes et Shuar affectées par la militarisation de leur territoire en Équateur, avec des communautés mapuche au Chili en lutte contre l’implantation de projets hydroélectriques, et avec plusieurs défenseur.e.s des droits humains et groupes ayant subi des actes d’intimidation, de menaces et d’attaques ciblées (entre autres, le COPINH au Honduras, Bios Iguana au Mexique, CALAS en Guatemala, Rios Vivos et le Comité environnemental de défense de la vie de Tolima en Colombie).

L’équipe des actions urgentes, coordonnée par une responsable et composée de stagiaires de différents programmes universitaires et de militant.e.s, est mobilisée toute l’année afin de traduire de nombreux documents et des nouvelles des partenaires avec lesquels nous travaillons pour rendre ces informations accessibles pour le public québécois et canadien à travers le bulletin Solidared (écrit et audio), en français et en espagnol, et aussi via notre site Internet et notre page Facebook.

Récemment, l’équipe a cherché à innover et à diversifier ses outils de communications en élaborant une version audio du bulletin mensuel Solidared : voix de résistances dans les Amériques, grâce à une formation donnée à l’équipe par deux stagiaires provenant de l'Association latino-américaine d'éducation radiophonique (ALER). 

L’information partagée à travers ce bulletin provient de différents mouvements, organisations sociales et groupes de base qui travaillent pour la justice sociale et environnementale à travers le continent. Elle constitue donc des nouvelles de première source, qui ne sont pas diffusées par les grands médias. 

L’appui à ce projet permettra de poursuivre notre travail quotidien de veille et de diffusion des violations des droits humains à travers les Amériques et de répondre de manière ponctuelle aux différents appels de solidarité. Les raisons sont nombreuses pour continuer à lutter et à dénoncer puisque chaque jour, des populations des Amériques résistent devant un modèle qui privilégie les intérêts privés et transnationaux au détriment des communautés locales.

Concrètement, les fonds amassés contribueront au salaire de la responsable des actions urgentes et aux frais liés à la réalisation d'actions urgentes, ainsi qu'aux communications avec les mouvements sociaux. 

Dans le cadre de cette campagne de financement, vous pourrez vous procurez, en contrepartie d'un don, un billet pour participer à notre soirée festive, qui aura lieu le 17 novembre, à 19h00, à l’Espace Day &
column2:
Night, à Montréal, où sera lancée la prochaine édition de la revue Caminando qui porte sur les moyens de communications communautaires et alternatifs. Ceux-ci offrent des espaces de diffusion libre, de transmission d’information sur les luttes sociales, de participation et d’empowerment, de multiplication des voix, de critiques et de construction conjointe d’analyses. Un don au CDHAL pourrait aussi vous permettre d'obtenir en contrepartie une copie de la revue. Veuillez consulter les contreparties. 

Merci à l'avance pour votre appui! Tous les dons, même les plus petits font une réelle différence pour notre équipe et notre travail de solidarité avec les mouvements sociaux en Amérique latine. 

Aidez-nous à diffuser largement la campagne dans vos réseaux!
