Bangladesh Delegation Proposal and Fundraising Appeal
United Students Against Sweatshops
Bangladesh Delegation August 14-24th 2013

On April 24th, 2013 an eight-story building called Rana Plaza in Dhaka, Bangladesh collapsed claiming the lives of over 1,100 garment workers who produced clothing for US and European multi- billion dollar brands. This garment industrial disaster was the largest in history and claimed the lives of some of the most exploited workers in this world, most of them young women my own age. This tragedy happened on the heals of a victory against Adidas, where Indonesian workers from an illegally shut down factory, PT Kizone, fought and won their $1.8 million in severance pay that they were legally owned. United Students Against Sweatshops (USAS) fought in solidarity demanding that our Universities cut contracts with Adidas due to these and other labor rights violation in order to pressure Adidas to respect workers rights. I was part of the struggle at Brown University to sever our contract with Adidas and with Brown Student Labor Alliance, a USAS affiliate, we successfully got the University to non-renew business with Adidas over labor rights violation. It was a bittersweet moment when days-later a thousand lives were taken by sweatshop conditions.

USAS is sending a delegation of seven students, myself included to Bangladesh with the goal of eradicating the death trap factory conditions in the Bangladesh garment industry, while building strong, sustainable unions of workers. USAS is the largest youth led solidarity network in the nation with 150 affiliated campus groups. We use the unique leverage of our Universities lucrative contracts with brands to pressure corporations to improve wages, working conditions and respect for basic workers rights on the garment factory floor. We are doing this delegation in recognition that this is a historic opportunity for change in Bangladesh. The Rana Plaza factory collapse is the biggest tragedy along a trend of fire-safety violation related tragedies in Bangladesh. Not only do Bangladeshi workers receive a poverty wage rate of $37 a month to produce apparel for multinational brands like Wal-Mart, the Children’s Place, and Joe Fresh, but since 2005, over 1,800 garment workers have died in factory fires and building collapses in Bangladesh alone. These tragedies are often preventable with workers aware of danger often reporting the conditions to management but are then threatened with withholding wages or being fired for speaking up. Multinational brands pressure factory owners to produce more apparel faster for very little money, forcing them to cut corners in safety and conditions.

But workers are fighting back and demanding that brands sign on to the Accord on Fire and Building Safety in Bangladesh. This binding agreement between multinational brands and unions requires independent safety inspections with public reports, mandatory repairs and renovations, the obligation by brands and retailers to underwrite the costs and to terminate business with any factory that refuses to make necessary safety upgrades, and a vital role for workers and their unions. More so, the National Garment Worker Federation in Bangladesh organized a sit in by 200 orphans of the Rana Plaza Factory collapse calling on brands to take monetary responsibility over the deaths from the factory collapse and demanding brands sign onto the Accord. On our delegation we will meet with these organizers and think through ways we, students and workers in the US, can organize in solidarity. This delegation will help us build the case to force brands like Wal-mart and GAP to sign on to the Accord.

Upon returning from our delegation we will produce materials for political education, including worker interviews, wage analysis, and reports of working conditions. These materials will be available for our broader USAS network to utilize in our fight for brand responsibility here on our front and to motivate students in the US to fight along side of the workers that are demanding better working conditions and who live the exploitative reality.  After the delegation, myself and the other delegates will be organizing report-backs and we will be available for interviews or presentation.

I appreciate the support that you have already shown me, the anti-sweatshop movement, USAS, and I hope you strongly consider this proposal for funding the delegation to Bangladesh. I am asking for donations to support me going on this delegation, which includes the cost of flights, housing, food, and visa expenses. Please don’t hesitate to contact me, Mariela Martinez, USAS Collective Liberation Chair and Delegate at 323-404-6878 or mariela_martinez@brown.edu.
Si se puede,
Mariela Martinez
","Bangladesh Delegation Proposal and Fundraising Appeal
United Students Against Sweatshops
Bangladesh Delegation August 14-24th 2013

On April 24th, 2013 an eight-story building called Rana Plaza in Dhaka, Bangladesh collapsed claiming the lives of over 1,100 garment workers who produced clothing for US and European multi- billion dollar brands. This garment industrial disaster was the largest in history and claimed the lives of some of the most exploited workers in this world, most of them young women my own age. This tragedy happened on the heals of a victory against Adidas, where Indonesian workers from an illegally shut down factory, PT Kizone, fought and won their $1.8 million in severance pay that they were legally owned. United Students Against Sweatshops (USAS) fought in solidarity demanding that our Universities cut contracts with Adidas due to these and other labor rights violation in order to pressure Adidas to respect workers rights. I was part of the struggle at Brown University to sever our contract with Adidas and with Brown Student Labor Alliance, a USAS affiliate, we successfully got the University to non-renew business with Adidas over labor rights violation. It was a bittersweet moment when days-later a thousand lives were taken by sweatshop conditions.

USAS is sending a delegation of seven students, myself included to Bangladesh with the goal of eradicating the death trap factory conditions in the Bangladesh garment industry, while building strong, sustainable unions of workers. These tragedies are often preventable with workers aware of danger often reporting the conditions to management but are then threatened with withholding wages or being fired for speaking up. Multinational brands pressure factory owners to produce more apparel faster for very little money, forcing them to cut corners in safety and conditions.

But workers are fighting back and demanding that brands sign on to the Accord on Fire and Building Safety in Bangladesh. This binding agreement between multinational brands and unions requires independent safety inspections with public reports, mandatory repairs and renovations, the obligation by brands and retailers to underwrite the costs and to terminate business with any factory that refuses to make necessary safety upgrades, and a vital role for workers and their unions. More so, the National Garment Worker Federation in Bangladesh organized a sit in by 200 orphans of the Rana Plaza Factory collapse calling on brands to take monetary responsibility over the deaths from the factory collapse and demanding brands sign onto the Accord. On our delegation we will meet with these organizers and think through ways we, students and workers in the US, can organize in solidarity. This delegation will help us build the case to force brands like Wal-mart and GAP to sign on to the Accord.

Upon returning from our delegation we will produce materials for political education, including worker interviews, wage analysis, and reports of working conditions. These materials will be available for our broader USAS network to utilize in our fight for brand responsibility here on our front and to motivate students in the US to fight along side of the workers that are demanding better working conditions and who live the exploitative reality.  After the delegation, myself and the other delegates will be organizing report-backs and we will be available for interviews or presentation.

I appreciate the support that you have already shown me, the anti-sweatshop movement, USAS, and I hope you strongly consider this proposal for funding the delegation to Bangladesh. I am asking for donations to support me going on this delegation, which includes the cost of flights, housing, food, and visa expenses. I'm Huda from Gaza. The war on Gaza in 2014 left me homeless. I wish you could help me to get our house reconstructed.
It's difficult to describe the harsh conditions we the inhabitants of Gaza live. The continuous made it worse.
This tough situation makes me tired of hardly all this at my young age.
As it's winter time I can't granted a warm place. A healthy food even a warm clothes.
I'm launching this campaign and looking forward that you will help for this situation I live to make it easier and get our house rebuilt.
I make this list which include  all requirements I need to rebuild my house

- Cement and blocks     1600$
 - Concrete                      2000$
 - Ceramic and tiles         1000$
-  Kitchen and baths        1300$
I seek people who respect peace, humanity, childhood and charity to give me a chance to see my family happy again, to live and educate in stable situation not as homeless.

You can help by :
- Contribute 
- Spread worldwide by your social media
- Praying for us
Please help because your donation will make a difference.

A Short Summary
• Hello, my name is Sonja!

• Having volunteered since I graduated to gain experience and exposure to work within child protection, criminal law and clinical settings, My research and passion to fight for the welfare of children, has enabled me to be accepted to pursue my PhD Project.

• Through the Child Maltreatment and Child Wellbeing Project,  I aim to update and extend the current evidence on child abuse and child death in order to directly benefit victims within legal settings by comparing evidence from the UK, Australia and USA.
<li>So Why do people abuse children? --- &gt
column2: My research into the similarities and differences between cases like Baby P, Jimmy Savile, (etc), in different countries may uncover clues to preventing abuse.

column1: • This international comparison has never been done before and is essential if I am to directly improve and challenge current policies, in order to reduce the number of victims of child abuse and child death, and gain justice for those who have suffered.
• I have known women and men who have suffered personally, but have not gained justice or the support they deserve, due to current policies and this needs to change.
• The money you donate is essential for this project to commence it will not only help children now but will impact on their futures and future generations.
What's Needed &

• In order to gain unique access to multiple research facilities within the UK, Australia and America,  which will provide me with the academic resources, official documentation on current child abuse cases and relevant government policies, I am asking for a sum of £200,000.

• This money will provide me with the first building block which is essential for this project to start, only then will I have the opportunity to change policies and improve the wellbeing of children.
• Being accepted to pursue a personal PhD project is very rare so this is a unique opportunity that won't come round again.

• I have spent time gaining the specific knowledge and experience to enable the evidence I gather to be analysed efficiently. I can use the research I gather to implement changes and gain justice as soon as possible. --- The longer it takes for this research to occur, the more children will suffer and not only will they not get the support they need at the time and beyond but also justice they need and deserve.

• This will be ground-breaking and a chance to help protect children both through education and at home, as well as provide the latest evidence and research to the government and police forces to push for changes in current policies. WITHOUT THE EVIDENCE .... NO CHANGES CAN OCCUR!

    • The Impact your donation will have:
• Your donations, however big or small, will all contribute.
• They will enable me to gain access, collect and analyse current literature, interviews, court and police transcripts --- which is essential if any changes are to occur.
• You are the first building block and without this fund the project will take years if not longer to start, in which time more children will suffer and die.
• If I am unable to raise the full amount for this project to commence then I will of course donate the money that I do raise to charities who help protect children, such as the NSPCC.
• I have a 'can-do' attitude and I won't give up until changes are made to protect and reduce child abuse and death within the UK and across the world.

• With the evidence and research, I aim to attend conferences and public arenas to raise awareness of current issues AND provide new initiatives and policies which must be implemented to put an end to child maltreatment and promote child wellbeing.
<li><font size=""5""><span style=""line-height: 30px
<li><span style=""font-size: 24px
<li>Challenge One: Finding the finance is the main challenge for this project---- &gt
column2: I need YOUR HELP to make this happen.

column1: • Challenge Two: Raising awareness about my project, as well as awareness around the issue of child abuse and child death. A highly sensitive issue, it needs to be handled with care.

• My relentless attitude, hard working nature and problem solving abilities has provided me with this opportunity and I won't let it slip me by until I have explored every avenue and no stone is left unturned. 

    • Other Ways You Can Help

• If you cannot provide funds then please please spread the word about this project, whether that be when you are at work, or on the bus, or if you could link it on you social media websites - using the Indiegogo share tools.

• Without the money this project WONT happen but the MORE people know about it the higher the chances I will have of raising this money and pursuing the Child Maltreatment and Child Wellbeing Project.
• Thank you for taking the time to read this and please do all you can to help this project become a reality.
","A Short Summary
Hello, my name is Sonja!

Having volunteered since I graduated to gain experience and exposure to work within child protection, criminal law and clinical settings, My research and passion to fight for the welfare of children, has enabled me to be accepted to pursue my PhD Project.

Through the Child Maltreatment and Child Wellbeing Project,  I aim to update and extend the current evidence on child abuse and child death in order to directly benefit victims within legal settings by comparing evidence from the UK, Australia and USA.
So Why do people abuse children? --- > My research into the similarities and differences between cases like Baby P, Jimmy Savile, (etc), in different countries may uncover clues to preventing abuse.

This international comparison has never been done before and is essential if I am to directly improve and challenge current policies, in order to reduce the number of victims of child abuse and child death, and gain justice for those who have suffered.
I have known women and men who have suffered personally, but have not gained justice or the support they deserve, due to current policies and this needs to change.
The money you donate is essential for this project to commence it will not only help children now but will impact on their futures and future generations.
What's Needed & What You Get:

In order to gain unique access to multiple research facilities within the UK, Australia and America,  which will provide me with the academic resources, official documentation on current child abuse cases and relevant government policies, I am asking for a sum of £200,000.
This money will provide me with the first building block which is essential for this project to start, only then will I have the opportunity to change policies and improve the wellbeing of children.
Being accepted to pursue a personal PhD project is very rare so this is a unique opportunity that won't come round again.

I have spent time gaining the specific knowledge and experience to enable the evidence I gather to be analysed efficiently. I can use the research I gather to implement changes and gain justice as soon as possible. --- The longer it takes for this research to occur, the more children will suffer and not only will they not get the support they need at the time and beyond but also justice they need and deserve.

This will be ground-breaking and a chance to help protect children both through education and at home, as well as provide the latest evidence and research to the government and police forces to push for changes in current policies. WITHOUT THE EVIDENCE .... NO CHANGES CAN OCCUR!   The Impact your donation will have:
Your donations, however big or small, will all contribute.
They will enable me to gain access, collect and analyse current literature, interviews, court and police transcripts --- which is essential if any changes are to occur.
You are the first building block and without this fund the project will take years if not longer to start, in which time more children will suffer and die.
If I am unable to raise the full amount for this project to commence then I will of course donate the money that I do raise to charities who help protect children, such as the NSPCC.
I have a 'can-do' attitude and I won't give up until changes are made to protect and reduce child abuse and death within the UK and across the world.

With the evidence and research, I aim to attend conferences and public arenas to raise awareness of current issues AND provide new initiatives and policies which must be implemented to put an end to child maltreatment and promote child wellbeing.
Risks & Challenges
Challenge One: Finding the finance is the main challenge for this project---- >  I need YOUR HELP to make this happen.
Challenge Two: Raising awareness about my project, as well as awareness around the issue of child abuse and child death. A highly sensitive issue, it needs to be handled with care.

My relentless attitude, hard working nature and problem solving abilities has provided me with this opportunity and I won't let it slip me by until I have explored every avenue and no stone is left unturned.    Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot provide funds then please please spread the word about this project, whether that be when you are at work, or on the bus, or if you could link it on you social media websites - using the Indiegogo share tools.
Without the money this project WONT happen but the MORE people know about it the higher the chances I will have of raising this money and pursuing the Child Maltreatment and Child Wellbeing Project.
Thank you for taking the time to read this and please do all you can to help this project become a reality.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

Dear family and friends,

I’m very encouraged as I write this letter to you. The Lord has been doing tremendous things through our family. We have been overwhelmingly blessed in so many ways, not the least of which included the arrival of our little man Max this past February.

Over the past several years God has impressed upon me a heart for a certain part of the world. I was in Africa for a short term mission trip over
5 years ago, and my heart has longed to go back ever since. In the time since
then I have cultivated relationships with different missionaries that are there
full time, learned about and invested in their ministries, and have been
praying and brainstorming about ways that I can partner with and support them.

My plan is to take another short term trip this January, which God willing will be the
first of many. The purpose of this trip is to learn from my friends and
partners in the country, identify areas of need and ways that God can use me to
support these ministries over the long term.

My trip will take me to Guinnea Bissau, West Africa where I will be
staying with a family that I have built a tremendous relationship with over the
last several years. They are Youth For Christ missionaries and are the
directors of a youth center in this impoverished forgotten corner of the world.
They have done tremendous work here and have been key drivers in establishing
an English School, as well as a computer and technology school.They’re teaching
the people of Guinnea Bissua trades and in demand skills, enabling them to be
industrious, “teaching them how to fish.” The have a machine shop and have also
completed projects using solar and other forms of alternative energy. I can’t
wait to see what the Lord reveals while I am there.

My favorite part about these projects, is that they are all “kingdom building” - systemic
justice -type works. Working with people to equip and enable them to provide
for their families and their communities in a sustainable manner
column2:
all while
overwhelming them with love and sharing with them the hope found in the gospel.
The Lord works in tremendous ways through the powers of prayer and partnership.
Only God knows what fruit this time may bear, but I do know that with prayer
warriors and financial partners in my corner, God will bless this time
tremendously. I’ve sent this letter to you because you are someone who has been
a blessing in my life over the years and so I’m reaching out for your continued
love and support. Included in this envelope is a card explaining how you can
partner with me, to do kingdom work and take the Gospel to the world.

column1: Thank you much for taking the time to read this and I love you all.
God Bless,

Brandon
Marken
Ways to Partner:
1. Pray! Pray and Pray some more!
2. Support Financially

a. 
By mail: 3125 lorrie drive Spring Arbor, Mi
49283

b. online via campaign

Short Summary

We are working with the protestors of Capitol Hill, Seattle to create a safe and sustainable environment for them to protest for Black lives and BIPOC. This movement has gained national media attention and is setting a precedent for occupy protests around the country.

We are raising funds to help sustain this for as long as it lasts. The funds raised will be providing shelter, medical care, mental health services, food and water, as well as countless of other opportunities to people who might not necessarily afford these. There were days where we were on the front lines treating people who had been tear gassed and shot, and we need to prepare for this to be a possibility for upcoming weeks, if not months. It takes a village to make a city safe, so support us in our fight.
<h3>What We Need &amp

We are doing this fundraiser without perks because we fully believe that you shouldn't need a deal-sweetener to make a difference in somebody's life. The funds we raise will be going to supplies for different stations, these include: medical, cooking, coffee, security, transportation, and more. You would be helping us get supplies akin to the following:
<ul>
• Medical supplies (such as blood pressure cuffs, glucose strips, trauma supplies, etc.)
• Blankets, pillows, sleeping bags, and tents for those without shelter
• Handmade sink units for keeping us clean
• Hand sanitizer
• Trash bins
• Canopies
• Folding tables and chairs
• Containers to hold supplies in
Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, you can still share! COVID-19 has put a lot of us out of a job and the reason we're asking for financial help is because we can't afford it ourselves. With your donation or your share, you can help make a difference on hundreds of thousands of lives.

The police of a certain town in south Louisiana are interpreting a law titled ""Weapons-Carrying Concealed"" to mean that all forms of carry are banned except concealed carry with a permit.

The ordinance is as follows,

Sec. 18-10. Weapons-Carrying concealed.

Whoever shall carry within the corporate limits of the city,

a weapon or weapons concealed on or about the person, such as

pistols, bowie knives, dirks, razors, or any other dangerous

weapons, shall on conviction thereof, suffer fine or imprisonment, the fine not to be less than fifty dollars ($50.00),

nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), and imprisonment not to be less than ten (10) days nor more than

thirty (30) days, or both such fine and imprisonment at the

discretion of the city judge, provided that the provisions of

this section shall not apply to sheriffs, and their deputies,

constables, city police officers and the city marshal, when in

the actual discharge of their official duties. (Ord. No. 1, §

1,1-19-23)

I was arrested for supposedly violating this ordinance on May 4 2015 and I am seeking funds for legal defense.

I will not state the name of the town in this post but a Google search of the ordinance will show what town it is.

Help me tell police that they are law enforcement officers and cannot interpret the law however they choose.

Thank you all for any help and God Bless the U.S.A.

Some of the ladies of Local Women's Handicrafts

When Nasreen Sheikh was a 12 year old girl she did something no girl in her village had ever done before. She fled the poor farming village where she was born and traveled far away to Nepal's capital, Kathmandu.
Nasreen at about 12 years

Her adult brother was based in Kathmandu and agreed to support Nasreen so she could escape the inevitable plight of a rural village girl: a forced arranged marriage to an older man, no education, domestic servitude and quite possibly violence at the hands of her spouse.
Nasreen's Dream

Her dream was to educate herself out of poverty and to decide her own destiny. Not long after arriving in Kathmandu Nasreen's brother became unable to support her and decided to send her back to village.
She yearned for an education, but was contemplating an inevitable return to the village where the cycle of poverty would continue.

She saw an American expat walking his dog in Kathmandu and, out of desperation, approached him and shared her plight. He agreed to help her stay in Kathmandu and since then he has helped her to learn a wide range of subjects including English, maths and philosophy.
She started to think differently about a woman's role in the world and it inspired her to make a difference.
Although Nasreen worked in a 'sweat shop' in order to survive, she had much bigger plans.
At 14 she recruited seven women at the sweat shop to join her in a fair trade sewing business that she planned to start.

At 16 she founded Local Women's Handicrafts, a fair trade handicrafts business which has now trained and employed over 100 women from disadvantaged backgrounds: women who have escaped arranged marriages, violence and oppression and are trying to raise children on their own.
Escaping an arranged marriage
When Nasreen was 18 years old and had 20+ women working for her, her parents arranged for her to be married to a man from her village who she didn't know and was unlikely to meet before the marriage.

Marriage would have meant returning to her village and walking away from her business and her purpose. She refused and went into hiding and so far she has avoided being married (although was shunned by her village).
To help local girls, Nasreen and her sister Saheen also design, make and distribute free sanitary packs for local high school girls, including re-usable sanitary pads, underwear and soap.

Saheen visits local schools and teaches adolescent girls basic sanitation and how to use the pads. She also tries to break down the taboos about menstruation that exist in Nepal so that girls know it is perfectly natural and normal to have periods each month.
New sanitary packs for 35 girls
Initially the ladies working for Nasreen worked above the retail shop in Kathmandu but the landlord was unhappy about lower caste woman working there so Nasreen was forced to look for an alternative.

Kind-hearted customers came to the rescue via a crowdfunding campaign and a loan, enabling her to buy some land on the outskirts of Kathmandu and build a small brick structure for a work space. She still needed to rent a bamboo shack next door to fit everyone in.
The lease is nearly up on the rented shack and it cannot be renewed as the landlord plans to use it for himself.

Nasreen urgently needs help to complete the second floor of her building so that everyone can be under the one roof. It will give her the opportunity to employ more women as she currently has to turn needy women away.
For $15,000 AUD (approx $11,300 USD) Nasreen can complete the building to lock up and move everyone in.
(above photography by Julian Bound)
The unfinished second floor
Nasreen: “If I do not succeed I will shame my family and the people from my village will point to me as an example of what happens when a woman tries to move above her place”.
PLEASE JOIN WITH US TO HELP HER SUCCEED!
Some small handicrafts made by the ladies (photography by Julian Bound)
The shop in Kathmandu (photography by Julian Bound)
Whether you are in a position to donate or not, please share this campaign with your friends and family :)
","Some of the ladies of Local Women's Handicrafts

When Nasreen Sheikh was a 12 year old girl she did something no girl in her village had ever done before. She fled the poor farming village where she was born and traveled far away to Nepal's capital, Kathmandu.
Nasreen at about 12 years

Her adult brother was based in Kathmandu and agreed to support Nasreen so she could escape the inevitable plight of a rural village girl: a forced arranged marriage to an older man, no education, domestic servitude and quite possibly violence at the hands of her spouse.
Nasreen's Dream

Her dream was to educate herself out of poverty and to decide her own destiny. Not long after arriving in Kathmandu Nasreen's brother became unable to support her and decided to send her back to village.
She yearned for an education, but was contemplating an inevitable return to the village where the cycle of poverty would continue.

She saw an American expat walking his dog in Kathmandu and, out of desperation, approached him and shared her plight. He agreed to help her stay in Kathmandu and since then he has helped her to learn a wide range of subjects including English, maths and philosophy.
She started to think differently about a woman's role in the world and it inspired her to make a difference.
Although Nasreen worked in a 'sweat shop' in order to survive, she had much bigger plans.
At 14 she recruited seven women at the sweat shop to join her in a fair trade sewing business that she planned to start.

At 16 she founded Local Women's Handicrafts, a fair trade handicrafts business which has now trained and employed over 100 women from disadvantaged backgrounds: women who have escaped arranged marriages, violence and oppression and are trying to raise children on their own.
Escaping an arranged marriage
When Nasreen was 18 years old and had 20+ women working for her, her parents arranged for her to be married to a man from her village who she didn't know and was unlikely to meet before the marriage.

Marriage would have meant returning to her village and walking away from her business and her purpose. She refused and went into hiding and so far she has avoided being married (although was shunned by her village).
To help local girls, Nasreen and her sister Saheen also design, make and distribute free sanitary packs for local high school girls, including re-usable sanitary pads, underwear and soap.

Saheen visits local schools and teaches adolescent girls basic sanitation and how to use the pads. She also tries to break down the taboos about menstruation that exist in Nepal so that girls know it is perfectly natural and normal to have periods each month.
New sanitary packs for 35 girls
Initially the ladies working for Nasreen worked above the retail shop in Kathmandu but the landlord was unhappy about lower caste woman working there so Nasreen was forced to look for an alternative.

Kind-hearted customers came to the rescue via a crowdfunding campaign and a loan, enabling her to buy some land on the outskirts of Kathmandu and build a small brick structure for a work space. She still needed to rent a bamboo shack next door to fit everyone in.
The lease is nearly up on the rented shack and it cannot be renewed as the landlord plans to use it for himself.

Nasreen urgently needs help to complete the second floor of her building so that everyone can be under the one roof. It will give her the opportunity to employ more women as she currently has to turn needy women away.
For $15,000 AUD (approx $11,300 USD) Nasreen can complete the building to lock up and move everyone in.
(above photography by Julian Bound)
The unfinished second floor
Nasreen: “If I do not succeed I will shame my family and the people from my village will point to me as an example of what happens when a woman tries to move above her place”.

My name is Lumir Lapray and I am a French exchange Graduate Student at the Department of Sociology of the University of California, Los Angeles. I love reading, travelling, or enjoying a fine lunch with lots of French bread, mountains of American fried chicken, and friends from all over the world. Last summer, I participated in the Paris program of the incredible Humanity in Action Fellowship, which gathers young leaders from many different countries. After a whole month of meeting activists and debating ways to include marginalized people in the public debate and fight discrimination, we had to come up with an innovative ""Action Project"" to put our ideals into action. As a consequence, I decided to launch this campaign.

Je m'appelle Lumir Lapray, et je termine mon cursus de Sciences Po Lyon en échange au sein du Département de Sociologie de l'Université de Californie, Los Angeles (UCLA). J'aime lire, voyager et partager un repas fait de baguette française et poulet frit américain, entourée d'amis du monde entier ! L'été dernier, j'ai participé au programme de ""Humanity in Action, agir pour l'égalité"", à Paris. Avec des jeunes de plusieurs pays, j'ai eu l'immense chance de rencontrer de nombreux activistes et de débattre des heures durant sur les stratégies à adopter pour récréer un dialogue véritablement citoyen. A l'issue de ces rencontres, nous avons tous dû créer notre propre ""projet d'action"", afin de prouver notre engagement au quotidien contre la discrimination et l'exclusion. J'ai donc choisi de lancer cette campagne.
<ul><li>
<span style=""font-size: 24px

column1: <blockquote>
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column2: >J'ai décidé de nommer cette campagne ""Nous voulons toutes rester dignes !"", car je suis convaincue de la force de ce message. Nulle femme, quelle que soit son histoire personnelle, ne devrait lutter tous les mois pour acheter les produits, pourtant de base, dont elle a absolument besoin. Nulle femme ne devrait choisir entre se nourrir ou rester digne. Cependant, beaucoup sont confrontées à ce choix. Et c'est là que vous pouvez faire la différence ! En faisant un don sur cette plateforme, vous pouvez tous apporter votre soutien aux femmes et jeunes filles sans abris de Los Angeles. C'est l'occasion incroyable de contribuer de manière concrète et efficace à la vie de nombreuses personnes, le tout en quelques minutes ! Nous savons tous qu'aujourd'hui, grâce à l'Internet, les frontières sont constamment redessinées : il nous est possible de changer la vie des femmes et d'hommes que nous n'avons jamais rencontrés, mais dont l'histoire nous touche. Chacune de ces femmes, chacune de ces filles a une histoire émouvante. Et VOUS pouvez faire en sorte de les accompagner, à distance, certes, mais votre impact n'en sera pas moins fort.

column1: <h3><ul><li><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column4: >Where will your money go ? Où ira votre argent ?

column2: >I have described in the ""Perks"" how your money will be spent. ALL the funds will be used to buy feminine hygiene products, which will go to the Cardinal Manning Center of Skid Row. This latter is managed by the Society of St Vincent de Paul, an organization which provides a wide range of services to those living in the neighborhood, and has a global mission of promoting the dignity of the person and alleviating human suffering. Another part of this campaign will be happening from May 13th to May 30th at UCLA, where physical donations of feminine hygiene products will be collected in Haines Hall, room 254, monday to friday from 8 to 7 ! If you know anyone who is a student, member of staff or faculty there, please share this information with them !
column3: >J'ai détaillé, dans la colonne si contre, comment votre argent sera dépensé. TOUS les fonds serviront à acheter des produits d'hygiène féminine, qui seront ensuite déposés au ""Cardinal Manning Center"" . Celui-ci est géré par la Société de St Vincent de Paul, une association qui fournit de nombreux services aux sans abris
column4: > de Los Angeles. Sa mission est de promouvoir le droit des personnes à vivre dans la
column5: > dignité et de venir en aide aux plus démunis. En parallèle de cette campagne en ligne, j'ai aussi mis en place un lieu de dépôt sur le campus de UCLA, où les dons pourront être déposés dans Haines Hall, salle 254, du lundi au vendredi, de 7h à 19h ! Si vous connaissez quelqu'un qui étudie ou travaille sur ce campus

column1:
Thank you so much for your trust and support ! And don't forget to share with your families, friends, colleagues and neighbors ! 

Mille mercis de votre confiance et de votre soutien ! Et n'oubliez pas de partager avec votre famille, vos amis, vos collègues et vos voisins !

In solidarity, 

Lumir
","Hi folks ! Bonjour à tous !
Who am I ? Qui suis-je ?

My name is Lumir Lapray and I am a French exchange Graduate Student at the Department of Sociology of the University of California, Los Angeles. I love reading, travelling, or enjoying a fine lunch with lots of French bread, mountains of American fried chicken, and friends from all over the world. Last summer, I participated in the Paris program of the incredible Humanity in Action Fellowship, which gathers young leaders from many different countries. After a whole month of meeting activists and debating ways to include marginalized people in the public debate and fight discrimination, we had to come up with an innovative ""Action Project"" to put our ideals into action. As a consequence, I decided to launch this campaign.

Je m'appelle Lumir Lapray, et je termine mon cursus de Sciences Po Lyon en échange au sein du Département de Sociologie de l'Université de Californie, Los Angeles (UCLA). J'aime lire, voyager et partager un repas fait de baguette française et poulet frit américain, entourée d'amis du monde entier ! L'été dernier, j'ai participé au programme de ""Humanity in Action, agir pour l'égalité"", à Paris. Avec des jeunes de plusieurs pays, j'ai eu l'immense chance de rencontrer de nombreux activistes et de débattre des heures durant sur les stratégies à adopter pour récréer un dialogue véritablement citoyen. A l'issue de ces rencontres, nous avons tous dû créer notre propre ""projet d'action"", afin de prouver notre engagement au quotidien contre la discrimination et l'exclusion. J'ai donc choisi de lancer cette campagne.
What is this ? Qu'est-ce que c'est que cette campagne ?

I have created this campaign because what struck me most, upon my arrival in Los Angeles, is the incredible number of humans living in homelessness, in spaces yet neighbored by Hollywood or Beverly Hills. Los Angeles has the highest population of homeless people in the entire nation : according to the Institute for the Study of Homelessness and Poverty at the Weingart Center, an estimated 254,000 individuals experience homelessness in Los Angeles County during some part of the year and between 33% and 50% of them are women, most of them women of color. The challenges they face everyday are immense, as everything is harder to come by, even the most simple things. Feminine hygiene products are one of those : they are seldom donated, expensive and desperately needed. Observing this, I saw the opportunity of building my ""Action Project"" around this issue, for I so deeply believe that all women should have access to basic personal care products.

Si j'ai choisi de lancer cette campagne, c'est parce que ce qui m'a le plus marquée, dès mon arrivée à Los Angeles, c'est le nombre de personnes sans domicile fixe, pourtant à deux pas d'Hollywood et Beverly Hills. Los Angeles a la population de SDF la plus large de tous les Etats-Unis : selon une étude du Weinghart Center, l'on en dénombre quelques 254 000 tout au long de l'année et entre 33% et 50% de ces sans abris sont des femmes, le souvent plus noires et hispaniques. Les défis que relèvent chaque jour les femmes sans abris, pour qui chaque produit, même des plus basiques, parait hors d'atteinte, sont innombrables. Parmi eux, les produits d'hygiène féminine : rarement font-ils partis de la liste de dons reçus par les associations, alors même qu'ils sont très chers, et absolument nécessaires. Devant ce constat, j'ai donc pris contact avec une structure spécialisée dans l'accompagnement de sans abris, qui a accepté de s'unir à mon projet.
This is where you come in ! C'est là que vous intervenez !

I called this campaign ""We All Want Dignity, Period !"", because, to me, this is what it all comes down to. No woman, whatever her story, should have to struggle every month because she cannot afford the basic products she needs. She should never have to choose between staying well-fed or staying hygienic. But many do. This is where you can make a difference. By giving here, you can all contribute to help the women and girls on Skid Row maintain dignity at all times. I deeply believe that what is truly powerful about this action, is that you do not often find the opportunity of sharing regardless of one's race, religion, nationality, sexual orientation, etc. This is your chance to do something incredibly concrete and useful, and it will literally take 10 minutes of your time ! We all know the amazing impact that an online community, united around the same goals, has in today's world. YOU can be a game changer and make a major difference in the everyday lives of dozens of women and girls in our City of Angels.

J'ai décidé de nommer cette campagne ""Nous voulons toutes rester dignes !"", car je suis convaincue de la force de ce message. Nulle femme, quelle que soit son histoire personnelle, ne devrait lutter tous les mois pour acheter les produits, pourtant de base, dont elle a absolument besoin. Nulle femme ne devrait choisir entre se nourrir ou rester digne. Cependant, beaucoup sont confrontées à ce choix. Et c'est là que vous pouvez faire la différence ! En faisant un don sur cette plateforme, vous pouvez tous apporter votre soutien aux femmes et jeunes filles sans abris de Los Angeles. C'est l'occasion incroyable de contribuer de manière concrète et efficace à la vie de nombreuses personnes, le tout en quelques minutes ! Nous savons tous qu'aujourd'hui, grâce à l'Internet, les frontières sont constamment redessinées : il nous est possible de changer la vie des femmes et d'hommes que nous n'avons jamais rencontrés, mais dont l'histoire nous touche. Chacune de ces femmes, chacune de ces filles a une histoire émouvante. Et VOUS pouvez faire en sorte de les accompagner, à distance, certes, mais votre impact n'en sera pas moins fort.
Where will your money go ? Où ira votre argent ?

I have described in the ""Perks"" how your money will be spent. ALL the funds will be used to buy feminine hygiene products, which will go to the Cardinal Manning Center of Skid Row. This latter is managed by the Society of St Vincent de Paul, an organization which provides a wide range of services to those living in the neighborhood, and has a global mission of promoting the dignity of the person and alleviating human suffering. Another part of this campaign will be happening from May 13th to May 30th at UCLA, where physical donations of feminine hygiene products will be collected in Haines Hall, room 254, monday to friday from 8 to 7 ! If you know anyone who is a student, member of staff or faculty there, please share this information with them !J'ai détaillé, dans la colonne si contre, comment votre argent sera dépensé. TOUS les fonds serviront à acheter des produits d'hygiène féminine, qui seront ensuite déposés au ""Cardinal Manning Center"" . Celui-ci est géré par la Société de St Vincent de Paul, une association qui fournit de nombreux services aux sans abris de Los Angeles. Sa mission est de promouvoir le droit des personnes à vivre dans la dignité et de venir en aide aux plus démunis. En parallèle de cette campagne en ligne, j'ai aussi mis en place un lieu de dépôt sur le campus de UCLA, où les dons pourront être déposés dans Haines Hall, salle 254, du lundi au vendredi, de 7h à 19h ! Si vous connaissez quelqu'un qui étudie ou travaille sur ce campus, transmettez leur cette information !

Thank you so much for your trust and support ! And don't forget to share with your families, friends, colleagues and neighbors ! Mille mercis de votre confiance et de votre soutien ! Et n'oubliez pas de partager avec votre famille, vos amis, vos collègues et vos voisins !
In solidarity, Lumir",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

Short Summary

We are currently in the process of adopting two wonderful kids from the Democratic Republic of Congo.  We recently visited them and realized that their orphanage is lacking a wall which would vastly improve their standard of living, as well as the safety of all of the kids in care here!

Without this wall:
• The children are exposed to the neighboring village
• The smallest children are able to wander and leave the compound
• Neighbors enter the compound and disrupt the children during meals and school
• The children aren't able to freely play with toys that have been donated to the orphanage as they are often stolen by neighbors
• The neighbors dump garbage around the compound

What We Need 

It's as simple as building a wall!  The funds will be used to:
• Re-build the decayed wall - this has been quoted at $1,100.  Local workers and materials will be used.
• Remove some of the very dangerous components on the compound, including two open garbage pits and rusted steel bars that remain in the former foundation, approximately $400.
• Buy materials and have Local artists paint the interior of the wall with a beautiful mural, to really enhance the space for the children, approximately $300.
• Create a new space for garbage disposal, approximately $200.

The Impact

With this wall...
• The children are protected from the neighboring village
• The smallest children are safe within the compound
• The children have increased focus during school and privacy during mealtimes.
• The children can freely play with toys that have been donated to the orphanage, increasing cooperation and learning stimulation.
• The garbage is controlled within the compound, increasing hygiene.
• The children get the security of this beautifully painted wall!
Other Ways You Can Help
• Tell your friends and families about this campaign!
• And use the Indiegogo share tools for social media!

Short Summary

Hi, my name is Carolyn. I'm a 59 yr old mom/grandma/FT student trying to make a better life. My youngest child (24) has been in trouble with the law, he has had drug/alcohol issues. He just spent 2 1/2 yrs in prison (on a 15 yr sentence) for stealing $10 from a man while he was drunk. Randy is now clean and sober, has job, trying to do what is right but after 8 weeks out he is arrested on warrant for ""alledgedly"" trying to call his 4 yr old son on his mom's cell while he was in prison last August. In May 2011 he filed a case to get visitation, didn't go to court until Nov. Judge gave him 1 phone call a week with son. If he goes back to prison he loses parental rights, Karson gets adopted by step-father, my family will never see him again till he is 18 or more. Please help, a Public Defender cannot help this case, we need a good Atty. Even the Atty's have said it is a 'witch hunt'.
<div>
<h3>What We Need &amp
Break it down for folks in more detail:
They need $2500 down to even take the case. McKenzie Law Denise Sheldon Atty. Boise, Idaho. Many have quoted me $3500-6000 down.

I just got a PT job which hasn't started yet. I also drive school bus during school year. I'm going to have a BS in Criminal Justice in Sept. and want to go on to get an MSW (Master's in Social Work) to be a drug/alcohol counselor. I would like to eventually work with Vets w/PTSD. I have no extra money. School is Student loans.

My family means everything to me. No one is without mistakes in their lives, I am just trying to give Randy and Karson a fair chance at a future. I have never tried to do this before because I felt he made the mistake, now pay for it. This is just wrong. He was doing everything right and needs a chance to show he is clean and sober and loves his son.
Any amount will help, we are not giving up. His friends are going to have a Car Wash. We are trying anything. Please help, God Bless you all!
<div>
The Impact
The Atty told me if he goes to trial and the parole hearing without an Atty (not a PD) his chances of losing are 90% greater than if he has an Atty.

If he loses he will probably go back to prison for the remainder of the sentence which is 12 more years. His son will be 17 by then and Randy will be 37. I will be 71! In Idaho if he goes away that long he will lose parental rights, the son will get adopted by step-parent, and I lose any chance of Grandparent rights! After adoption in Idaho there are no Grandparent rights. Now I have a chance to sue to see my grandson.

The mother has tried to cut me and my family out of Karson's life since she got involved with the guy she married. Before that we were okay. I have bent over backward trying to do the right thing to see my grandson. Now I'm about to lose my son and grandson together. Please help this is unjust and unfair.
I don't have parents that can give me a free house and car. I just have me and my children and grandchildren. My firends help where they can.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
We have tried to get a Pro Bono Atty for the Family court case and for the Criminal Case to no Avail. We have tried that avenue for over a year for the Family court issues.

Please if you can only give a dollar give that. All donations will add up and help. Thank you.

My family means everything to me. No one is without mistakes in their lives, I am just trying to give Randy and Karson a fair chance at a future. I have never tried to do this before because I felt he made the mistake, now pay for it. This is just wrong. He was doing everything right and needs a chance to show he is clean and sober and loves his son.
Any amount will help, we are not giving up. His friends are going to have a Car Wash. We are trying anything. Please help, God Bless you all!
The Impact
The Atty told me if he goes to trial and the parole hearing without an Atty (not a PD) his chances of losing are 90% greater than if he has an Atty.

If he loses he will probably go back to prison for the remainder of the sentence which is 12 more years. His son will be 17 by then and Randy will be 37. I will be 71! In Idaho if he goes away that long he will lose parental rights, the son will get adopted by step-parent, and I lose any chance of Grandparent rights! After adoption in Idaho there are no Grandparent rights. Now I have a chance to sue to see my grandson.

The mother has tried to cut me and my family out of Karson's life since she got involved with the guy she married. Before that we were okay. I have bent over backward trying to do the right thing to see my grandson. Now I'm about to lose my son and grandson together. Please help this is unjust and unfair.
I don't have parents that can give me a free house and car. I just have me and my children and grandchildren. My firends help where they can.
Other Ways You Can Help
We have tried to get a Pro Bono Atty for the Family court case and for the Criminal Case to no Avail. We have tried that avenue for over a year for the Family court issues.
Please if you can only give a dollar give that. All donations will add up and help. Thank you.",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns
|","Boise, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/hire-randy-an-attorney-fund/pica

Growing the Movement for Justice at Fiesta '17!


Drawing crowds of over 20,000 people, Fiesta is an annual free street festival that celebrates the Latinx community through food, music, and art. Having a table at Fiesta would allow us to network with many people who are heavily affected by the very policies our groups work against. 

We need your help to reach more potential supporters in our fight for justice. 

Who are we?

To find out more about each of these two groups, check out our Facebook pages.

Sanctuary City Coalition

International Socialist Organization

 My name is Corey McCaffery and I'm a libertarian.

I'm originally from Indiana and went on to study at Hawai'i Pacific University, where I majored in political science. I have since moved to the Sunshine State and have dedicated my time to spreading the word about libertarianism as much as possible. I have worked with various blogs and have written for a startup libertarian content source called Voluntary News.

In the last few years,the liberty movement has gained a great deal of attention. Thanks to Dr Ron Paul and his supporters, libertarianism has gone from being virtually unheard of, to being a subject discussed even on the mainstream media. There's still a lot of work to be done, though, and that's where I need your help.

Within the last year, I've become more and more disenfranchised with the daily routine of things and have felt like I'm not doing enough to advance this movement. As an INFJ, I find myself avoiding social interaction unless I'm in a situation which necessitates it, like when I'm at work, where political discussion is frowned upon. I'm ready to step out of my comfort zone, though, and really dedicate myself to encouraging others to give thought to libertarian philosophy.
<ul>
• I'm giving up my job and home to trek across the U.S. with a shopping cart full of survival essentials and my cat, Gooby.
• I'll be walking from Daytona Beach Shores, FL to Santa Monica, CA.
• I'll be meeting people and discussing libertarian philosophy with them.
• I'll talk to them about the issues important to them.
• I'll answer questions.
• I'll listen.
• I'll interview politicians, off-grid community members, organic farmers, immigrants, and more.
• I'll analyze human nature from a libertarian perspective
• I'll keep a blog about my travels
• I'll provide valuable philosophical content, firsthand accounts of my interactions, photos, videos, and an action plan for how I believe we can truly advance the liberty movement.
• Walking across the country isn't easy. I need mental, emotional, and financial support.
• I'm hoping to receive $2500 from contributors who are interested in what I am doing and see value in the observations that I will document.
• Every $10 will help me walk 20 miles!
• Having backers behind me will give me an even bigger incentive to see this through til the end. It will also give me the ability to eat every once in a while.
<ul class=""ul1"">
• A resource for fresh content from an individual who's approaching this subject in a new way.
• $10 donations helped me walk 20 miles! They will be listed on my website as a sponsor of the walk.
• $20 helped me walk 40 miles! These donations will receive a postcard from me somewhere along my journey and their name added to the list of sponsors.
• $30 donations helped me walk 60 miles! You will receive all of the above and a guidebook for the sort of planning that goes into a transcontinental walk.
• $50 donations helped me walk 100 miles! You will receive all of the above, plus a personalized, handwritten two page letter from me while I'm out on the road.
<li class=""li3"">$75 donations help me walk 150 miles! You will receive all of the above and a white ""<a href=""http://vlntry.com/shop/#!/~/product/category=0&amp
column2: id=23191616"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" target=""_blank"" title=""vlntry"">Free Markets Free People"" t-shirt from vlntry news!

column1: <li class=""li3"">$100 helped me walk 200 miles! These donations will receive everything listed above, plus a white ""<a href=""http://vlntry.com/shop/#!/~/product/category=0&amp
column2: id=23191625"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" target=""_blank"" title=""vlntry"">Stop believing in authority. Start believing in each other"" t-shirt from vlntry news!

column1: Are you crazy?
Some might say so, but I adhere to the idea that those who are crazy enough to think they can make a difference are the ones who actually do.
Why do you think this will be helpful to the libertarian community?

I think it's important for us to connect with people on a personal level in order to advance this movement. We cannot simply rely on our computer or television screens in order to spread the message. Unfortunately, most people cannot dedicate 100% of their time to talking to others about libertarianism, answering questions, giving advice, etc. That's what I'm hoping to do. I'll speak with hundreds, and possibly thousands, of individuals about the topics important to them, and they might just be willing to talk to their friends, family, and neighbors afterwards. It's hard telling how many people I could introduce to the philosophy when we factor in the butterfly effect.
You expect people to pay for your vacation?

I don't know what sort of person would consider a 3184 mile, 8 month, misearble and grueling walk across the country a vacation. I'll be doing a lot of work on this trip to spread the message of liberty and share my experiences with others.
What sort of homeless person needs $2500?

I'm asking for donations so that I can focus on my message and not have to worry about how I'm going to pay for food and the other supplies I'll need to survive. I assure you that I will be sleeping outside 90% of the time.
Why are you taking your cat? Will he be safe and comfortable?

Simply put, I feel that Gooby is my responsibility and I cannot ask someone else to take care of him. He's like a child to me, and I will be loaded up with supplies to take care of him in case of an emergency. The cart will be outfitted with a fan to ensure that he isn't too hot, and it will be loaded with blankets and a heating pad to ensure that he doesn't get too cold. He's been training with me in preparation for this journey and I would not take him if I didn't feel confident that he is equipped to handle it. Here he is helping me plan our route through Arizona!
Who will you be speaking with?

I'll be speaking with anyone who wants to. I'll talk to strangers and I'll talk to people who contact me along my route. I have interviews set up with organic farmers, off-grid community members, politicians, police officers, immigrants, veterans, and more!
I can't donate, but how else can I help?
See my list of ways below!
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:
<ul class=""ul1"">
• Follow my progress
<li class=""li3"">
Send words of encouragement.
<li class=""li3"">
Send me book recommendations for my trip.
<li class=""li3"">
Contact me to meet me along my route. I would love a hot meal and a shower every once in a while!

Amigos y amigas, hace 8 meses el arzobispo de Piura, Jose Antonio Eguren Anselmi, querelló a mi papá por difamación agravada. Tanto la petición que empecé yo en ese entonces, como la que propuso Amnistía Internacional hace poco, así como las fiestas que se hicieron para recaudar fondos, ayudaron a recibir un montón de apoyo solidario que hizo que mi padre no se sienta solo en todo este proceso. Como ya sabrán, ayer el sistema judicial nos volvió a decepcionar y mi papá fue sentenciado a un año de prisión suspendida, y encima tiene que pagarle al arzobispo sodálite 80, 000 soles por un delito que no cometió. Este juicio ha sido una sangría
column2: el costo económico y emocional que ha significado para él y para toda nuestra familia es inimaginable. Lo mismo está por ocurrirle a Paola Ugaz, quien es coautora de la investigación que desmanteló los abusos perpetrados por el Sodalicio.

column1: Con esta iniciativa, quería pedirles nuevamente su ayuda. Se ha abierto una cuenta para recaudar fondos con el propósito de financiar los gastos legales y de viajes.
Muchísimas gracias!!!

What is Queers 4 Queers?

Queers 4 Queers is a Seattle-based, locally-focused non-profit organization working to improve queer quality of life in our city. We prioritize the needs of queers of color, as well as those who are disabled, immunocompromised, and/or impoverished.
Last summer, founder Xhavier Jacobsen was inspired by the grassroots efforts &
column2: activism in our city. In the absence of a traditional, in-person Pride celebration, he wanted to support the local BIPOC transfemme community. He rallied the skills and involvement of Jonah St. Croix and Andy Wise, and the first Trans BIPOC Care Kit project was underway. Our tiny team contacted dozens of local businesses, collected thousands of dollars in gifts and donations for the cause, and ultimately created over 30 custom Care Kits for BIPOC transfemmes in Seattle, as well as almost 100 assorted Mini-Care Kits.

column1: Before the first Care Kits were delivered, we knew that providing material support to our queer peers was how we wanted to spend our time and effort going into the future. It was the beginning of a long and enthusiastic brainstorming session, beginning with Xhavier's notion to aptly name our organization Queers 4 Queers. We added Cort Olson's savvy to our petite Board of Directors, and began weekly remote meetings to hash out our hopes and expectations for the project.
Now, almost a year later, Q4Q is a state-certified non-profit with a website and a bank account - and big ideas to start putting into action.
Q4Q's biggest sophomore goal is to establish our most far-reaching regular program: the People's Pantry. Developed by Jonah &
column2: Xhavier in collaboration, the People's Pantry will be both a monthly event as well as a perpetual resource supplying the marginalized queer community of Seattle with a range of necessities, including personal &amp
column3: household supplies, sexual health products, ungendered menstrual products, and HRT supplies. In order to collect, organize, safely store, and effectively distribute these goods, Q4Q needs a brick and mortar location.

column1: But we're still working on existing projects (albeit on a smaller scale than we'd like) in the meantime:

You read that timeline right: We're about relaunch our Trans BIPOC Care Kits project, and, at the same time, we are reaching for federal non-profit registration. Federal registration will open doors to grant and funding opportunities no amount of hustle alone can achieve. Being able to pursue grants and donations as a federally-recognized non-profit is the fastest - and arguably only - route to achieving the means to launch more Q4Q programs like the People's Pantry.
We just need the capital to gain the position to swing for the bigger capital, and that is where you as a donor come in.
What We Need
There are just a few, essential items Q4Q is trying to accomplish with this fundraiser:
<ul>
• Pay for the Q4Q federal non-profit application - a cost of $600
• Secure a Q4Q phone number - a cost of ~$150
• Secure an independent domain for the Q4Q website - a cost of ~$400
• Cover printing, shipping, and administrative expenses - an estimated cost of ~$200
• Further fund the Summer 2021 Trans BIPOC Care Kits Program!
Once we've covered these costs, every additional dollar this campaign collects will be applied toward both enhancing the Summer 2021 Trans BIPOC Care Kits and saving up for offices.
The Impact
The Community

Getting Queers 4 Queers off the ground and operating on a federally-recognized level empowers us to facilitate not just a better quality of life for Seattle's most at-risk queer demographics, but tangible, material security and joy. In the words of some of the 2020 Care Kit recipients:

column2:
>Christian Raddler:
“What can I say? The efforts put into sending out these care kits brought me many happy tears. Not only did it make me cry, but it brought a HUGE smile to my face to know what lengths Xhavier and company were willing to go to make sure others in the community were reminded that they were loved, cared about and in the their thoughts. 10/10 they have my support!!!!”

>""This self care kit pushed me to ground me in a way I had not let myself before. I’ve loved that a lot of the goodies were local to the PNW. The clothes were super comfy! I made myself an altar with my tarot deck, my stones, with some aroma things like the beeswax candle. I thought I was already good at self care, but realize that it was only made possible with the community made here. That self care also means caring for those around you, your community. I’m thankful that I was able to get this during at such a time like 2020 ❤ !""

>Tinashae Monet:
""The amount of joy and love I felt when opening up my care package last year was absolutely uncontainable! To receive all of the gifts and hand picked items to remind myself that I’m loved and to love myself at such a chaotic time of year was everything I never knew I needed!!""

column1: The Future
Improving local queer quality of life - tangibly, materially, &
column2: meaningfully - is something you can do today, by helping to build the future foundation of the People's Pantry.  The faster Q4Q accomplishes our early administrative goals, the sooner we can start supplying the most marginalized in our community essentials such as:

column1: <ul>
• household necessities
<li>personal hygiene &amp
• sexual health items
• ungendered menstrual products
• HRT supplies

What's more, when Q4Q is firmly and formally established, we plan to offer much more exciting ways to participate in achieving our future goals, including benefit shows, auctions, and other exciting events that require means and momentum to pull off in grand and exciting fashion.
<h3>Risks &amp
As practical queers, we like to ask ourselves - as we throw ourselves entirely into our shared passion project - what's the worst that could happen?
In a world where our goal is not reached, we put our noses to the grindstone &
column2: keep searching for ways to meet these fundamentals so that we can engage with the real work of benefitting the community. Meeting - or exceeding - our goal with this campaign will put us on track to deliver an incredible Holiday Gift program this winter! It will also allow us to focus on securing the funding for physical offices where we can stage more elaborate programs. If we don't meet our goal here, it will simply take Q4Q longer to reach these fundamental milestone and begin serving the Seattle queer community on a broad, organized scale.

column1: We believe our community deserves these services now.
Other Ways You Can Help
Is your budget stretched thin in these unprecedented times, but you'd like to support the Q4Q cause? Here are some easy things you can do right now that can make all the difference:
Share the Q4Q Campaign

It's simple and effective: Share our campaign far and wide this Pride! It's free and easy to hype the Q4Q campaign across your social media. Share our mission with your family and employers, and help us reach donors we wouldn't be able to without your stunning personal connections! You are community!
In-Kind Donations

Does your personal business or employer have goods or services to donate to the Summer 2021 Trans BIPOC Care Kit Program? We'd love to pass that gift on to the community on your behalf. Ask your boss - and if you are the boss, ask yourself: What do you have to give your queer community today? Then bounce to the Q4Q Donate page:
Donate On Your Schedule
If ties are too tight right now, but abundance is is your future projections, Q4Q is always accepting monetary donations. Follow the link above &
","What is Queers 4 Queers?

Queers 4 Queers is a Seattle-based, locally-focused non-profit organization working to improve queer quality of life in our city. We prioritize the needs of queers of color, as well as those who are disabled, immunocompromised, and/or impoverished.

Last summer, founder Xhavier Jacobsen was inspired by the grassroots efforts & activism in our city. In the absence of a traditional, in-person Pride celebration, he wanted to support the local BIPOC transfemme community. He rallied the skills and involvement of Jonah St. Croix and Andy Wise, and the first Trans BIPOC Care Kit project was underway. Our tiny team contacted dozens of local businesses, collected thousands of dollars in gifts and donations for the cause, and ultimately created over 30 custom Care Kits for BIPOC transfemmes in Seattle, as well as almost 100 assorted Mini-Care Kits.

Before the first Care Kits were delivered, we knew that providing material support to our queer peers was how we wanted to spend our time and effort going into the future. It was the beginning of a long and enthusiastic brainstorming session, beginning with Xhavier's notion to aptly name our organization Queers 4 Queers. We added Cort Olson's savvy to our petite Board of Directors, and began weekly remote meetings to hash out our hopes and expectations for the project.
Now, almost a year later, Q4Q is a state-certified non-profit with a website and a bank account - and big ideas to start putting into action.

Q4Q's biggest sophomore goal is to establish our most far-reaching regular program: the People's Pantry. Developed by Jonah & Xhavier in collaboration, the People's Pantry will be both a monthly event as well as a perpetual resource supplying the marginalized queer community of Seattle with a range of necessities, including personal & household supplies, sexual health products, ungendered menstrual products, and HRT supplies. In order to collect, organize, safely store, and effectively distribute these goods, Q4Q needs a brick and mortar location.
But we're still working on existing projects (albeit on a smaller scale than we'd like) in the meantime:

You read that timeline right: We're about relaunch our Trans BIPOC Care Kits project, and, at the same time, we are reaching for federal non-profit registration. Federal registration will open doors to grant and funding opportunities no amount of hustle alone can achieve. Being able to pursue grants and donations as a federally-recognized non-profit is the fastest - and arguably only - route to achieving the means to launch more Q4Q programs like the People's Pantry.
We just need the capital to gain the position to swing for the bigger capital, and that is where you as a donor come in.
What We Need
There are just a few, essential items Q4Q is trying to accomplish with this fundraiser:
Pay for the Q4Q federal non-profit application - a cost of $600
Secure a Q4Q phone number - a cost of ~$150
Secure an independent domain for the Q4Q website - a cost of ~$400
Cover printing, shipping, and administrative expenses - an estimated cost of ~$200
Further fund the Summer 2021 Trans BIPOC Care Kits Program!
Once we've covered these costs, every additional dollar this campaign collects will be applied toward both enhancing the Summer 2021 Trans BIPOC Care Kits and saving up for offices.
The Impact
The Community

Getting Queers 4 Queers off the ground and operating on a federally-recognized level empowers us to facilitate not just a better quality of life for Seattle's most at-risk queer demographics, but tangible, material security and joy. In the words of some of the 2020 Care Kit recipients:

Christian Raddler:“What can I say? The efforts put into sending out these care kits brought me many happy tears. Not only did it make me cry, but it brought a HUGE smile to my face to know what lengths Xhavier and company were willing to go to make sure others in the community were reminded that they were loved, cared about and in the their thoughts. 10/10 they have my support!!!!”
Mario Martinez:

This self care kit pushed me to ground me in a way I had not let myself before. I’ve loved that a lot of the goodies were local to the PNW. The clothes were super comfy! I made myself an altar with my tarot deck, my stones, with some aroma things like the beeswax candle. I thought I was already good at self care, but realize that it was only made possible with the community made here. That self care also means caring for those around you, your community. I’m thankful that I was able to get this during at such a time like 2020 ❤ !""

Tinashae Monet:""The amount of joy and love I felt when opening up my care package last year was absolutely uncontainable! To receive all of the gifts and hand picked items to remind myself that I’m loved and to love myself at such a chaotic time of year was everything I never knew I needed!!""
The Future

Improving local queer quality of life - tangibly, materially, & meaningfully - is something you can do today, by helping to build the future foundation of the People's Pantry.  The faster Q4Q accomplishes our early administrative goals, the sooner we can start supplying the most marginalized in our community essentials such as:
household necessities
personal hygiene & dental products
sexual health items
ungendered menstrual products
HRT supplies

What's more, when Q4Q is firmly and formally established, we plan to offer much more exciting ways to participate in achieving our future goals, including benefit shows, auctions, and other exciting events that require means and momentum to pull off in grand and exciting fashion.
Risks & Challenges
As practical queers, we like to ask ourselves - as we throw ourselves entirely into our shared passion project - what's the worst that could happen?

In a world where our goal is not reached, we put our noses to the grindstone & keep searching for ways to meet these fundamentals so that we can engage with the real work of benefitting the community. Meeting - or exceeding - our goal with this campaign will put us on track to deliver an incredible Holiday Gift program this winter! It will also allow us to focus on securing the funding for physical offices where we can stage more elaborate programs. If we don't meet our goal here, it will simply take Q4Q longer to reach these fundamental milestone and begin serving the Seattle queer community on a broad, organized scale.
We believe our community deserves these services now.
Other Ways You Can Help
Is your budget stretched thin in these unprecedented times, but you'd like to support the Q4Q cause? Here are some easy things you can do right now that can make all the difference:
Share the Q4Q Campaign

It's simple and effective: Share our campaign far and wide this Pride! It's free and easy to hype the Q4Q campaign across your social media. Share our mission with your family and employers, and help us reach donors we wouldn't be able to without your stunning personal connections! You are community!
In-Kind Donations

Does your personal business or employer have goods or services to donate to the Summer 2021 Trans BIPOC Care Kit Program? We'd love to pass that gift on to the community on your behalf. Ask your boss - and if you are the boss, ask yourself: What do you have to give your queer community today? Then bounce to the Q4Q Donate page:
Donate On Your Schedule
If ties are too tight right now, but abundance is is your future projections, Q4Q is always accepting monetary donations. Follow the link above & bookmark us. We'll be here!",7.0,0,"1 Campaign

Специфични средносрочни цели

Атакуване на несправедливия лимит от 35 изборни секции на държава, благодарение на създадения прецедент в САЩ (подадени заявления за 38 изборни секции)

Атакуване на недостатъчно активната и неефективната държавна политика по отношения на възможностите за отваряне на достатъчно изборни секции на територията на ФР Германия. Знаем, че във ФР Германия на която живеят над 200 000 български граждани, за които се отварят една 12 секции в 8 населени места, в които има посолство или консулство.

Общи цели

Въпреки, че се намират на хиляди километри далеч от Родината, българските граждани по света искат и могат да защитават правата си пред българските институции.

ЦИК взима понякога несправедливи решения. Понякога тези решения се основават на Изборен кодекс, който погазва правата, залегнали в Конституцията.

Целта на водените дела не е обезателно спечелване на делото. Борбата от дистанция и в съкратени срокове е неравна и не гарантира 100% успех.

Водените дела изискват ресурси не само от страна на гражданите, но и на ответните институции. Институциите нямат неограничени ресурси и решителната позиция на гражданите ги респектира и прави внимателни за в бъдеще.

Делата привличат вниманието както на обществеността и медиите, така и на други институции, които биха застанали зад каузите на българските граждани в чужбина (например омбудсман).

Допълнителни предимства на всяко водено дело са, че

• се получава достъп до вътрешни документи на институциите, които съдържат ценна информация за начина, по който те упражняват своята власт и изпълняват своите задължения (в случая ЦИК, МВнР, посолства и консулства)
• се натрупва ценен процесуален опит за дистанционно адвокатско представителство на интересите на българските граждани пред българските институции

Материали по съдебните дела

  • Обжалвано решение 4400-НС на ЦИК от 04.03.2017 (тук)
• Секция в Ег Харбър, Ню Джързи (тук)
• Секция в Нейпълс, Флорида (тук)
• Секции в Германия (тук)
